name: Kirigalpottha Mountain
description: Sri Lanka’s Kirigalpottha Mountain in the Nuwara Eliya District at a height of 2388m is the country’s second tallest mountain. A feature of the mountain which gave it its name is its tall trees which have mottled white bark.

name: Gal Ekka Ella
description: Due to it being located underneath the Gal Ella rail bridge it is relatively unknown. However for those that want to visit this 5 meter high waterfall it is only a 1.15kms hike from the Heeloya railway station.

name: Balana Fort
description: Today in remnants and managed by the Sri Lanka Archaeological Department, Belana Fort, near the Alagalla Mountain Range in the Kingdom of Kandy, once played a major role in Sri Lanka’s history. The fort was originally built to protect Sri Lankans from successive invasion forces of the Portuguese, English and Dutch from 1505 to 1948. One battle around the fort is known to have cost 4,000 Portuguese invaders their lives.

name: Dambegoda Bodhisattva statue
description: The 15 cubits-high Dambegoda Bodhisattva statue is mentioned in texts dating back to 1780 CE and is proof of the strong influence of the Maitreya cult in that period of Sri Lanka’s history.

name: Maligatenne ( Nuwaragalkande) Ruins
description: For centuries a trinity of reservoir, village and temple were a way of life for the Sri Lankan people and at the ruins at Nuwaragalkande all three aspects can be seen. It is said that the area was used by Mahasen in the 3rd century and that some of the ruins are of his Maligatenne (semi-palace).

name: Vessagiriya Ruins - Anuradhapura
description: Located among 3 huge boulders the Vessagiriya Ruins at Anuradhapura include 23 caves and a mysterious round building which archaeologists are struggling to learn its purpose.

name: Welgam Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The Welgam Rajamaha Viharaya is known to Hindus as the Natanar Kovil and so that is probably why it was not destroyed by the Chola invaders who did destroy many other Buddhist temples in the area.

name: Nilgala Forest
description: Nilgala forest reserve is located in the Monaragala District and is a popular place to visit for both bird watchers and butterfly enthusiasts. Visitors to the forest will usually use the footpath which starts at Pitakumbura village.

name: Thattu Ella Falls
description: The 14 meter high Thattu Ella Falls located in the village of Lankagama in Sri Lanka’s Galle District is just one of five waterfalls within a stretch of 1km of the Hariyawa stream.

name: Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil
description: Located at Nallur in Sri Lanka’s Northern Province Nallur Kandaswamy Kovil is considered a significant Hindu Temple. Originally founded in the 10th century the temple was further developed in the 13th century when Kotte Kings built their capital’s palace nearby.

Huluganga Ella
description: Sourced by water from the Knuckles Mountains, the 75 meter high Huluganga Ella is popular with visitors both local and foreign. Water flowing over the falls has recently been reduced due to a dam having been built above it however, environmentalists are petitioning to have the authorities allow the release of extra water.

name: Kudawewa village experience by Duara travels
description: Thanks to Duara Travels visitors to Sri Lanka can enjoy a real village life experience in Kudawewa village, a quiet countryside village near Rathna Waterfalls. Visitors will actually stay with a family from the village of a 3 or 6 day, authentic Sri Lankan village experience.

name: Katudeniya Purana Viharaya
description: The Katudeniya Purana Viharaya has been in existence since at least the 16th century but unfortunately was destroyed several times by the British in the early 19th century. Although the temple was destroyed many of the paintings and the Buddha statue remained and can still be seen today.

name: Dimbulagala Raja maha Viharaya
description: Located in what was once known as the kingdom of the Vakshas the Dimbulagala Raja maha Viharaya was a place known for an abode for sacred beings. This place was also known as a great place of learning but over the years fell into unused and became overgrown.

Udawatta Kele Sanctuary
description: Udawatta Kele Sanctuary is a forest reserve covering 257 acres of hillside in the city of Kandy. In the days of the Kandyan Kingdom the area was just known as the garden above the palace but in 1856 it became a forest reserve and then in 1938 it attained its official sanctuary status.

name: Magul Maha Viharaya, Arugam Bay
description: The Magul Maha Viharaya at Arugam Bay must date back to at least the 2nd century BC as it is said to be the wedding site for King Kavantissa and Princess Viharamaha Devi who was later sacrificed to the sea in a golden boat. The temple is perhaps best known today for its distinctive moonstone which is adorned with flower motifs including lotus leaves.

Arankele Forest Monastery
description: Listed as one of Sri Lanka’s premier hermitages, Arankele Forest Monastery is popular with both local and foreign visitors alike. Founded in the 8th century as a monastery it has been home to some notable monks, such as Arahat Malyadeva thero. Today it is still used for practicing both old and new meditation techniques. Located in a quiet location, most visitors leave feeling relaxed and refreshed.

name: Shri Shailakutarama Purana Gallen Viharaya
description: Located on the Hikkaduwa – Baddegama Road the Shri Shailakutarama Purana Gallen Viharaya has been preserved by Sri Lanka’s Department of Archaeology. This is the site of an ancient cave temple if you climb the steps up a boulder to the main cave, you will be able to see the reclining Buddha and statue.

name: Temple of the Tooth Relic (Dalada Maligawa)
description: Although its name is Dalada Maligawa it is often referred to as the Temple of the Tooth Relic and is located in Kandy City. The relic was an important part in Sri Lankan politics as whoever held the relic held governance of the country. It is mainly due to this temple that Kandy, the last capital of Sri Lankan kings, is today a World Heritage Site.

name: The Refectory of Mihintale
description: The refectory at the Mihintale ruins can be distinguished by the two stone canoes. One canoe would be for the rice whilst the other for gruel. The size of a monastery’s refectory can give a guide as to how many monks would have used the monastery at different times in its history.

name: Palace complex of King Nissanka Malla
description: Although from what remains of the Palace complex of King Nissanka Malla which had 2 stories, the lower made of blocks and the 2nd made of wood, it may have seemed impressive for its day when it was built in the 12th century, it would have been dwarfed by King Maha Parakramabahu’s palace which is said to have had 7 stories with 1000 rooms on each, especially as it was just 1kms away and built in the same century.

name: Namal Uyana - The Rose Quartz Mountains
description: The Rose Quartz Mountain Range is distinctive and unique for two reasons. First for Namal Uyana which is a 260 acre forest dominated by Iron Wood Trees which, as they are endemic to Sri Lanka, are very rare. Secondly these mountains are known for having the largest deposits of Rose Quartz in Asia.

name: Erupothana Reservoir
description: Sri Lankans have been building huge reservoirs since the 4th century BC and the Erupothana Reservoir is 1 of a few still functioning in the Erupothana region. Perhaps uniquely however, at 1 place the Erupothana Reservoir uses a natural rock formation instead of a sluice gate to control water flow.

name: Pahalagama Archaeology Site
description: The Pahalagama Archaeology Site is located in the Trincomalee District on the Adampane – Kuchchaveli road. Although the stupa and the whole site may be small, it is well maintained and the lack of Buddha statues but his footprints engraved in stone, indicate the site dates back to the 2nd or 3rd century BC.

name: Pusulpitiya Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The village of Pusulpitiya in Kotmale on the banks of the Kotmale Oya and the Pusulpitiya Rajamaha Viharaya are associated with many legends in Sri Lanka due to on several occasions, the Sacred Tooth Relic finding its way here during different times of unrest and also due to it being the village where Prince Dutugemunu spent his childhood.

name: Sri Nagala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although Sri Nagala Rajamaha Viharaya had been neglected for a long period, it has now once more been restored. Located in the foothills of the Nikawewa mountain range this temple has a history dating back to the 3rd century BC.

name: Lunugamvehera National Park
description: Although the Lunugamvehera National Park has a wide assortment of wildlife of its own which include at least 43 mammals, 183 birds, 12 amphibians, 33 reptiles and 21 fish species it also acts as a migration route for elephants moving between the Yala and Udawalawe national parks.

name: Ramboda Oya Falls
description: Located in the Pussellawa area with a height of 109 meters Ramboda Oya Falls is the 11th highest in Sri Lanka. The waterfall is sourced by the Panna Oya which is a tributary of the Kothmale Oya and can be accessed at the Ramboda Pass on the A5 highway.

description: Located 4kms from Wanduraba on the Kottawagama road, Mabotuwana Sri Sumanarama Purana Vilgamu Rajamaha Viharaya is considered to have the largest Tampita Viharaya in Sri Lanka’s southern region. Built in 1240 this temple is credited to being built by the famous Devapathiraja who built two others in this same region.

name: Polhena Beach
description: Polhena Beach Is located just 2kms from Matara City and so is popular with locals rather than tourists. This means that the beach is rarely crowded and so is considered ideal for romantic get-a-ways. Although parts of the nearby reef were damaged during the 2004 Tsunami, it still thrives and so is also a good place for snorkeling.

name: Kalugala Hulan Ella
description: Having travelled along the Uda Dumbara – Kalugala road for about 3.5kms visitors will see the impressive 80 meter high Kalugala Hulan Ella waterfall. It should perhaps be noted that as there are 2 Hulan Ella waterfalls in Sri Lanka, this is the 1 at Kalugala and not the other 1 which is located close to the popular Kalthota Doowili Ella.

name: Hiyare Reservoir Sanctuary
description: The Hiyare Reservoir Sanctuary also consists of a Biodiversity Research Center and is located just outside of Galle. The research center today provides a breeding center for endangered species and an animal rescue program.

name: Shiva Kovil (no. 3) And Gansh Kovil of Polonnaruwa
description: Along with 2 Shiva Kovils at Polonnaruwa there is a Gansh Kovil all of which have been partially restored. These Kovils can be found on the left side once you enter Polonnaruwa’s inner city ruins.

name: Kande Viharaya
description: A giant Buddha statue sits here. Located on a hill near Aluthgama Town in the Kalutara District Kande Viharaya is one of the major Buddhist temples in Sri Lanka. Recognized by the government as an archaeological site the temple was built in 1734. Enclosed in an octagonal wall the Bodhi Tree here is considered of particular importance.

name: Dickwella Beach
description:
22kms from Matara in the Matara District in the Southern Province is the small coastal town of Dickwella. As well as being known as the location of the largest sitting Buddha Statue at 50 meters tall, it is also known for its sandy beach which is long and protected by headlands, making it safe for swimming. 

Some people prefer to swim here because it's less crowded than the nearby Hiriketiya beach.

name: Elle Wala Ella Fall
description: Concealed in the jungle 5kms from Wellawaya Town in the Monaragala District, at a height of only 4 meters, Elle Wala Ella Fall may be relatively small but it is a beautiful waterfall. To reach these falls take the Wellawaya to Ella Road and turn off opposite the Rathmal Vehera Ancient Temple.

name: Butterfly Peace Garden, Batticaloa.
description: Established in 1996 the Butterfly Peace Garden, Batticaloa is a non-profit organization which was founded to help children who had been traumatized by civil war in the region. In 2004 however, it also helped victims of the tsunami which devastated the region.

It is therefore made up of numerous small waterfalls but they are known by just the combined name, not individual ones.

name: The Hill Club
description: Located in Nuwara Eliya, Sri Lanka the Hill Club is a gentleman’s club established by the British in 1876. Although it was founded by foreign coffee and tea planters for use by foreign coffee and tea planters, today it has 750 members both foreign and Sri Lankan.

name: Kande Ela Forest Park
description:
Most visitors to Sri Lanka will probably want to visit Horton Plain to see the End of the World however, many will not know to stop at Kande Ela Forest Park on their way and that could be regrettable. This is an educational facility created by the Department of Forest Conservation and gives visitors an insight into planting, logging and reforestation.

Not really a hike but a small walk!!

name: Weliwita Sri Sanghikarama Tampita Viharaya
description: The Weliwita Sri Sanghikarama Temple was important in reviving Buddhism in Sri Lanka during the reign of King Keerthi Sri Rajasinghe in the 18th century. During this period Tampita Viharaya were popular features in temples and the one at this temple is a typical example, being built on 20 stone pillars, each 2 feet 9 inches high.

name: Ravana Ella Lower Fall
description: Located in the Ravana Ella Wildlife Sanctuary 6kms from the Ella railway station, Ravana Ella falls are a popular attraction with visitors. Although only with a height of 25 meters these falls are considered to be one of the widest in Sri Lanka however, there is a great difference in the falls between the wet and dry seasons.

name: Gonagiri Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located in thick forest with a backdrop of a huge boulder Gonagiri Rajamaha Viharaya covers an area of about 25 acres. Built in the 3rd century BC this temple complex allows visitors to submerge in an atmosphere of serene tranquility.

name: Batticaloa
description: Batticaloa, known as Maṭṭakkaḷappu in Tamil and Maḍakalapuwa in Sinhala, stands as a prominent city within Sri Lanka's Eastern Province and once served as its capital. Currently, it functions as the administrative hub for the Batticaloa District. Home to the Eastern University of Sri Lanka, Batticaloa also thrives as an important center for commerce. Located on the nation's east coast, the city is 111 kilometers south of Trincomalee and is nestled on an island. Just 35 kilometers to the northwest lies Pasikudah, a favored tourist spot known for its beaches and consistently warm, shallow lagoons.

name: Dodan Ella Falls
description: With diverse species of wildlife and various herbal plants the area around the 53 meter high Dodan Ella Falls has been used as locations for movies. The authorities are currently investigating the area as local villages claim that some of the caves in the area may contain artifacts of archaeological importance.

name: Athugala Buddha Statue
description: Located in north central Sri Lanka near Kekirawa is a 40 meter standing statue of Buddha known as the Avukana Statue. Beautifully carved to show Buddha’s closely worn garment, this is perhaps the best standing statue of Buddha in the country and as such is a popular tourist attraction.

name: Handapan Ella Falls
description: With a height of 23 meters the Handapan Ella Falls form the origin of the Rakwana River. Located in the area where the Kandyan Kingdom existed, local legend is that a chieftain of the kingdom hid his treasure in the falls.

name: Silachetiya (Kujjatissa) Stupa
description: Silachetiya stupa which is also known by the name Kujjatissa was built in the 2nd century BC. This stupa has been associated with Bikku who according to chronicles had special powers. It is said that when he died his body levitated to this site and has been performing miracles ever since.

name: Sitakotuwa Ella Falls
description: Located in the Kandy District of Sri Lanka is the 60 meter high Sitakotuwa Ella Falls. This waterfall is known in legends as it is said to be where Queen Sita had been kept in a cave and also where King Ravana is said to have died.

name: Nandimithra Nawawangu Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Nandimithra Nawawangu Rajamaha Viharaya is thought to have been built in the 2nd century BC and at that time covered a huge amount of land. Sadly today however what is left of the temple covers a much smaller area and much of it has disappeared through time with even the stupa appearing as little more than a mound of earth.

name: Pitakele Duwili Ella Falls
description: There are several waterfalls in the Sinharaja Rainforest but the 8 meter high Pitakele Duwili Ella Falls is considered to be the widest, especially in the rainy season. Duwili, roughly translated, means dust cloud which is what the spray from the falls looks like as it plunges to the waters below.

name: Hike up Narangala Mountain
description: With a height of over 1500 meters Narangala Mountain is the highest peak in the Uva region. Although it is high it is very popular with hikers as its ascent is not too difficult. Those visitors that do hike to its top are rewarded with a spectacular sight and learn why the mountain is known as the Golden peak.

name: Kabella Lena cave Temple
description: Although the Kabella Lena cave Temple houses the largest reclining Buddha Statue in the country, access to see it is only allowed when the priest is present. The temple was built in the 1st century BC in the3 middle of alarge rock and was known for its magnificent pool however, due to the pool’s lack of attention it is not as grand as it once was.

name: Kumbaloluwa Ella Fall
description: Cascading down a total of 14 meters in 2 sections into a deep gorge the Kumbaloluwa Ella Fall is said to have taken the life of a Buddhist monk. Families in the local villages use the falls as their source of water.

Whoever built it though it is known that the British used it for many years and then it fell into disrepair until it was taken over by the Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology who restored it. After its restoration it came under the control of the Urban Development Authority for a short while before once again changing hands to become a cottage industry for a local temple.

description: Boasting one of the largest Tampita Vihara in the Kandy District, Weligodapola Tampita Viharaya was built in 1755 with the Tampita Vihara being added about 20 years later.

name: Pepiliyana Sunethradevi Maha Pirivena
description: It is said that King Parakramabahu VI built the Pepiliyana Sunethradevi Maha Pirivena in honour of his mother in the early 15th century but whilst that fact is not disputed, some have claimed that it was also in honour of his love for a low caste girl who although he had fallen in love with, was not allowed to see. Those that claim the second part of the story say the building is built on the site of that girl’s house.

name: Kabaragala Rock

description: Located in Southern Sri Lanka the Kanneliya - Dediyagala - Nakiyadeniya (KDN) Biosphere Reserve is one of only two remaining rainforests in the country and as such was designated a biosphere reserve by UNESCO in 2004. It is said that this area is the richest in floral diversity in all of South Asia.

name: Nagarak Ella Falls
description: The 9 meter high Nagarak Ella Falls can be found near the Nonpareil Estate on the Horton Plain Road. This waterfall is sourced by several streams which meet at the top of the falls and having dropped down the falls is received in a basin formed out of sheer rock.

name: Bihalpola Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although in ruins today, Bihalpola Rajamaha Viharaya which was built in the 3rd century BC was reconstructed again in the 1st century BC. What can still be seen at this ancient site is a stupa, some steps and some paintings from the period showing King Walagamba.

name: Lover's Leap Falls
description: 3kms from Nuwara Eliya town in Sri Lanka’s high mountains is the 30 meter high Lover's Leap Falls. The fresh mountain water from the bottom of the falls is used by the villagers. It is said that the falls got their name after a Prince’s subjects did not like his choice of lover and so the lovers jumped to their death at these falls.

name: Atadage - Polonnaruwa Kingdom
description: Atadage now is in ruins but it was once a temple which had been built on 54 stone pillars. As “Ata” means 8 it is said that the temple was built to house 8 holy relics, 1 of which is known to be the tooth relic of Buddha. These relics were probably housed on the second floor of the temple but today the only sign of that floor are a few granite steps which remain. Built by King Vijayabahu I (1070-1110)

name: Ganga Adventures
description: Stand up paddle tours are rapidly becoming a popular attraction in Sri Lanka and leading the way in this field of adventure are Ganga Adventures. Visitors can today choose between options of 1 to 3 day paddling adventures along some of Sri Lanka’s rivers or an adventure paddling off the coast.

name: Kahatagaha Graphite Mines
description: The Kahatagaha Graphite Mines is one of Sri Lanka’s largest mines and has been since it opened in 1872. First owned by a British company and then a local company it was nationalized in 1972 but is now operated by a government owned company.

description: Naipena Viharaya was a Hindu Temple that was built for the worship of Vishnu but somewhat unexpectedly, no statues of Vishnu have yet been found among the remains.

name: Kalaniya Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Located just 7kms outside Colombo the Kalaniya Raja Maha Viharaya is said to have a close attachment with the Sri Lankan government and a popular saying is that if the temple should fall, so will the Sri Lankan government.

name: Galway's Land National Park
description: What was once declared a wildlife sanctuary since 1938, Galway's Land National Park earned National Park status in 2006. This relatively small national park is located in Nuwara Eliya City as well as Victoria Park are considered to be 2 of the most important birding sites in Sri Lanka with at least 20 species of rare birds nesting in them.

name: Edagala Forest Hermitage
description: Located on the site of an ancient cave temple on a road leading off the Udawalawe – Thanamalwila Road 2kms before reaching Thanamalwila, Edagala Forest Hermitage is still in use today. As the hermitage is still in use today visitors are reminded they should not disturb any meditating bikkus that may be on the site.

name: Elephant Rock Surf Point, Arugam Bay
description: About 4kms south of Arugam Bay is a place called Elephant Rock which is renowned for being an excellent place for surfing. Apart from surfing elephant rock affords visitors a great opportunity to explore small isolated beaches in the area and of course, as its name implies, an opportunity to see elephants.

name: Bambaragala Monastery - Theldeniya
description: The Bambaragala Monastery and temple are situated at an elevation among a mass of rocks with residence for the priests located about halfway up the steps to the temple. Many caves surround this complex and several of them have inscriptions, some dating back to the 2nd and 3rd century BC. Paintings adorn the walls of the temple while on the ceiling is a drawing of a lotus in full bloom.

name: Galagama Ella Falls (Kathi Gahana Ella)
description: The Galagama Ella Falls are over 100 meters in height and are located along the Belihul Oya. Although these falls can be more easily reached via Horton Plains many visitors prefer hiking from Belihuloya.

name: Anagimala Ella Falls
description: Although this 46 meter high falls require a 3km trek to reach, the trek is easy and the falls are surrounded by flora and flora including orchids and many species of butterflies. The falls are in Galle district and within the Kanneliya Forest Reserve and so is a popular attraction for visitors.

name: Ambulugala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Muwangala Raja Maha Vihara is an ancient Buddhist Temple located in Muwangala which has formerly been recognized as an archaeological site by the Sri Lankan government. Whilst ruined remains of the ancient temple are on top of a rocky outcrop, more recent additions to the temple are located on the lower ground. The presence of Sri Pathul Gal or Asanaghara in the ancient temple is, to archeologists, a sign that it pre-dates the building of Buddhist statues in the country.

name: Somawathiya National Park
description: Located 266kms northeast of Colombo Somawathiya was designated a National Park in 1986 having been a bird sanctuary for 20 years prior to that. As well as being the habitat for wildlife in the Mahaweli River it is also home to an ancient stupa which is said to contain the Ancient Tooth Relic of Buddha.

name: Ritigala Ancient Monastery
description: The remains of the Ritigala Ancient Monastery is now an archaeological site located on Ritigala Mountain. In recent years access to these ruins has improved for both archaeologists and visitors alike due to improvements made since Ritigala Mountain became a strict natural reserve.

name: Ahas Bokku Ella Falls
description: These falls which consist of several falls all falling from a height of 30 meters, offer an excellent treat for true nature lovers. A rough translation of the falls name suggests they are “folds from the Sky”, a reference to their beauty. Located in the Kalutara District 6.5kms from Ambatenna Bridge the falls are relatively easy to reach by road.

name: Salgala Forest Monastery
description: There are several cave temples in Sri Lanka which could have famously been the place where King Walagambha hid for his several years in exile but the Salgala Forest Monastery is considered to be the favourite among leading experts. This is of course an ancient monastery but in the 20th century it was once again revitalized and has become a perfect example where visitors can witness how Sri Lankan Buddhist Monks really live.

name: Talangama Lake and Wetlands
description: Being located less than an hour’s drive from Colombo Talangama Lake and Wetlands allow visitors to the capital to more easily experience much of Sri Lanka’s wildlife. Wetlands are of course enjoyed by birds and visitors can hope to see many of the 100 different species that frequent this thriving natural habitat.

name: Buddhangala Monastery
description: Deep in the jungle 7kms from Ampura, Buddhangala Monastery covers 1280 acres and includes 5 rocks where, now in ruins, a monastery once stood. Established in the 4th century BC over the course of thousands of years the monastery became overgrown and infested but in 1964 Kalutara Dhammananda cleared the area with help from a few local Buddhists.

name: Katu Kithul Ella Falls
description: Stories surrounding the 15 meter high Katu Kithul Ella Falls tell of a large man in white sometimes climbing down the waterfall and anyone who sees him will become sick. There is a katukithul tree at the top of the falls and so that is what the falls are named after.

name: Ochchappu Kallu Buddhist Ruins (Wilpattu NP)
description: Located inside the Wilpattu National Park, now in ruins, is what is thought to have been a large complex known as the Ochchappu Kallu Buddhist Shrine. Although the rock ledges are still intact the stupas and other details have all been destroyed by treasure hunters leaving only ruins behind them.

name: Aukana (Awkana) Buddha Statue
description: Although many of the Buddha statues in Sri Lanka are known to be 2000 years old it is thought that the Aukana Statue was carved in the 5th century. This statue is 46 feet in height and features Buddha giving a blessing. This, like many statues, had a canopy in order to protect it from the elements but in this instance the Sri Lankan Archeological Department authorized its removal.

name: Giant's Footprint at Delft Island
description: Delft Island is located about 30kms from Sri Lanka’s mainland and is rich in history. Apart from its historic attraction the island is popular with visitors due its abundance of horses left over from the colonial eras and for its giant footprint. Both by its size and true to local legends the footprint is of a man who would have been 40 feet tall.

name: Naindanawa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Naindanawa Rajamaha Viharaya in the village of Polpithigama is no longer a popular place of worship but archaeologists still have an interest in it due to its unusual rock carving of a 7 headed cobra. Although some experts consider the carving to have been made in the 3rd century, others think it may have been made by the ancient Cobra Tribe who existed in the 6th century BC.

name: Ceylon Resort
description: Recommended by one of our customer

name: Galle Face Green
description: In the heart of Colombo, along the coast is a 12 acre urban park known as Galle Face Green. Although the green was originally created by the Dutch as a place to position their cannon, the promenade was established by the British Governor in 1859. People fly kites here and there are plenty of local food stalls. Good for an evening sunset, and, there are other resturants around if you want something a bit fancier.

name: Niyamgamdora Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Despite the origin and history of the Niyamgamdora Rajamaha Viharaya not being known other than it was built sometime during the Kandyan Era, it has not stopped the Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology from making parts of it a protected site.

name: Attanagalla Raja Maha Viharaya - Nittambuwa
description: This is one of the most famous of Sri Lanka’s ancient royal temples. Legends say that the temple is built on the site where an ex- king and future Buddha (Bodhisattva) completed one of the ten perfections to become an enlightened one. The temple dates back to the 3rd century and is located 28 miles northeast of the capital, Colombo.

name: Wisari Ella Fall / Alikola Oya Falls
description: Located in the Badulla District the 20 meter high Wisari Ella Fall (Alikola Oya Falls) is formed by 2 rivers, the Punagala and Alikola but flows into the Kirindi River. Situated on Maha Kande Mountain’s eastern slope these falls are hidden well inside the Mountains of Uva.

name: Kotasara Sri Piyangala Raja Maha Viharaya
description: With a history going back to the 3rd century BC Kotasara Sri Piyangala Raja Maha Viharaya is located at Bibile. The ruins of this ancient temple complex stretch over 12 acres but of most interest to many is the Patanagara building which measures 13 x 11 meters and was added in the 2nd century BC.

name: Senota Enterprises - DPMC Service Dealer
description: Main mechanic in south and helper

name: Viharahinna Ruins
description: Hidden in jungle are the Viharahinna Ruins. Although archaeologists struggle to locate ancient artifacts in the dark shrub, they have found some pillars which would appear to have belonged to some pretty impressive sized buildings.

name: Seemapauwa Forest Monastery
description: 25 acres of forest which surround the Seemapauwa Forest Monastery in Angunakolapalessa has been found to reveal many ancient artifacts. This is hardly any surprise considering that according to inscriptions found at the site, the monastery has been in existence since the 2nd century BC.

name: Peradeniya Hanging Bridge
description: Hanging Bridges like the one at Peradeniya are fairly common in Sri Lanka but whilst at one time3 they were built and hung by ropes, today steel cables are used. To many though, steel cables are just as un-nerving as the ropes as the bridge still swings and creeks as you cross it watching for missing or broken wooden planks as you go.

name: Sinha Pokuna of Mihintale
description: Sinha Pokuna at Mihintale is one of three ponds or bathing places which can still be recognized today from ancient times. Ancient monasteries would use both natural and artificial waterways for irrigation and for daily use by the monks

name: Ambuluwawa Temple
description: Although called a temple Ambuluwawa Temple is today, a place of worship for all 4 major religions in Sri Lanka, each with their own worship areas. As well as attracting people from all 4 religions, the temple, which is built on a summit with an elevation of 3500 feet above sea level, provides a great view point for both pilgrims and other visitors.

name: Sangamuwa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Sangamuwa Rajamaha Viharaya is the site of, where carved in to a rock, what must be one of the world’s first peace agreements. Chiseled into the rock is an agreement between Gajabahu II and Parakramabahu I in the mid-12th century to cease the warring between their rival factions.

name: Isurumuniya Viharaya
description: The Isurumuniya Viharaya you see today is located a couple of hundred meters away from the original which was built in the 3rd century BC. This temple is thought to be the place where the sacred tooth relic was kept when it was first brought to Sri Lanka. The temple is perhaps better known today though due to a carving of a couple which was found there. Experts cannot decide if the couple is Prince Saliya and his mistress or the Hindu God and Goddess, Siva and Parvathi.

name: Kattankudy Heritage Museum
description: The history of Muslims in Sri Lanka goes back to the start of the 17th century in the Kandyan Kingdom. Exhibiting the rich heritage of those Muslims and Muslims in general is the Kattankudy Heritage Museum. Kattankudy is just one of the many towns in the Batticaloa District which is dominated by Muslims.

name: Pilimathalawa Brick Arch Bridge
description: The Pilimathalawa Brick Arch Bridge, which has never needed repairs since it was built by the British in the early 1800s is thought to be the oldest brick bridge still in use in Sri Lanka today. The bridge is 70 meters long and comprises of four archways and although one of five bridges built on the Colombo – Kandy road, it is the only one still open to vehicular traffic today.

name: Panduwasnuwara Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although Panduwasnuwara enjoyed a brief history as the country’s capital in the 12th century archaeologists have found evidence to support it had been a major city of importance since at least the 7th century. Although today there is a new temple, 16 stone pillars and some artifacts can be seen from the older Panduwasnuwara Rajamaha Viharaya.

name: Ranagala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: 500 meters in front of the Ranagala Rajamaha Viharaya which has been renovated, a Bo Tree can be seen which is thought to have been planted in the 3rd century BC. One of the unusual things about this temple is that at the top of a rock there is a well which has been carved into it. The inside walls of the well have been smoothed but no one knows the reason why but it is said that ancient treasures have been hidden inside the well.

name: Little Basses lighthouse
description: Little Basses lighthouse is located north east of Great Basses Reef Lighthouse on a reef named Kuda Ravana Kotuwa. This lighthouse is one of the most famous in Asia and although it is maintained by the Sri Lankan Navy, after receiving some damage in the 2004 Tsunami, the British lighthouse authority helped in its repair.

description: Duara travels have created a unique experience for visitors to Sri Lanka and that is to experience traditional Sri Lankan village life by staying 3 days with a typical village family, eating, sleeping and being entertained by them. Although organized by Duara travels village communities receive a portion of the cost paid by travellers.

name: Bandagiriya Ancient Viharaya
description: Bandagiriya is the highest point in the Hambantota District and at its summit is the ancient temple or Viharaya. Built in the 2nd century BC it must have then, as today, offered some great views of the surrounding area.

Govinda Hela (Westminister Abbey)
description: Nicknamed Westminster Abbey by the British during their reign in Sri Lanka, Govinda Hela is a huge rock which towers 570 meters above the ground in the Uva province. The rock mountain can be seen from the Siyabanduwa- Ampara but if visitors want to get closer they should be aware to take care as the surrounding area is a protected forest.

name: Batticaloa Lagoon Environmental Learning Centre
description: The Batticaloa Lagoon Environmental Learning Centre is an ideal place to learn about Batticaloa’s largest lagoon’s environment whilst at the same time enjoying some great views of it. Having learned about the ecosystem many visitors to the center then take a short boat ride to experience it for themself in the nearby eco-park.

name: Paurukanda Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The stupa at Paurukanda Rajamaha Viharaya is perhaps somewhat unique as it has been built on stone but what attracts visitors to it is the Buddha footprint which was carved in rock in front of it in the 19th century. Located on top of a hill, trees give shade for those that climb the steps and the path to the top.

name: Bodhimalakarama Tampita Viharaya
description: Located 85kms from Colombo on the Colombo to kandy road is the village of Mangalagama. This ancient village is known as the place where a Bo Tree sapling took root whilst the pilgrim transporting it rested overnight. On hearing the news the Kandyan King had the Bodhimalakarama Tampita Viharayaon around the tree. The pilgrim’s name was Mangala and the village grew around the temple, hence its name.

name: Diyakerella Ella Ella
description: Located in the Kandy District at Meemure Village the Diyakerella Ella Falls makes a loud noise as it thunders down a 45 meter high rock face. Surrounded in jungle and with the Lakkgala Mountain as a backdrop these falls are worth a visit.

name: Ratnapura National Museum - Elelepola Walawwa
description: The National Museum in Ratnapura was opened in 1988 in what was once a mansion (Walawwa) for Maha Adikaram, a tax collector for the British after the Kandyan Kingdom’s annexation.

name: Dambulla cave Temple
description: Located in the central part of Sri Lanka about 72kms north of Kandy is the Dambulla Cave Temple which is also known as the Golden Temple of Dambulla and has been a World Heritage Site since 1991. Although the complex, which is considered one of the largest and best preserved cave temple complexes in Sri Lanka, consists of 80 caves, most paintings and statues of interest are located in just 5 of the caves.

name: St. Marie's Cathedral, Batticaloa
description: To give it its proper title the cathedral church of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Batticaloa is an iconic landmark in Puliyanthivu. Built in 1808 it started its days as a co-cathedral with Trincomalee-Batticaloa but became a cathedral for Batticaloa only in 2012 with the creation of it becoming its own diocese.

name: Nakkavita Ella Falls
description: The 100 meter high Nakkavita Ella Falls are located along the Mahagal Oya River where it flows over a huge stone slab. You can see these falls from the road to Maliboda just past Nakkavita

name: Suriyagoda Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located along the Kandy to Colombo road Suriyagoda Rajamaha Viharaya was founded in the 15th century. The images of Buddha and others in this temple are very well preserved but some of the wooden structures are partly burnt, probably by Portuguese who suffered a loss in battle in this area.

name: Ran Avuda Mandapaya
description: Originally constructed in the 16th century in the Kandyan Kingdom Ran Avuda Mandapaya is believed to be the place where royalty had their crowns and swords designed. Today the Sri Lankan Archeology Department over saw its renovation so now it can be used as a visitors and learning center where visitors can go there to learn more about Buddhism.

name: Gerandigala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although the Gerandigala Rajamaha Viharaya was known to ancient kings it has been modernized over the years. The temple is located at the southern end of a line of huge rocks in precarious positions which are collectively known as Gerandigala or Rat Snake Rock.

name: Maduru Oya National Park
description: Located 288kms northeast of Colombo the Maduru Oya National Park protects the catchment areas of 5 reservoirs. Named a National Park since 1983 the park also helps preserve the wildlife in the area which includes many elephants.

name: Hanthana Mountain Range
description: Declared an environmental protection area in 2010 the Hanthana Mountain Range lies south west of Kandy in central Sri Lanka. A popular location for mountain hikers the range comprises of 7 peaks with the highest being Uura Kanda at a height of 3800 feet.

name: Kalpitiya Whale and Dolphin Watching
description: Due to the Kalpitiya Peninsula being located close to the continental shelf it is an ideal place for whale watching. As well as the presence of the more common Blue Whale, Sperm Whales can also often be seen as they prepare to dive for giant squid, their main source of food.

name: Elgin Falls
description: The Elgin tea estate is located at an elevation of 1500 meters and the property contains 5 separate waterfalls. The main falls are located 18kms from Nuwara Eliya city but the last 3kms requires to be hiked.

name: Thaliya Wetuna Ella
description: Located on the Alakola Estate in the Knuckles Mountain Range Thaliya Wetuna Ella is a 50 meter high waterfall which is fed by a tributary of the Hulu Ganga River. To reach the falls take the Alakola Estate road for 3kms from the Hula Ganga Bridge.

name: Hathagala Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Although older history of the Hathagala Purana Tampita Viharaya has been lost it is known that it received royal patronage in the 18th century. Today the temple is still used by Buddhist Monks as an education center.

name: Hot Springs of Mahaoya
description: Mahaoya Hot Springs are located 2kms from the town and are the hottest hot springs in Sri Lanka. The hottest water from these 7 individual springs is 56C (133F) which is of course too hot to bathe, in fact there are only 2 of the 7 springs which have temperatures suitable for bathing.

name: Elamaldeniya Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Located on a rocky hillside 8kms from Pitabeddara Town, Elamaldeniya Raja Maha Viharaya was built in the 2nd century BC. Although the temple site has a car park only the stupa can be seen on a hill in the distance and so visiting the temple will require a short hike which includes climbing 200 steps.

name: Lenawara Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Close to Bandaragama Town Lenawara Rajamaha Viharaya has been built on several layers of a hill. The preaching hall used by the monks is close to the bottom however, the temple pagoda is at the top so some climbing will be needed to see that.

name: Dutch Reformed Church of Galle
description: Located inside the Galle Fort the Dutch Reformed Church was built in 1755 and is the oldest protestant church still in use today in Sri Lanka. With contributions from the Dutch Embassy the church went through renovations in 2004 and its conservation program has since won a UNESCO Asia Pacific Heritage Award.

name: Polgaswatte Rakka Ella Falls
description: The Polgaswatte Rakka Ella Falls resemble a wide stairway as the drop down 6 meters of rock face near the Deraniyagala – Noori Road. Like many other waterfalls which are in the vicinity of this road, these falls have suffered from water being diverted for hydro works and so are seen at their best during the rainy season.

name: Gangaramaya - Humupitiya
description: Due to it being complete with bo tree, image house, Simamalaka and a chamber with relics of the Buddha the Gangaramaya Temple is both famous and popular. Visitors to the temple will also be able to see a huge mural depicting the eight vicissitudes of life.

name: Mullaitivu Sri Samudragiri Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Probably built thousands of years ago all that remains of the Mullaitivu Sri Samudragiri Rajamaha Viharaya is a stupa and even that, to the untrained eye may only look like a mound of earth. What remains of this ancient temple can be found near to the Nandikadal Lagoon causeway.

name: Buttala Rahathangala Kanda
description: Although Buttala Rahathangala Kanda may be a popular place with tourists it does not have the trade mark comforts of most tourist attractions. It does however have much of interest to offer visitors as it is somewhat of a treasure trove with not just ruins to see but also many artifacts.

name: Brampton Falls
description: Located close to the Brampton Tea Estate 10kms from Belihuloya, the Brampton falls receive their water from the eastern slopes of the 1530 meter high Papulugala Mountain. Set in tropical jungle the waterfalls water goes on to flow into the Walawe River.

name: Monastic Ruins of Haththota Amuna
description: Originally built in the 7th century and then repaired in the 12th, Haththota Amuna is an ancient weir believed to have been built on the site of a monastery. The weir is connected to a 45kms long canal in order to provide water to the distant Elahera.

name: Baker's Bend
description: Baker's Bend is the name given to the 23rd bend on the road from Belihuloya to Nagrak Banglow. Today the bend acts as an excellent viewpoint, affording views over the plains and of the Adarakanda mountain range. Legend has it that whilst a governor of the region, Mr. Baker, was riding this trail when his horse fell and was killed. The governor survived but then built the bend in the shape of a horseshoe in memory of his beloved horse.

name: Maduwanwela Duwili Ella Falls
description: Due to a conduit above the falls running water to a reservoir, the 25 meter high Maduwanwela Duwili Ella Falls does not flow as heavy as it once did but is still impressive. Local villagers say the falls got their name from the misty spray which rises from the cascade like a flower.

name: Lanka Filling Station - Pungudutivu MPCS Ltd.
Gonagolla Monastery (Punchi Seegiriya), Ampara
description: Located 3 miles east of the Ampara – Gonagolla Road at the Kohombana Junction is the Gonagolla Monastery. This site is known for its 2 caves, 1 of which is home to frescoes of a man and a woman. Inscriptions accompanying the frescoes date them to the 3rd century.

name: Rathna Prasada of Anuradhapura
description: Originally the Rathna Prasada of Anuradhapura was built as a palace in the 2nd century and then renovations were made and golden statues of Buddha added in the 9th century. Although the gold statues have long gone, probably taken by treasure hunters, what remains of the palace can show visitors how impressive it must have looked in its former days.

name: Asgiri Maha Viharaya - Kandy
description: Located north of Kandy Lake in Kandy, this monastery is one of two which shares custodian ship of the Holy Tooth Relic of the Lord Buddha. According to historic records many kings have contributed to the building of the monastery, for example, although founded in the early 14th century by Parakramabahu IV of Kurunegala, the Meda Pansala or middle temple was built in 1767.

Uran Wetunu Ella
description: With a height of 108 meters the Uran Wetunu Ella waterfall is in an area known for its wild boar and medicinal plants. Sourced from the Mirishena Mukalana (Mirishena Jungle) this waterfall has never been known to dry up.

name: Vijayarama Ruins
description: Close to the stone bridge on the outskirts of Anuradhapura the ruins of the Vijayarama monastery are spread over 23 acres. These ruins had been overgrown by jungle for 120 years but then, in 2014, the area was made a protected archaeological site.

name: Ulugala Kaluwala Ella Falls
description: Ulugala village in the Ratnapura District is home to the 38 meter high Ulugala Kaluwala Ella Falls but in order to reach the village you will have to cross the suspension bridge across the Ranmudu River.

name: Floodplains National Park
description: Located 222kms northeast of Colombo the Floodplains National Park is 1 of 4 National Parks set up under the Mahaweli River development project. Established in 1984 this park is considered to be a corridor for elephants migrating between the Wasgamuwa and Somawathiya national parks.

name: Lakshapana Ella Falls
description: With a height of 129 meters Lakshapana Ella Falls is one of the highest in Sri Lanka and gets its name from the iron ore (Laksha) which is found in the rocks it flows down. The falls are said to have been home to a labyrinth of tunnels but today only one is known of or been found.

name: Kudiramalei Point
description: An ancient sea port which lies on Sri Lanka’s western coast is named Kudiramalei Point or has been called Thambapanni in the past. This port has played an important role in the island’s history as it was used by princesses and kings during their reigns. What would have once been palaces are little more than rubble today and where princesses would exclusively bathe, crocodiles now swim.

name: Devathura Ella Falls
description: Although quite large only a 10 meter high section of the Devathura Ella Falls can be seen from the road. As there is a tea estate above the falls the falls were called ‘Thevatura Falls’ (Tea Waterfall). This waterfall is popular with visitors as it is set in serene surroundings of beautiful flora and fauna.

name: Portuguese Black Fort
description: With the sea on both flanks and a line of rock behind it the Black Fort at Galle was originally built by the Portuguese however, later the Dutch made improvements and gave it its name, probably due to it housing the cells of black slaves they brought from Africa.

name: Nalagana Ella Falls
description: With a number of shuts each 40 meters high the Nalagana Ella Falls are located about 9kms east of Bulathkohupitiya. The source of these falls is the Ritigaha Oya reservoir. For visitors interested in exploring the area a rest house is located 4kms from the falls.

name: Kiri Ella Falls
description: Also known as Kiri Ella Falls the 18 meter high Kabaragala Ella is located on the side of the Kabaragala Mountain. From a distance the water as it cascades down this waterfall appears white, like milk. A local legend associated with the falls tells of a treasure being hidden somewhere nearby.

name: Mahiyangana Viharaya
description: Mahiyangana Viharaya is said to stand on the same site as Buddha once sat in the air to address the Yakkas of Sri Lanka for the very first time, informing them of his mission.

name: Ruwanwella Sangili Palama
description: Built in 2007 at a length of 550 feet, Ruwanwella Sangili Palama (Ruwanwella Suspension Bridge) is believed to be the longest suspension bridge in Sri Lanka. The bridge is suspended 40 meters above the Gurugoda Oya so it can connect Ruwanwella Town with some of the villages on the other side of the river.

name: Atupothdeniya Purana Pothgul Rajamaha Viharaya
description: This temple has been in existence since the 1st century BC when it was used as a library for Buddhist manuscripts by King Walagamba during the Baminitiya Famine. One of the main aspects of interest today to visitors to the temple, often from Colombo just 62kms away, is the Tampita Vihara Ge which was a popular feature in the Kandyan era.

name: Rajana Ella Falls
description: Although the Rajana Ella Falls has several names it always has “Raja” (King) as it is said that this 12 meter high waterfall was used by King Walagamba to bathe and organize his armies. Legend has it that there is also a hidden tunnel at the waterfalls where the king stored his treasure.

name: Buduruwayaya Archaeological Site
description: The Buduruwayaya Archaeological Site which is famous for its huge statue of a reclining Buddha is located about 6kms from Bakamuna town. Archaeologists have found an assortment of other artifacts at the complex and so visitors have more to see than just the statue.

name: Padikemgala Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Etched in stone at the Padikemgala Raja Maha Viharaya are vivid details about where and when Buddha received true enlightenment after renouncing his royal inheritance and spending six years as a hermit.

name: Marakkala Ella Falls (Kaluwala Ella)
description: It is said that the 8 meter high Marakkala Ella Falls is where a boy tied his fishing line to his toe and was pulled into the water by a large eel. The area surrounding the falls is full of wildlife such as porcupines.

name: Kandahena Ella Falls
description: Although impressive Kandahena Ella Falls are of an undetermined height and are a little difficult to find however, to visit them travel along the Namunukula – Ranugalla road until you reach the Kandahena Estate. After you turn into the estate and travel a further 2kms, just past the Kandahena school you will find the falls.

name: Minigamuwa Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: The Tampita Viharaya at Minigamuwa Purana is built on a wooden platform which is supported on stone pillars, the traditional Kandyan style. This temple is said to have been built at the end of the 16th century by King Wimaladarmasuriya for a priest called Buddhagammana thero.

name: Ilumbakanda Doowili Ella Falls
description: There is a new route to the 40 meter high Ilumbakanda Doowili Ella Falls in the planning stages but in the meantime visitors have to hike either 2kms into the forest from Imbullkande Village or 7kms from the Morning’s Side Forestry Research center in Suryakande.

description: The traditional Italian kitchen at Prego offers a diverse selection of homemade pasta and ravioli dishes, traditional Roman Pizzaâ€™s from Prego's huge wood fired oven, and a large selection of small plates to accompany. Prego has an on-site wine store which houses 150+ imported wines for you to choose from.Â

name: Ancient Hospital Complex of Mihintale Aramic Complex
description: Mihintale is said to have been home to 2000 monks in the 5th century and so medical facilities are expected to have existed on the site. Although the hospital complex which can be seen there today was built much later, around the 9th century AD, it is thought that a previous hospital existed at the site.

name: Maligatenne Raja Maha Viharaya
description: From about 2 miles out from Colombo you can see a dagaba on top of a mountain and that is Maligatenne Raja Maha Viharaya. This temple has caves at 3 different levels the the largest being the meditation center.

name: Water World Lanka
description:
Water World Lanka is in fact 2 parks in 1 as it is both an aquarium and a bird park. The aquarium is not only the only one in Sri Lanka but is also the first underwater tunnel aquarium in South Asia.

[Wildlife Opinion]
Observing wildlife in their natural habitat offers a more authentic and enriching experience compared to viewing them in zoos. It also allows the animals to be free in their truly natural environment.

name: British Era Gallows Tree
description: In the early 19th century when the British ruled Sri Lanka, due to a shortage of bullets the Governor decided to have a gallows tree constructed near his residence in Hanbanthota to hang the leaders of an uprising instead of having them face a firing squad. Since 2014 the Sri Lankan Archaeology Department have taken measures to conserve the gallows as a tourist attraction.

name: Radella Rail Bridge Waterfall
description: What is known as the Radella Rail Bridge Waterfall is a waterfall which is 20 meters in height and can be reached by a short walk from the Radella railway station.

name: Ratna Ella (Navarathna Ella) Fall
description: With a height of 101 meters Ratna Ella (Navarathna Ella) Fall is the tallest waterfall in the Kandy region. A local legend tells of 7 pots of treasure being hidden in the falls and that although 5 have already been found, those that seek the other 2 will find untimely deaths at the bottom of the falls.

name: Wee Oya Ella Falls
description: Wee Oya Ella Falls are a pair of 20 meter high waterfalls located in the Bombepola Forest. From the Yatiyanthota to Pahala road these waterfalls can be seen peeking out of the dense jungle.

name: Kandy Commonwealth War Cemetery
description: Located in Kandy the Kandy Commonwealth War Cemetery consists of 203 graves, all for people who lost their lives during WW11. Although considered a British military cemetery there are graves for 70 commonwealth soldiers plus 3 Italian and a Frenchman.

name: Pahanthuda Ella Falls
description: Pahanthuda Ella Falls are sometimes mistaken for Galagama Falls but they are further up on the edge of Horton Plains. This waterfall is 5 meters high and the pool and the waterfall are said to resemble a temple candle complete with its wick.

name: Weligama Beach
description: Weligama is a coastal village located 144kms south of Colombo. Translated Weligama literally means ‘sandy village’ and so it would have gotten this name thanks to the sandy Weligama Beach. Fishing is popular in the village but more recently tourism is becoming even more popular.

name: Nedun Raja Maha Vihara
description: Nedun Raja Maha Vihara has a history going back to the late 16th century when it was built by King Rajasinghe I. This King became infamous in history when, Buddhist Priests said they could not redeem his sin of killing his father. He was eventually forgiven by a Hindu Priest and so converted to Hinduism after which time he killed hundreds of Buddhists for not allowing him redemption.

name: Dripping Rock
description: Located on the Halgolla Tea Estate, along the road to Wewalthalawa is a vertical rock face known as dripping Rock. The name comes from the fact that a small stream at the top of the rock provides a continuous, steady shower of water at the bottom.

Gerandi Gini Ella Falls
description: Located below a tea estate in the Ramboda area, the Gerandi Gini Ella Falls, start from a spring originating in the Galaha Forest Reserve. Although the largest section of the falls is 100 meters in height, the falls are actually an amalgamation of falls totaling 270 meters in height. Because of the size of the falls they can be seen from afar.

name: Relic Shrine in Abayagiri Monastery
description: Rituals used to be held to worship relics of Buddha and the ruins of the Abayagiri Monastery now show evidence that this was a shrine where those rituals took place. Although the roof of the building is no longer there the pillars are and at the top of them you can see carvings of hands holding up the roof.

name: Rambe Veheragala Viharaya
description: The Veheragala Viharaya at Rambe may be new but it was built on the same site as an ancient rock temple and evidence of that older complex can be found all around the massive rock on which the original temple was founded.

name: Ruwanveli Maha Seya
description: Ruwanveli Maha Seya is considered to be the most important Buddhist site in Anuradhapura and was built in the 2nd century BC. Although the stupa at this site is now 350 feet in height, its original height is estimated to have been only 180 feet when built by king Dutugemunu but in subsequent years it has been renovated by several later kings.

name: Doramadalawa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: It is said that the sleepy village of Doramadalawa, which is home to Doramadalawa Rajamaha Viharaya that has the longest cave image house in the country, is mentioned in the chronicles of Sri Lanka. The son of a princess hid here for 17 years until he was old enough to fulfill a prophesy and kill his 10 uncles and become King.

name: Malwatu Maha Viharaya at Kandy
description: The Malwatu Maha Viharaya in Kandy is only one of two Buddhist Monasteries in Sri Lanka that holds sacred tooth relic of Lord Buddha custodianship. Built in the 15th century the oldest part of the temple ia an archaeologically protected monument.

name: Maha Vishnu Devalaya - Kandy
description: In Kandy the Maha Vishnu Devalaya is dedicated to Lord Vishnu the Hindu God. Devotees to this deity come from all over the world to worship in this temple which is said to be one of only four associated with the Temple of the Tooth.

name: Naga Pokuna of Mihintale
description: The fact that many people in ancient Sri Lanka took to life in a monastery, hydro engineering became essential as the monks relied on an effective water supply system. In the Mihintale region three ponds were built and Naga Pokuna is one which the remains of can still be plainly seen today.

name: Udakanda Ella Falls
description: The 10 meter high Udakanda Ella Falls is located in the Ratnapura District to the north west of the Sri Pada Jungle. Although there are two different routes to these falls, the best is to travel to Udakanda from where it is just a 500 meter hike to the falls

name: Kothmale Oruthotawella Sangili Palama (Hanging Bridge)
description: Although there are several different types of bridges built through the ages in Sri Lanka, some of the more interesting ones are the suspension bridges like Kothmale Oruthotawella Sangili Palama which are often referred to locally as hanging bridges.

name: Kuda Bambarakiri Ella Fall
description: Although Bambarakiri Ella Fall is the better known of the two there are in fact two waterfalls at this location but the second one is more hidden in the forest and referred to as Kuda Bambarakiri Ella Fall, Kuda just meaning small.

description: Mulkirigala Raja Maha Viharaya is known as a great royal temple and is one of the most important in Sri Lanka in regards to design, style and architecture. Although perhaps not as famous as the Lion Rock Temple this rock temple is a couple of hundred years older and is today recognized by the government as an important archaeological site.

The inscriptions are 2000 years old but the site shows signs of being in existence since the 6th century BC.

name: Red Mosque of Pettah
description: The Jami-Ul-Alfar Mosque commonly referred to as the Red Mosque was built in Colombo in 1909 and commissioned by the Pettah Muslim community. The building has a red and white candy stripe colour and a clock tower.

name: Batticaloa Lagoon
description: With a length of 56kms Batticaloa Lagoon is the largest of 3 lagoons in the Batticaloa District. This is an estuarine lagoon and although Batticaloa City is located between it and the Indian Ocean, the lagoon still meets the sea in 2 separate places.

name: Pathahawatte Raja maha Viharaya
description: The huge 2 meter wide wall that surrounds Pathahawatte Raja maha Viharaya leads experts to assume that this was not at first a temple but a palace. The problem is that although the temple seems to have been built in the early 16th century, history does not show a need for such a palace at that time.

name: Pokunuwita Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The Pokunuwita Rajamaha Viharaya which is located on several levels of a rock face has an unusually large and odd looking wooden table for offerings in front of a Buddha statue and there is a huge seated Buddha statue in one of the temple rooms but seemingly from a much later date than that which the temple itself was built.

name: Nilaveli Beach
description: Nilaveli Beach Is located at the hamlet of Errakkandy about 16kms north of Trincomalle and has gentle surfs lapping at a white sandy beach for about 1km. Even the trip to the beach is enjoyable as you pass a lagoon which is fringed with lush coconut trees.

name: Hulugalla Tampita Viharaya
description: As with all Tampita Viharaya Hulugalla Tampita Viharaya is built on pillars which were a popular design in the Kandyan era. Built in the 19th century this temple has not weathered well due to lack of attention but although they too are weathered, an ancient Buddha statue and some murals can be seen in the Image House.

name: Goxin Falls
description: Located 25kms from Ratnapura town the 50 meter high Goxin Falls can become as wide as it is high during the rainy season. For some unknown reason the falls were named after a British painter however, it may have been something to do with the fact the painter was a watersport enthusiast.

name: Tsunami Honganji Viharaya
description: Located 200 meters from the shore and guarded by 4 lions a 30 meter tall statue of Buddha pays tribute to the 2000 people that lost their lives in the 2004 tsunami. Known as the Tsunami Honganji Viharaya this tribute was helped paid for by the Temple of Kyoto and modeled on the Afghanistan statue of Buddha destroyed by the Taliban in 2001.

name: Kataragama Devalaya - Badulla
description: Although the origin of the Kataragama Devalaya at Badulla is unknown it is known to have featured strongly in legends from the 17th century when King Kumarasinhe defeated a large Portuguese army.

name: Kirawanagama Dowili Ella
description: The Sinhalese word for dust is 'Duwili' and so the Kirawanagama Dowili Ella waterfall which is 40 meters high was named after it, as that word best implies how the spray from the falls is seen.

name: Ruwanwella Fort (remains of)
description: Fortunately the Sri Lankan archaeology department the entrance to what was once Ruwanwella Fort otherwise that too may have been lost to time. Although both the Portuguese and the Dutch would have had fortifications of some sort at the strategic site of the fort, it is believed the British were the ones to build the actual fort as, according to markings on the top of the entrance, the date 1817 next to the initials of the British Governor of Ceylon can be seen.

name: Toluvila Ruins
description: Located close to the Anuradhapura railway station are the ruins of the Toluvila Aramic Complex. Although in ruins 3 great statues were found in what was the image house. 1 of these statues is considered to be one of the most elegant ever found in Sri Lanka and as such was moved to the National Museum in Colombo.

name: The Royal Palace of the Kandyan Kingdom
description: Known as Mahawàsala and located in Kandy north of the Temple of the Tooth is the royal residence of the Kandyan Kings. The last king to live in the palace was King Sri Vikrama Rajasinha (1798–1815).

name: Mawela Walagamba Len Viharaya
description: To reach the Mawela Walagamba Len Viharaya you must walk 200 meters down a steep slope from the Kadugannawa Ambalama road. Prior to this road being built by the British in the 1800s, devotees had to use an older road to reach the temple but which is now abandoned.

name: Mini Worlds End - Hulangala
description:
There is one main "Worlds End" in Sri Lanka however there are 5 other places referred to as "mini world ends". One of these is known as Hulangala Mini Worlds End. It lies at the Southern end of the knuckles mountain range. 

[Entrance]
You'll have to find the "Hulangala Mini World's End Entrance" to start the treck!

[Entrance Fee]
Entry fees at the gate are LKR 100 for each visitor and LKR 250 for every vehicle. Beginning from the Selagama estate's worker housing, a 2 to 3 km trek will lead you to the scenic overlook. You can drive all the way to the viewpoint if you have a motorcycles, tuktuk, and four-wheel drive vehicles. 

[Elevation]
Situated at an elevation of 760 meters (about 2500 feet) is the Mini World's End, whereas the Hulangala Hill reaches a height of 1025 meters (approximately 3360 feet). Due to its location, expect to encounter brisk winds at the summit. The cliff presents a significant risk, and visitors should proceed with caution near the precipice, as there are no safety barriers. It's important that children are supervised by adults at all times.

[Nearby Waterfall]
Additionally, a trip to the Yatawatta Biso Ella, situated within the Selagama estate, is possible. To access the waterfall, one must veer right past the estate's line houses and continue towards the Yatawatta Hindu Temple. Upon arriving, visitors should disembark from their vehicles and trek across several rice fields to arrive at the waterfall's crest.

name: Chulangani Vehera Ruins
description: Although the small stupa Chulangani Vehera has been dated to the 12th century, the Buddha statues inside the image house have been dated to the 6th and 7th centuries. The site is located near to the Yudaganawa car park.

name: Udunuwara Shailatharama Maha Viharaya
description: The Udunuwara Shailatharama Maha Viharaya has been established since 1890 but the building housing the temple’s main Buddha image was only built in 1901. This is a popular place of pilgrimage even though devotees have to reach there by cart and ferry across the Kalu Ganga River.

name: Warnagala Ella Falls
description: Due to hydro power projects upstream from the 40 meter high Warnagala Ella Falls in the Ratnapura District, it is now seen at its best only during the rainy season.

name: Sapugaharoda Ella Falls
description: Sapugaharoda Ella Falls is one of the few waterfalls in the Hambantota district of Sri Lanka. But it is 25 high and receives many visitors both local and foreign due to a hotel being near and a ledge having been made across the pool at the bottom of the falls, allowing easier bathing.

name: Vishnu Kovil (no. 2) of Polonnaruwa Kingdom
description: Located on the right side of the entrance to the ancient city of Polonnaruwa there is a Kovil whilst on the left there are 2.  Even though these Kovils are carved out of solid granite, only the lower portions remain but it is what is known as the Vishnu Kovil (no. 2) which is lasting best.

name: Duwili Ella Falls
description: With its full name Lankagama Duwili Ella Falls is a 23 meter high waterfall in the Galle District. Behind these waterfalls is a hidden cave which measures 2 meters by 4 meters which is thought to have been a popular hiding place during Sri Lanka’s history.

name: Beli-Lena Caves
description: Beli-Lena Caves are located 8kms from the town of Kitulgala and are very large. It was not their size that interested Sri Lanka’s Archaeological Department when they excavated then between 1978 and 1983, it was what was in the caves. Bones from at least 10 skeletons were found and they are believed to be of humans from as far back as 30,000 years ago.

The combination of different trees near the falls provides an idyllic canopy.

name: Muhudu Maha Viharaya, Pottuvil
description: Built more than 2000 years ago the Muhudu Maha Viharaya at Pottuvil still provides interest to archaeologists with remnants of stupas and statues of Buddha, kings and gods.

name: Pigeon Island National Park
description: The Pigeon Island National Park is just one of two Marine Parks in Sri Lanka. Although the park is located 312kms from Colombo it can be reached in less than 5 hours using the expressway. Named after the Blue Rock Pigeons that inhabit the island it was named a bird sanctuary first in 1963 but was then upgraded to a National Park in 2003.

name: Nagapooshani Amman Kovil
description: A boat ride away from Jaffna on the island of Nainativu is the Nagapooshani Amman Kovil. This is a temple which receives a lot of devotees, especially during June and July for the Mahostavam thiruvilla. The temple is said to have some artifacts which cannot be found elsewhere and include a statue of Goddess Nagapoosani and the ten headed Ravana.

name: Mamangam Temple, Batticaloa
description: Although an old Hindu Temple, the Mamangam Temple at Batticaloa is still very popular. In July the temple holds a 10 day festival which attracts Hindus from all parts of Sri Lanka.

name: Sella Kataragama
description: Not only is Kataragama a well-known pilgrimage town for several denominations including Buddhists and Hindus from Sri Lanka but also from South India. The town is home to several different temples and close to the town is Sella Kataragama a shrine dedicated to Ganesha the elephant faced god.

description: The temple Sri Sumittaramaya which lies about 10kms past  Anamaduwa town near the Mahamithawa Wewa (reservoir)  may be relatively new but its Tampita Viharaya is ancient. A Tampita Viharaya would be built on pillars, usually of rock so as to avoid damage from white ants or any other vermin.

name: Lemastota Oya Ella Falls
description: The waters flowing over the 30 meter high Lemastota Oya Ella Falls starts its journey from the Lemastota River, the Kalkanna and the Welioya Reservoirs. The falls are not visible from any road and so are little known but can be hiked to 500 meters through the Dambethanne Tea Factory Estate but permission has to be sought first.

name: Karagahagedara Ambalama
description: In its scenic setting of paddy fields, coconut estates and lush home gardens, a visit to Karagahagedara Ambalama is always a pleasure. In the ancient past Karagahagedara Ambalama which delicately balances on 4 boulders would have been an important and convenient stopping point for pilgrims.

The temple is thought to have existed since before the introduction of Buddha statues to the island but rock inscriptions can be seen in a cave on the temple’s premises.

name: Seenigama Devale
description: Seenigama Devale or Seenigama Devalaya is a shrine which is on a small island near the coast on the southwest of Sri Lanka. The island which is located at the village of Seenigama on the Colombo-Matararoad receives a lot of visitors as the shrine is dedicated to the God Devol who has always been the god thought to protect fishermen and their boats but more recently is also said to be the god to protect drivers and their trucks and buses.

name: Main Point (surf break), Arugam Bay
description: Located in the Ampara District Arugam Bay is 314kms from Colombo but it receives its share of visitors as it is considered one of the top ten surfing venues in the world. Main Point is perhaps the best vantage point for surfers as its position allows for unrestricted waves coming in from the south west.

name: Sellaba Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located at Wellawaya, Sellaba Rajamaha Viharaya lies in ruins today but displays positive signs of having been an ancient rock temple. The ruins of this temple are strewn around a forested hill but pillars from buildings can still be seen as can a fairly large stupa.

name: Wathuruwa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Built in the mid-3rd century BC Wathuruwa Rajamaha Viharaya is said to be where Prince Dutugemunu, in the 2nd century BC, received a blessing whilst on his way to freeing Sri Lanka from the Tamil invaders.

name: Wakirigala (Tampita) Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although the history of Wakirigala (Tampita) Rajamaha Viharaya is originally believed to go back to the 11th century it is believed it was destroyed by the Portuguese and later rebuilt using the remnents of the old temple.

name: Wedihiti Kanda
description: Although the mountain Wedihiti Kanda is 3.5kms away from Kataragama Devalaya legends say it was from this mountain that an arrow was fired in order to determine where the temple Kataragama Devalaya should be built.

name: Meddekanda Ella Falls
description: Until the 1970s elephants used to bath in the pool at the bottom of the 18 meter high Meddekanda Ella Falls. Although elephants may have bathed there the pool is very dangerous and so visitors are advised not to use it for recreational purposes.

name: Rahas Ella Falls
description: The forest around the Rahas Ella Falls has suffered eco-damage since British rule but further downstream protection is offered in the Rahas Ella Forest Reserve where the wildlife like mongoose and some rarer species still thrive. The falls themselves are 15 meters high and plunge into a dangerously deep cleft.

name: Muhudu Maha Viharaya
description: Although there are only remnants of the Muhudu Maha Viharaya today, it was in its past a place of legend. It is said that this was where Princess Devi landed after having been cast out to sea. Later she would marry King Kavantissa.

name: Holy Trinity Church
description: Although the Holy Trinity Church’s construction in Nuwara Eliya started in 1845 it took 7 years to complete and so its consecration did not take place until 1852. In 1954 the church was visited by Queen Elizabeth 11 who donated a stained glass window to the church as a memory of her visit.

name: Chapel Hill (Trincomalee Bay) Light House
description: Located on the north of the harbor Chapel Hill is 1 of 3 lighthouses at the Trincomlee harbor. The harbor has been a major shipping harbor since ancient times and although now being operated by the Sri Lanka Ports Authority it has been operated by successive rulers in its past.

name: Thalpe Beach
description: Thalpe Beach is just one of the attractions which is making Unawatuna a popular place for tourists. As the beach and the area become increasingly more popular, more facilities and attractions also appear.

name: Abayagiri Monastery
description: Abayagiri Monastery was established in Sri Lanka in the 2nd century BC and is renowned for being a great place of learning and as a place for intellectual discussions. In the 5th century a Chinese monk by the name of Fa-hsien, whilst visiting the monastery, copied Buddhist texts to take with him back to China. Today the museum at the monastery, a popular place for tourists visiting the area, is dedicated to the work of Fa-hsien.

name: Turtle Watch Rekawa
description: Five different species of turtle come on shore to lay their eggs on Sri Lanka’s Rekawa Beach. This attracts many tourists who want to watch these magnificent beasts as they struggle up the beach but caution must be taken as the turtles can easily be deterred from laying their eggs.

name: Brahmana Ella Falls
description: These falls receive their water from the Hariyawa Brook which after the falls provides water to a hydropower station. The falls are 16 meters high and have 2 legends attached to them however, both legends refer to a man falling and losing his life during the reign of King Walagamba, just in different circumstances.

name: Polonnaruwa Kiri Vehera
description: Although the Stupa at Kiri Vehera in Polonnaruwa with a height of 80 feet is only the second largest in Polonnaruwa, it has maintained its original condition better than most and certainly better than the larger one. Built in the early 12th century this building has weathered 900 years with grace.

name: Henanegala Len Viharaya, Mahaoya, Ampara
description: Henanegala Len Viharaya is considered to be 1 of the 4 temples built by King Kawanthissa. The location of the rock monastery was considered appropriate during his war with the Tamil King.

name: Mandawala Ella

As this waterfall is little known other than by local villagers it is un-spoilt and yet can be easily reached just 700 meters from the Hinnapita road located at the Diggalpoththa junction on the Poramadulla – Palle Bowala Road.
