name: Halmehi Ella Falls
description: Halmehi Ella Falls is a 9 meter high waterfall from which local people say they can hear the sound of people washing coming from the water. Although the falls are only 1.5kms from the village of Mapalana, the road to them is difficult.

name: Rathu Palama Ella
description: At just 4 meters height the Rathu Palama Ella is more like rapids running down a steep flight of steps but is still a spectacular sight. The waterfall is located about 200 meters from a bridge which can be reached through a rubber estate.

name: Ginigedara Ella Falls
description: Due to its location being hard to reach the cascading 14 meter high Ginigedara Ella Falls is rarely visited. However, annually it does receive visitors as environmental students endure the 6kms hike once a year in order to see its unique biological diversity.

name: Kanniya Hot Water Springs, Trincomalee
description: The Kanniya Hot Water Springs at Trincomalee consist of 7 hot springs, each with varying temperatures of water. These springs or wells are only 3 or 4 feet deep and so will run out of water if more than about a dozen buckets are removed.

name: Karandeniya Shailatharama Viharaya
description: Located on a hill which provides stunning views of the countryside, to reach Karandeniya Shailatharama Viharaya you will pass through cinnamon plantations. This temple houses a 35 meter long statue of a reclining Buddha, the largest in South Asia.

name: Talaimannar Pier
description: Once the main point of departure from Sri Lanka to India, the Talaimannar Pier now sits looking rusty and old alongside the white of the Talaimannar Lighthouse.

name: Deraniyagala Watawala Ella
description: Although the Deraniyagala Watawala Ella falls are not very high they are very wide. There are actually 2 parts to these falls but both parts cannot be seen from any 1 place. These cascading waterfalls are very impressive and the second part of them can be seen by continuing along the river side path from the first.

name: Shri bhakta Hanuman Kovil
description: Built in 1999, the 18 foot high Shri bhakta Hanuman Kovil, towers above the entrance to this site. This is a popular venue with devotees especially for 10 days when Hanuman Jayanthi’s birthday is celebrated

name: Apsara Tailors Hikkaduwa
description: Aspara Tailors in Hikkaduwa has become somewhat of a must go place for tourists. Following in a family tradition, Aspara offers the finest in tailored clothing. However, being enterprising and innovative, Aspara catered to modern times and specialized in making hoodies. Today he has a second business in Arugam where he specializes in making bikinis and surfing pants. Aspara personally spends 6 months in each location every year, building the businesses equally.

description: This Hindu Temple is located not far from the fort in Trincomalee. Dating back to the 11th century, although the temple is dedicated to Kali, its portal tower is decorated with impressions of a more vengeful but smaller deity, Kali kovil.

name: Makeli Ella Falls
description: Resembling a bride’s veil from a distance the 10 meter high Makeli Ella Falls is located in the Kalutara District. This was once a popular bathing area but due to a modern development program, the river is silting up.

name: Uppuveli Beach
description: The golden sands of Uppuveli Beach 6kms northwest of Trincomalee were a popular tourist destination prior to the 2004 Tsunami but since then they have failed to achieve the same numbers.

name: Eden Falls
description: Although Eden Falls, which drop in 3 different levels, are located in the Knuckles Mountain Range, their actual location is on private property owned by the Eden Falls Hotel.

name: Dumpus Ella Falls
description: Due to a bend in the river the Dumpus Ella Falls are not visible from the road at the Induruwa Bridge on the Gilimale–Siripagama Road however beside the bridge is a footpath that will lead visitors to it. At only 5 meters height the falls are relatively small but they look very enchanting.

name: Kalagam Vehera Ruins
description: Unfortunately the area surrounding the Kalagam Vehera Ruins became more famous due to terrorist activities in the 21st century than it had been for these ruins which date back to the pre-Christian era.

name: Sun Wind Beach Kite Resort and Kite School Kalpitiya
Dorawaka Rock caves
description: Archaeologists excavating the Dorawaka Rock caves believe that the inscriptions they have found date back to the 3rd phase of the Stone Age, the Mesolithic Era. If true the inscriptions will date back to 700 BC and will represent the oldest known form of writing in Sri Lanka.

name: Ambastala Stupa of Mihintale
description: The Ambastala Stupa is the first thing to be seen having climbed the 1,840 steps of Mount Mihintale. The stupa is said to house hair from Buddha’s eyebrows. The location of the stupa is said to mark the exact historic spot where King Devanampiyatissa met the great Mahinda Thero.

name: Batathota Lena Viharaya
description: Although this cave temple which is located on a rocky mountain range had been neglected for years, today it receives thousands of visitors daily. The temple is thought to have been built in the 12th century but after a time for some reason was abandoned. Batathota Lena Viharaya was rediscovered in 1908 after which time it was renovated and many pilgrims now travel the 7kms of small road to visit the site.

name: Arippu Dutch Fort
description: Although referred to as the Dutch Fort, the fort at Arippu was in fact built by the Portuguese who later gave it to the Dutch. The fort stands in ruins today but after it was abandoned as a fort, it was used by the British to house officers overlooking the pearl fisheries and then later still, converted into a guest house.

name: Moonstone at Mahasen Maligaya of the Abayagiri Monastery
description: In the latter stages of the Anuradhapura period Moonstones were a popular feature at temples. There is an excellent example of one at the ruins of the Abayagiri Monastery at Mahasen Maligaya.

name: Robert Knox's Tamarind Tree at Muttur
description: When their ship’s mast broke the captain, Robert Knox, and its crew made land on Sri Lanka in order to make repairs. The king at the time however was not happy about the situation and so had them tricked into coming ashore where they were arrested under a Tamarind Tree they were using for shade. They were arrested in 1660. In 1889 an engraved stone was placed at the Tamard Tree to commemorate the event.

name: Demali Ella
description: Flowing to the Deni River Demali Ella is 105 meters high and is surrounded in legions. The region itself has many legions regarding the war between King Walagamba and the Tamil’s but the legions of the falls concern a woman falling into them and drowning after being startled by a King.

name: Kandy Pillaiyar Kovil
description: Located near the police station at the entrance to Kandy City, Pillaiyar Kovil is a Hindu Temple. Although not much is known about the history of this temple, it is believed it was built early during the British reign, on a site where a statue of the God Ganesh was found.

name: Devils Staircase
description: The spectacular track through the mountains of Sri Lanka known as the Devils Staircase is popular with visitors who take a jeep but the 13kms is also often hiked by experienced hikers. This is one of Sri Lanka’s most popular experiences for visitors.

name: Sandagiriya Stupa
description: The Sandagiriya Stupa is thought to be the oldest stupa in Southern Sri Lanka as it has been identified as the stupa mentioned in the great chronicles where relics sent to the Sri Lankan King from Emperor Asoka in the mid-third century BC were enshrined.

name: Kitesurfing Kalpitiya
description: Kalpitiya is a lagoon on Sri Lanka’s coast which has become renowned as a great kitesurfing destination. The shallow waters of the lagoon make for a good place to learn whilst the consistent winds make the location also ideal for international kitesurfing events and competitions.

name: Pedro tea estate
description: For visitors to Sri Lanka from anywhere in the world who may be interested in how their morning cup of tea originates can visit the Pedro Tea Estate 3.5kms east of Nuwara Eliya. Her visitors will not only see how their tea is picked but also how it is graded and then packed ready for export.

name: Budugallena Forest Monastery
description: At least 14 rock inscriptions stating how the caves were donated to the Priesthood have been found in the 62 caves which make up the Budugallena Forest Monastery. Although having been built around the 2nd century BC the complex was later abandoned but in 1970 part of the complex was cleared and some of the caves explored.

name: Mahalloluwa Sri Saddharmarama Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Mahalloluwa Sri Saddharmarama Purana Tampita Viharaya located in the Gamapaha District is unique in two ways. First, although built on pillars in the traditional Kandyan Style, the pillars are cemented with clay instead of being only granite. Secondly the temple is unique as it has the only known Tampita Viharaya with a reclining Buddha statue.

name: Alupola Ella Falls
description: Unfortunately, due to mining around the area and the associated damage to the eco system, the Alupola Ella Falls may not exist much longer. Whilst they do though the 68 meter high falls are a sight worth seeing and experiencing as due to the moisture they create, even when the sun is at its highest, a damp environment prevails.

name: Indikatu Seya of Mihintale
description: Within a very large comples ay Mihintale is a smaller complex named Indikatu Seya complex. This smaller complex consists of a monastery and 2 stupas. As you walk among these ruins you will see pots on pillars and the occasional charming guard stone.

name: Nawgala Rock
description: In the Kegalle district at Galigamuwa, Nawgala Rock seems to rise like ship in the mist, especially as it has communication towers at both ends. The rock is popular with hikers and provides some excellent views from the top. From one end you can see Kegalle City in the distance.

name: Milla Ella (Gona Wetuna Ella)
description: You will need a local guide to help you find the Milla Ella (Gona Wetuna Ella) waterfall as it is hidden deep in a jungle region of the Badulla District. Although the waterfall is only 700 meters from the Hopeton Banglawatta Road that 700 meters through the jungle is dangerous and tough.

name: Hetadage at Polonnaruwa Kingdom
description: Hetadage is an ancient shrine which is thought to have housed the sacred tooth relic during the Polonnaruwa Kingdom era. According to inscriptions on a slab at the shrine it was built in the 12th century by King Nissanka Malla.

name: Knuckles Forest Reserve
description: Five mountain peaks, Kirigalpottha, Gombaniya, Knuckles, Koboneelagala and Dotulugala located in the Central Province of Sri Lanka and rising to a height of 3000 meters are said to look like the knuckles of a clenched fist and so acquired the name Knuckles Mountain Range. The area of the mountains above 1500 meters has been declared a Forest Reserve and World Heritage Site as one of South Asia’s most important tropical forest habitats.

name: Jungle Beach
description: Far less crowded than its neighbor Unawatuna Beach, Jungle Beach is reached via a short but narrow and steep road through the jungle. Although this beach is less popular than its neighbor it still has sun beds and restaurants for visitors to enjoy.

name: Isinbassagala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Isinbassagala Rajamaha Viharaya was built in the 3rd century BC, about the same time as Buddhism was introduced to Sri Lanka. So far excavation of the ancient site has turned up a Naga Gala (Cobra carved stone) and a Foot print of Buddha.

name: Arawakumbura Dunhinda Ella Fall
description: Although there is no road or even marked path to the 45 meter high Arawakumbura Dunhinda Ella Fall, visitors who follow the unmarked trail to these falls can continue further to other falls along the Ibban Oya River. These falls are in full flow even during the dry season and the area around the falls, despite deforestation, is still home to numerous valuable trees.

name: Bolthumbe Aliya Wetuna Ella
description: The words Aliya Wetuna Ella mean the waterfall where the elephant fell but the story behind the name is not known. Located near to the Bolthumbe Saman Devalaya and is located on the same road but as the waterfall is hidden, visitors must walk along the stream which crosses the road in order to find it.

name: Lahugala Magul Maha Viharaya
description: About 22kms from Siyambalanduwa on the Pottuvil Road in the Monaragala District is the Lahugala National Park which is home to  Magul Maha Viharaya. This temple was built in the 2nd century BC by King Kavanthissa and is said to be the place where he married Pricecess Vihara Maha Devi.

name: Dambadeniya Kingdom - Palace Complex
description: During the wars in the 13th century against invaders from India, Vijayabahu III was forced to move his palace from Polonnaruwa to a new location on the summit of Dambadeniya which had a moat and sturdy ramparts. This new palace proved adequate for protecting the sacred tooth relic but reached its full glory in 1270 under the rule of his son Parakramabahu II.

name: Fairlawn Fall
description: Although the 4 meter high Fairlawn Fall on the Fairlawn Estate can be reached by road many visitors opt to take the 4km hike along the banks of the Maskellya Oya. The fall which creates several pools is sourced from the Maskellya stream which originates in the Sri Pada Reserve which reaches an elevation of 1810 meters.

name: Piyangala Chithra Lena
description: Piyangala Chithra Lena in the Ampara region of Sri Lanka is huge cave which has ancient paintings inside. You can find the cave about 100 meters from the road sign posted for the Pulukanava Raja Maha Viharaya.

name: Narangas Ella Falls
description: Narangas Ella Falls is a 70 meter high waterfall in the Galle District. The origin of these falls is the Kannekite Canal where it enters a tunnel for the first 7 meters before meeting up with more water to once again disappear into a tunnel. The tunnels are said to have been formed due to logging in the area.

name: Utuwankanda Hill Top
description: Sri Lanka’s most famous highwayman was named Saradiel and he was known to operate from a huge mound of boulders known as Utuwankanda. From the top of Utuwankanda you can see for 100kms in any direction, a perfect place to plan an ambush.

name: Ganeuda Purana Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The Ganeuda Purana Rajamaha Viharaya is said to have been built in the early 15th century however, there is evidence in the form of 8 stone pillars on the site, that a palace once existed here which is believed to have been the Warakagoda Kingdom’s ‘Temple of Tooth’ which would date back to the early 12th century.

name: Beddegana Wetland Park
description: In the heart of Colombo and part of the larger Sri Jayawardenepura Kotte Bird Sanctuary is a nature trail which is raised on wooden platforms and weaves its way through shrubs and vines. The trail is called the Beddegana Wetland Park and affords visitors the opportunity to experience a walk through a forest but without the potential dangers often associated with forests.

name: Strawberry farms
description: Located near to Gregory Lake in Nuwara Eliya, Sri Lanka there is a strawberry Farm. This means that even whilst visiting Sri Lanka you can not only enjoy fresh strawberries or taste a delightful strawberry jam but you can also see how they are grown when you visit the farm.

name: Kuttam Pokuna (Twin Ponds)of Anuradhapura
description: Two ponds, one measuring 132 feet and the other 91 feet are located at the Abayagiri aramic complex. Known as the Kuttam Pokuna or Twin Ponds, they are thought to have been created in the 6th century and joined by a pipeline are an excellent example of ancient Sri Lankan hydrologic engineering.

name: Ellatota Ella Falls
description: Although the Ellatota Ella Falls are an impressive 20 meters high they are not well-known to the city residents living in nearby Bandarawela and so do not receive too many casual visitors. Located near the Ellatota it is surprisingly not visible from the bridge but can still be seen a little further down the road at a sharp curve and that is perhaps the reason it is not so well-known.

name: Deepa Uyana ( Island Garden) - Polonnauwa
description: Deepa Uyana (Island Garden) is perhaps unique and is said to have exceeded even Great Parakramabahu’s palace complex in its grandeur. Although once home to many buildings, the best preserved of these today is the chamber of King Nissankamalla.

name: Kataragama Devalaya - Kandy
description: The Kataragama Devalaya (shrine) in Kandy is located in the city’s commercial area. The Deity Kataragama is one of the most popular in Sri Lanka and so there are several shrines by that name in the country.

name: Piyangiri Ella Falls
description: Located along the Alangoda – Weligapola road the 44 meter high Piyangiri Ella Falls plays an important role for the local villagers. There is supposed to be a cave which links these falls with the nearby Diyavini Falls and each year if that flows first there will be late rain and crops will suffer. The locals therefore perform a ritual to prompt Piyangiri Ella Falls to start to flow first.

name: Samangala Ancient Forest Hermitage
description: 23kms away from Ampara Town is the Samangala Cave Temple Complex which has been in existence since the 2nd century BC. Used as a forest hermitage 10 caves can easily be seen today but there are believed to be at least 40 more hidden in the nearby jungle.

name: St. Clairs Falls
description: Sometimes referred to as “Little Niagara of Sri Lanka” St. Clairs Falls is one of the widest waterfalls in the country. This waterfall actually consists of two waterfalls, one which is 50 meters wide and the other, a little further downstream which is 50 meters high.

name: Ambewela New Zealand Farm
description: Although New Zealand Farm is separate from Ambewela Farm the 2 today are under the same management however, only New Zealand Farm is open to the public. The farm is a popular destination especially for families as between the 2 farms they breed Ayrshire and Friesian cattle which are twice the size of traditional Sri Lankan cattle.

name: Kathaluwa Purana Viharaya
description: The small coastal town of Koggala is located on a strip of land by a lagoon and is famous for being the birth place of Martin Wickramasinghe who is considered by many to be the father of modern Sinhala literature. The Kathaluwa Purana Viharaya was originally built as 2 separate temples in Koggala, separated just by a wall, they later became considered as 1 but later still, due to a dispute between different chapters of the religion, became separate again.

name: Craft Tunnel
description: Discover the perfect blend of culture and cuisine at Craft Tunnel. Browse through colorful hand-made souvenirs, textiles, and carvings crafted by local artisans, then sit down to enjoy a delicious meal in the on-site restaurant. Whether you’re fueling up before a safari or winding down after exploring Udawalawa, Craft Tunnel offers a warm welcome, authentic flavors, and a chance to take a piece of Sri Lanka home with you.

name: Surathali Ella Falls
description: Named after a film which was made in the area the Surathali Ella Falls is 60 meters high and 2 meters wide. The waterfall is divided into 3 segments and is sourced by the Kadawath River.

description: Located on two rocky outcrops Muwangala Rajamaha Viharaya dates back to the 4th century BC. Although much of the temple is now in ruins, a new stupa at the top of 250 ancient steps on one of the rocks has now been built.

name: Dodanthale Tampita Viharaya
description: Before a man during the time of the Kandyan Kingdom, who was planning to steal the Tooth Relic from the current King and appoint himself King, could complete the building of his soon to be palace, the King found out about the man’s plans. The man quickly abandoned his plan and found statues to place in the building after telling the king he had merely been building a temple.

name: Dehigala Ella Falls
description: The nearest town to Dehigala Ella Falls, which is located on the Mahaweli River, is Bibile. The falls are 30 meters in height and can be accessed between the 3 and 6 mile posts on the Bibile to Mahayangana road.

name: Ussangoda National Park
description: Ussangoda National Park is the newest of Sri Lanka’s 21 National Parks and is located in the Southern province. The soil in the park is red unlike anywhere else on the island and myth says that it is the result of a meteor strike back in ancient history.

name: Nuwaragala Monastic Ruins
description: Nuwaragala Monastic Ruins are thought to be the remains of a monastery and castle, built and resided in by the brother of King Dutugemunu who is thought to have been hiding there until the death of his brother.

name: Wilpattu National Park
description: One of the oldest National Parks in Sri Lanka, Wilpattu National Park is also the largest and is uniquely made up of 106 natural lakes or reservoirs. Located in Sri Lanka’s North West, 180kms north of Colombo, this National Park covers 131, 693 hectares of lowland dry zone.

name: Mahaweli Maha Seya (Kothmale Seya)
description: Kotmale Seya (Mahaweli Maha Seya) is located on top of a mountain with exceptional views of the surrounding countryside including the picturesque Kotmale valley. Visitors are not coming here just for the scenic view though as this is the site for what will be the largest stupa built in Sri Lanka in over 2000 years with a 100 foot high dome.

name: Negombo Beach
description: 15 minutes away from the Bandaranaike International Airport is a small coastal town which is referred to by some as the “Little Rome” of Sri Lanka. This could be due to its vibrant night life or because it is home to Negombo Beach where there is an abundance of water sports to take part in. Most likely it is the combination of the two which certainly makes it a place worth visiting.

name: Maduru Oya Ancient Anicut
description: The ancient Maduru Oya sluice is a prime example of why ancient Sri Lankans are considered to have been exceptional engineers in constructing irrigation facilities. This ancient sluice probably built in the 1st century BC even has similar features to modern day irrigation programs.

name: Gedige Ruins
description: The remains of an old building structure, which are accessible off the Watawandana Road, are known as the Gedige Ruins. The building is thought to have once been a sanctuary for the Mahayana cult.

name: Nine Arches Bridge
description: Although the Nine Arches Bridge was planned to be built from steel, due to the commencement of the Great War in Europe, the steel was diverted to the war effort. That however did not deter the British from building the bridge which is said to be the best example of railway construction in Sri Lanka. Due to the uniqueness of the bridge coupled with its surrounding of lush hillsides, this area is becoming increasingly popular with tourists.

name: Independence Memorial Hall
description: Independence Memorial Hall located in Colombo was opened in 1948 to commemorate Sri Lanka’s independence from British rule. As well as providing a site for remembrance the hall also provides a peaceful retreat within the city for families, joggers or just walkers.

name: Anamaduwa Paramakanda Cave Temple
description: In the Putlam District of Sri Lanka there is a mysterious looking rock formation which is home to the even more mysterious Paramakanda Cave Temple which evidence shows was created in the 1st century BC. Although only a few caves have been found there are indications that a monastery complex covered the whole of this odd looking rock.

name: Kachchaputa Ella Falls - II
description: Kachchaputa Ella Falls – II is the second of 2 waterfalls with the same name which can be seen from the main road when visiting the nearby Keriella Falls.

name: Keerimalai Fresh water Spring
description: Keerimalai Fresh Water Spring is unusual as although it is a fresh water spring it is next to the sea. A tank has been built around the spring allowing a place to bath and this means only a wall of the tank separates the fresh water from the sea water.

name: Bomburu Ella Falls
description: Also known as Perawella Falls, the Bomburu Ella Falls are the widest falls in Sri Lanka. Located 15kms from Welimada town the falls are fed by a lake in the central mountains. The falls themselves consist of a group of several smaller falls to provide an impressive sight.

name: Ella Uda Ella Falls
description: Also known as Kahana Ella the Ella Uda Ella Falls are 4 meters high and are sourced from the Kodikande Mountain. Although the falls themselves are perhaps worth a visit, an added bonus for visitors is that from the falls they will be afforded an excellent view of the highest mountain in the Colombo District.

name: Pandioya Ella Falls
description: Surrounded in woodlands the 45 meter high Pandioya Ella Falls gets its name due to the abundance of “Pandi” fish which is a species that can be seen struggling to swim upstream. This waterfall is sourced by the Pandi River and whilst there are 2 more falls further up river, they are difficult to climb to.

name: Alawala Pothgul Len Rajamaha Viharaya
description: This temple at Gamaha is best known for its 3 caves that are situated on the temple’s grounds. The most popular of these caves is Vihara Lena which is home to a huge reclining statue of Buddha which stretches for the length of the cave. Although the reclining statue is thought to date back to the Kandyan Era (1500s AD) 2 other statues in the cave date back to the 4th century BC.

name: Kachchaputa Ella Falls - I
description: Close to the more famous Keriella Falls are 2 waterfalls called Kachchaputa Ella Falls – 1and 11, both of which can be seen from the main road and are about 300 meters apart.

name: Totagamu Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Between its 2 doorways the Totagamu Raja Maha Viharaya displays an image of the god of Love. This temple has been a leading place for learning since the 5th century and was known for its pleasant surroundings where peacocks danced.

name: Galamuna Ella
description: With a height of 8 meters the Galamuna Ella is located along the Ratnapura – Embilipitiya road. Its name means “stone face’ which is believed to have been given it due to a stone culvert which was here in the reign of King Walagamba in order to control water flow in times of drought.

name: Place where King Sri Wikrama Rajasinghe was Captured
description: Currently a commemorative stone pillar stands next to an old tree in the middle of some rice fields. The pillar marks the spot where the British finally captured the last King of Kandy and his family on the 18th February 1815. The locals say the tree has been there far longer than the pillar and that both will soon be made tourist attractions by the Sri Lankan Government.

name: The Dutch Fort of Batticaloa
description: Although known as the Dutch Fort of Batticaloa it was in fact owned by three different European colonial invaders to Sri Lanka. The fort was first built by the Portuguese 1628 but then surrendered to the Dutch in 1638. Later the Dutch surrendered it to the British in 1772.

name: Galdola Ella Falls
description: Located in the Sinharaja forest reserve, running down the side of Suriyakanda Mountain is the Rakwana River and from one of its tributaries is the 100 meter high Galdola Ella Falls. The waterfall actually flows over a very rock strewn terrain and so hence its name as Dola means rock pool.

name: Katuwana Fort
description: As the Kandyan Kingdom refused to fall under the Portuguese and Dutch powers who overtook the coastal areas where they built forts, the Portuguese and Dutch also had to build some inland forts, like Katuwana Fort, to protect them from the Kandyans attacking from the hills.

Within the Central Highlands of Sri Lanka which include montane grassland and cloud forest, Horton Plains National Park is a protected area. This is perhaps the most popular of Sri Lanka’s National Parks as it is home to the world famous World’s End.

name: Submerged Town of Teldeniya
description: In April 1985 7000 acres of land was submerged to create the Victoria Reservoir. This land included villages as well as towns like Teldeniya. Since that time the town has re-emerged on two occasions, the last in 2017 when the reservoir level was extremely low. Although the buildings were obviously destroyed many of the bridges and roads seemed almost intact.

name: Salli Muthumariamunam Kovil
description: Located near to Trincomalee Salli Muthumariamunam Kovil is an important Sri Lankan Hindu Temple. Although regularly during festivals dancers and drummers can be seen around the temple, often the devotees themselves are more interesting to visitors.

name: Mapanana Ella Fall
description: Mapanana Ella Fall is a 141 meter high waterfall located among an abundance of medicinal herbs. The waterfall is fed by water from a stream which starts in the Samanala mountain range.

name: Sangamitta Stupa
description: Archaeologists believe that the Sangamitta Stupa enshrines the ashes of Arhath Sangamitta, the daughter of India’s Emperor Asoka, who along with her brother, came to Sri Lanka in 249 BC to help spread Buddhist philosophy until the time of their deaths.

name: Mawaragala Forest Monastery
description: The Mawaragala forest monastery is located on top of a rocky mountain surrounded by forest. The path up to the monastery, although through the forest, is kept clear by the 25 monks who now inhabit it. The monastery is old and the monks currently there say that in ancient times as many as 60 monks would inhabit it.

name: Pothgul Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The Pothgul Rajamaha Viharaya in Rathnapura is a rock temple which was first built in the 1st century but was renovated during the Kandyan period. Although the temple itself is very picturesque, the main attraction of the temple is probably the 40 foot statue of a reclining Buddha in the cave image house.

name: Ancient Kingdom of Polonnaruwa
description: Polonnaruwa which was founded in the 10th century by the Chola dynasty was the capital of Sri Lanka’s second oldest kingdoms. Although mainly in ruins today it has been named a UNESCO World Heritage site due to it being thought to be the best planned city in ancient Sri Lanka. There is a small town near the ruined city but under a project named "Awakening of Polonnaruwa" a large development program is now underway.

name: Kaluwa Watuna Ella Falls
description: Hidden deep inside the Hasalaka jungle but near to the trail leading to the larger Ratna Falls is the 30 meter high Kaluwa Watuna Ella Falls. When you reach Hasaka village there are 2 paths, 1 to Kaluwa Watuna Ella Falls and the other to Ratna Falls.

name: Viharegama Maliyadeva Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Viharegama Maliyadeva Rajamaha Viharaya is located about 16kms from Dambadeniya and is where it is said the Maliyadeva Thero’s ashes were enshrined in the stupa. In the 13th century when Dambadeniya was the capital, pilgrimages to this temple were very popular.

name: Buduruwagala Temple
description: A complex consisting of 7 statues, the ancient Buduruwagala Temple dates back to the 10th century. Due to an orange streak on the main statue of Buddha, it is thought that this was once brightly coloured. Another statue, close to the Buddha, is thought to be of his female consort, Tara.

name: Nagolla Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Nagolla Raja Maha Viharaya can be found about 1.5kms off the Kurunegala-Alauwa bus route and is thought to have been built by King Walagamba around the start of the 2nd century BC.

name: Kande Sudu Ella
description: The area surrounding the 8 meter high Kande Sudu Ella waterfall is of special interest to environmentalists and as such is located in a world environmental heritage reserve. The interest is due to the variety of orchids, 1 of only 2 species of lizard and several unusual web spinning spiders that inhabit the region.

name: Kataragama Devalaya
description: Kataragama Devalaya in the Uva Province of Sri Lanka is an important place of pilgrimage for both Hindus and Buddhists. Believed to have been built in the 2nd century BC by King Dutugemunu as part of a vow to defeat his enemy today pilgrims smash coconuts to wish ill-will on their enemies.

name: Bathalegala (Bible Rock)
description: Bible Rock got its name due to its flat top making it look similar to a book and it can be seen from the main railway line running from Colombo to Kandy. The look of the rock is perhaps deceiving as it looks to be an impossible climb to reach the top however, a well-used trail affords hikers a relatively easy trek to its flat top.

name: Alawala Pre-Historic Archaeological Site
description: One of the most important Archaeological Sites in Sri Lanka is the caves of Alawala at Gampaha. Although one cave, Vihara lena has statues of Buddha it is the Potugal lena cave which interests archaeologists most. In this cave 2 skulls were found, 1 of a man and 1 of a woman, which are believed to date back to 13,000 BC.

name: Jethavanaramaya - Anuradhapura
description: After a dispute between two orders of monks the Jethavanaramaya Monastery at Anuradhapura was built on the same site as the Maha Vihara Monastery once stood. This new monastery featured the tallest stupa of its time and still today, stands as the tallest building of its kind in the world.

name: Bellanwila Rajamaha Vihara
description: Although Bellanwila Rajamaha Vihara is most famous for its yearly Esala Perehera festival held around August or September, many devotees visit every day regardless of the time of year. Located 12kms south of Colombo this is one of Sri Lanka’s most venerated Buddhist Temples.

name: Yala National Park
description: Sri Lanka’s Yala National Park may be only the second largest national Park in the country but it is certainly the most visited. This is a park where visitors can see wild elephants and where there is the highest density of jaguars anywhere in the world. The area was made a National Park in 1938 after having been a wildlife sanctuary since 1900.

name: Yudaganawa Stupa
description: With a circumference of 317 meters the Yudaganawa Stupa was first thought to be a Kota Vehera (two stupas) but later research proves that it was in fact built as a single stupa.

name: Eli Hatha ( Seven Falls)
description: The 100 meter high Eli Hatha waterfall is currently a collection of 7 smaller waterfalls but there are rumours that soon a dam will be placed on the third lowest part of the falls in order to provide a soon to be built mini-hydro-electric plant.

name: Ravana's cave
description: Ravana's cave otherwise known as the Ravana – Ella cave is something of a legend in in Sri Lanka. The Ravana Cave exists but is said to form a tunnel coming out at Ella Falls and the legend states that King Ravana kidnapped a beautiful Indian Queen, brought her to Sri Lanka and hid her in the cave.

name: Bambarella Saree Ella Fall
description: This fall got its name firstly because it can be reached by car in just 5 minutes from the town of Bambarella and secondly because its form is reminiscent of the fall of a lady’s saree. This is just one of many waterfalls along the Hulu River.

name: Kuda Ella Falls
description: Located above the Kirindi River in Kuttapitiya the Kuda Ella Falls has a name which is probably misleading. Kuda means small but it is only small compared to the nearby Kirindi Ella Falls as at 30 meters in height the is by no means small.

name: Ceylon Eco lodge Kitulgala by realdeal
Danigala Circular Rock
description: Dhanigala Mountain, due to its semi-circular shape, is often referred to as Circular Rock. The mountain in recent years has been the subject of various so called UFO sightings and the unusual vegetation found on the mountain does not help in refuting those claims. The actual circle is a relatively small portion of a larger structure which contains a mysterious cave which has unusual paintings inside.

name: Pothgul Vehera Statue - Polonnaruwa
description: Due to it being located on the Potgul Vehera complex in Polonnaruwa the Statue of Parakramabahu I is often referred to as just the Pothgul Vehera Statue. The statue carved from one large rock stands 11 feet 2 inches high and depicts a man standing, holding a long object in his hands, perhaps a book.

name: Surungamuni Point
description: Surungamuni Point in Haputale can be found after a long hike up hill. This is a shrine which has an arched shape and a statue of blue Surungamuni God inside. It is here where holy men will make sacrifices, which is apparent from the numerous scavenger birds that circle overhead. To some the site may seem scary but all will appreciate the scenic view found from the site.

name: Vehera Kanda Ruins of Kotte Kingdom
description: To protect what remains from vandals and treasure hunters the Vehera Kanda Ruins of Kotte Kingdom are surrounded in barbed wire and locked gates. Kotte was one of Sri Lanka’s historic capitals but unlike most this was not abandoned to be overgrown by jungle and so construction materials from existing buildings were used to create new buildings, thus destroying some of the architecture.

name: Hikkaduwa National Park (Corral Reef)
description: Containing a Fringing Coral Reef the Hikkaduwa National Park only received National Park status in 2002. Prior to that it had been declared only as a wildlife sanctuary but whilst a wildlife sanctuary the reef received detrimental effects from visitors which has now been reduced thanks to its newer status.

name: Sri Nagawanarama Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Hidden away in the Kadigamuwa area of Sri Lanka’s Kegalle District the Sri Nagawanarama Purana Tampita Viharaya is somewhat unique as it has two Tampita Vihara whilst traditionally a temple will only have one. Accounts tell of this temple being built in the 14th century but if that is the case then evidence shows it was renovated in the 18th century.

name: Pethangoda Banboo Grove
description: In an ideal setting surrounded by paddy fields and scenic hillsides two bamboo groves, known as the Pethangoda Bamboo Grove, protected by barbed wire have stood as a tribute to King Rajasinghe since the late 16th century. There are differing tales as to whether the king died after getting a bamboo splinter in his foot or from a cobra living among the bamboo that dealt him a fatal bite.

description: In 2004 whilst preparing to make a new expressway a new archaeological site was found. Now known as the Kumara Ella Archaeological Reserve it is believed the excavations have found an ancient bath house for monks, where they could bathe in hot water, similar to today’s steam rooms.

name: Pitawala Pathana Ella Fall
description: The 75 meter high Pitawala Pathana Ella Fall is one of two significant waterfalls in the Knuckles Mountain Range but due to their isolated location neither is visited very often. Situated deep inside the jungle as you hike to the first of the falls you pass a village which has even been abandoned. Both the falls however are located within about 150 meters of each other.

name: Dematamal Viharaya
description: 4kms from Buttala town, in Helagama, located in a paddy field is Dematamal Viharaya. The temple dates back to the 2nd century BC when 2 princes were battling for power and 1 of the princes, Prince Tissa, hid from his brother in the temple.

name: Budugehinna Rajamaha Viharaya
description: 14kms from  Galewela town is what is known locally as “Punchi Dambulla Len Viharaya” due to its resemblance to the Dambulla Cave Temple however, its real name is Budugehinna Rajamaha Viharaya and was in its own right, home to Buddhist Monks since the 3rd century BC. Although today the cave has been damaged by treasure hunters, many images and one carved statue still remain.

name: Sera Ella Falls
description: Located close to Laggala in the Matale District the 10 meter high Sera Ella Falls may seem unassuming however they do hide a secret. The secret they hide is a cave behind its plunging waters. The cave stays completely dry inside but getting to it along the steps carved into the rock can be difficult due to them being moist and slippery from the waterfalls spray.

name: Aluthnuwara Dedimunda Dewalaya
description: Dedimunda was the general for Lord Vishnu and whilst the Dadimunda deity has several temples in Sri Lanka the one at Aluthnuvara in the Kegalle District is considered the most important. The reason for this is that they believe that Dadimunda built this temple himself as his permanent residence. Dadimunda is often portrayed as a Kandyan chief with a soluva (walking stick).

name: Dunkumbura Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: With a seated Buddha statue in prominence in the inner sanctum, the Dunkumbura Purana Tampita  is built on 25 granite stumps. Although the temple was built around a Bodhi tree in the mid-19th century, the original tree is now gone but a replacement was planted in 1960 and that is the one visitors will see today.

name: Okanda Beach, Ampara
description: Located 28kms from Argram Bay is Okanda Beach which is popular with surfers and has three start points, one for each level of competency. Although the beach is known for its sand and surf, the local area is also known for its wild elephants and leopards.

name: Hathbili Ella Falls
description: Today these waterfalls which are in 2 segments are called Hathbili Ella Falls however, due to monks once living nearby, they were called Meditation Falls. Both segments of the falls drop a total of 11 meters and have a legend attached to them. Local legends state that 7 women used to regularly bathe in the waters but 1 day they all mysteriously vanished.

name: Biso Maligaya Moonstone of the Abayagiri Monastery
description: Believed to have originated around the 7th or 8th century, the moonstone at the Abayagiri Monastery is considered to be the best preserved from that era. There are in fact two moonstones at the site, the first and main one is located on a stairs in the central building whilst the second one can be found at an entrance to another building on the site.

name: Seetha Amman Kovil
description: Seetha Amman Kovil or temple is only temple known to be dedicated to Seeta Mata who was the wife of Lord Rama but prisoner of Ravana more than 5000 years ago.

name: Delwala Ella
description: Located in the Ratnapura District this 20 meter high falls is away from the main roads and so is little known. To visit the falls you can take 1 of 2 trails through a tea plantation, 1 leads to the top of the falls whilst the other leads to the bottom.

name: Lihiniyan Kelina Ella Falls
description: The 30 meter high Lihiniyan Kelina Ella Falls is located on the east side of Pathakade Segapuli Mountain and, according to local villagers, a ghostly procession passes across the falls prior to a period of drought. If seen the villagers pay homage to the deity Kohomba to combat the effects of the drought.

name: Planetarium
description:
Colombo is home to Sri Lanka’s only Planetarium. Built in 1965 the Planetarium is maintained by the Ministry of Science, Technology and Research and can seat up to 570 people as they watch the artificial sky projected on to the domed ceiling above them.

While the experience might be lacklaster compared to other countries, it's still a great exposure to local authentic interaction. If you're expecting to be amazed, it's better to skip. If you're expecting to get a truly local authentic understanding, take a seat!

name: Arambhaya Boutique Hotel
description:
Tucked away in the peaceful Aniwatte area, Arambhaya Boutique Hotel offers a calm retreat just minutes from Kandy’s bustling center. With stylish, modern rooms, a serene garden, and warm Sri Lankan hospitality, it’s the perfect place to relax after exploring the city’s cultural treasures. Guests love the spacious comfort, excellent breakfast, and thoughtful details that make every stay special.

name: Pottuvil Point, Arugam Bay
description: Although there are several places around Arugam Bay suitable for surfers, Pottuvil Point to the north of the bay is considered suitable for all levels of surfers with the waves being constant and breaking on to a shore which has a sandy bottom.

name: Ramboda Ella / Puna Ella Falls
description: Ramboda Ella sometimes referred to as Puna Ella Falls is a unique waterfall in the Nuwara Eliya District of Sri Lanka. Any fall this high with a height of 109 meters would be impressive but what makes this waterfall unique is the fact that it is a double waterfall. That is to say that 2 different waterfalls form a ’Y’ to plummet into the same pool at the bottom.

name: Galdoruwa (Gal Oruwa) Ella
description: The 30 meter high Gal Oruwa Ella flows into a boat shaped boulder making a loud roaring sound as it does. These falls which can be reached along the Lankagama road were once associated with lepers.

name: Olu Ella Falls
description: With a height of 127 meters Olu Ella Falls is listed as the 6th highest in Sri Lanka. It is however the highest waterfall on the Kelani River and in the Kegalle District. Fortunately these falls have not become a garbage dump for tourists as surprisingly, especially as visitors can drive up to the falls without the need to walk, they do not seem to be on any of the tourist routes.

name: St. Mark Anthony's Motors
description: Registered Bajaj Mechanic and Parts shop, also accepts card I'm told.

name: Ferry point
description: Although the ferries between India and Sri Lanka were halted both countries are working to get them reinstated. The new Ferry Point in Sri Lanka recently won an award for its architecture and so will add comfort and efficiency to the ferry service.

name: Delta Falls
description: Sourced from a tributary of the Kotmale River the Delta Falls consist of 6 streams which reach a height of 60 meters. The falls can be reached by rail or from via a bridge at the 41 mile post on the road 6 miles from Pussellawa.

name: Ahugoda Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: This is a temple located between Polgahawela and Kurunegala and consists of 3 structures, each of which has its own historical significance. The first is Tampita Viharaya, a wooden structure which stands on concrete stumps and has walls covered in Kandyan style drawings . The second is a building which is known as the living quarters and was restored on 2011 but the original wooden door is 400 years old.  The third building is a structure designed to cover the stupa.

name: The Assembly Hall of Mihintale Complex
description: Every monastery would have had an assembly hall where the monks could meet and discuss matters. At the Mihintale complex the assembly hall can be seen complete with its larger, raised stone in the middle where the head monk would sit.

name: Budumuththawa Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although Budumuththawa Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya, which is located between Padeniya and Anamaduwa is an ancient temple dating back to the Anuradhapura kingdom, visitors there can see artifacts from the Polonnaruwa and Kandyan eras as well as the Anuradhapura era.

name: Audience Hall of the Kandyan Palace
description: The “Magul Maduwa” or audience hall in the Kandyan Palace has on several occasions been a place where Sri Lankan history was made. One such instance occurred at it in 1815 as this is where 2500 years of Sri Lankan sovereignty ended when the last Sri Lankan Kingdom was handed over to British rule.

name: Kingdom of Anuradhapura
description: King Pandukabhaya founded Sri Lanka’s 1st kingdom, Kingdom of Anuradhapura, in the 4th century BC and its authority spread throughout the country. At the time of this kingdom Buddhism was already playing a strong role however it played an even stronger role after the arrival of the Sacred Tooth Relic.

name: Rock Beds of Yahangala
description: As the word Yahangala roughly means Rock of beds the word could be applied to many places in Sri Lanka however when mentioned people will usually be referring to a remote village on the Galewela – Andiyagala road where there are many caves in a huge rock with at least 12 rock beds inside them.

name: Tempitiya Rajamaha Viharaya Ruins
description: Although the Tempitiya Rajamaha Viharaya had been built in the 2nd century BC it had long been forgotten until in 1920 the ancient site of ruins was revived. In 2014 the ruins were declared a protected archaeological site by the Sri Lankan Government.

name: Weherahena Temple
description: Unlike most other temples in Sri Lanka the history of the Weherahena Temple only dates back to the early 20th century but it already popular withy Buddhist monks. The temple is home to a 39 meter high Buddha statue and what is believed to be the world’s first tunnel temple and with a length of 600 feet, the world’s longest.

name: Dorowana Ella
description: Although the Dorowana Ella waterfall can be seen from the road 800 meters away, due to its location it is difficult to approach any closer. Falling in 2 stages the total height of the falls is 30 meters but divides in the middle to form 2 separate streams.

name: Pareiyan Ella Falls
description: Located in the Monaragala District deforestation has severely affected the once magnificent flow over the 14 meter high Pareiyan Ella Falls. Whilst still a spectacular sight today it is sad to say that if deforestation continues these falls may one day cease to exist.

name: Traditional Food Sales Centre - Hela Bojun
Delft Island Fort Ruins
description: Constructed from limestone and coral the Deft island fort was built by the Portuguese but later taken over by the Dutch. Although in ruins today experts say it would have been a very strong fort at the time of its construction.

name: Jeewana Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Although a Tampita Viharaya was traditionally built on pillars during the Kandian era, the one at Jeewana Purana Tampita Viharaya is built on extra high pillars. A particularly good feature of this temple is its unique door frame which has a Narilafa Flower exquisitely carved on its door frame.

name: Yatala Vehera
description: Yatala Vehera is a Buddhist stupa in Sri Lanka’s Hambantota District. The stupa is thought to be 2,300 years old and built by King Yatala Thissa to mark the place of his birth.

name: Asgiriya Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located near Gampaha City in the Western province Asgiriya Rajamaha Viharaya is close enough to Colombo to receive day trippers from there and the towering buildings of that city can be seen from the top of the small hill on which the ancient temple is built. As with some other cave temples, it is thought this one was used as a hideout by kings as they made their war plans.

name: Masimbula Ella Falls
description: The Rakwana River which starts in Sinharaja Forest flows over many waterfalls and one of these falls is the 15 meter high Masimbula Ella Falls, named after the village in which it is located. According to the villagers the pool the waterfall plunges into is very deep and has taken many lives.

name: Gal Oya National Park
description: Located 312kms from Colombo the Gal Oya National Park is the catchment area for Sri Lanka’s largest reservoir, Senanayake Samudraya. As well as being known as the main catchment area for the reservoir, the national park is also well-known for its elephant herd and important herbs found in its forest.

name: Seethakanda Ancient Monastery
description: The Seethakanda Ancient Monastery in the Monaragala District is thought to have been part of a populated Aramaic complex which dates back to the 11th century. Although a small temple can still be seen in some rock caves, unfortunately any other ruins seem to have disappeared due to a rubber plantation being planted at the front of the site.

name: Giragama Walawwa
description: The name once given to residences of the top officials in Sri Lanka was Walawwa and Giragama Walawwa which is located on the intersections of Colombo Street and the Yatinuwara Veediya in Kandy, built in 1814, is thought to be the oldest still remaining.

name: Sathmahal Prasada (Seven Storied Palace) - Polonnaruwa
description: The most well-known of only 4 square shaped stupas in Sri Lanka is the 7 storied stupa, Sathmahal Prasada located at Polonnaruwa, which was built sometime around the 12th century. It is not known why the stupa was designed like this but several similar ones could be found in Cambodia and Siam and so it is thought that it was built for some Cambodian soldiers who were working for Sri Lanka’s king at that time.

name: Kallaru Lagoon, Batticaloa
description: Batticaloa Lagoon is a massive 56kms long and joins to the sea in 2 places. In the south it joins at Kallaru where it is sometimes referred to as Kallaru Lagoon. The other meeting with the sea occurs near the center of the lagoon Palameenmadu and both of these meeting are about 200 meters wide.

name: Somawathi Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Although Prince Abhaya built the Somawathiya Stupa for his wife Princess Somawathi once it and other buildings were completed, they were handed over to Arahat Mahinda and other monks.

name: Weragama Purana Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya (Diya Bubule Pansala)
description: Weragama Purana Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya also known as Diya Bubule Pansala has been in existence for centuries but has been rebuilt by 4 different kings, the last time being in the 18th century. The site for this temple was close to a spring which provided it water but today, due to the increase in paddy field irrigation, the spring is in danger of drying up.

name: Mapalalla / Katugashinna Ella Falls
description: Located near the town of Rikiilagaskada the Mapalalla / Katugashinna Ella Falls flow far less than it used to due to a dam having been built above it. The falls are 45 meters high and so are still very impressive especially in the rainy season when more water is allowed to flow over them.

name: Dehena Ella Falls
description: With a height of 73 meters the Dehena Ella Falls are very impressive. The source of the falls is a small spring named Gaslabu Ella located on Dehena Mountain. At the foot of the falls is a cave system which is said to get totally flooded during the rainy season.

name: Pasikudah Beach
description: Although tourism to Pasikudah and Pasikudah Beach had been on the increase prior to the 2004 tsunami, the tsunami caused both enough damage to dissuade visitors. Today however, due to renewed development in the area it is once more becoming a popular tourist destination.

name: Mini World's End drop - Horton Plains
description: Horton Plains in Sri Lanka is well-known for its World’s End view point with a 4000 foot drop but there are 5 other mini world ends also in Sri Lanka, one of which is also in Horton Plains. The mini world’s end in Horton Plains only has a drop of 1000 feet at the view point but this can seem far higher when it is shrouded in clouds.

name: Eth Vehera of Mihintale
description: There is no historic records to show who built the Eth Vehera of Mihintale or when it was built but the stupa is thought to have been part of a monastic establishment. Built on top of what is the highest point in Mihintale range with a base diameter of just 27 meters the stupa is relatively small compared to other Sri Lankan stupas.

name: Hathmale Ella Falls
description: Unfortunately the popularity of the 45 meter high Hathmale Ella Falls is having a detrimental effect on its environment with plastic and other trash being left behind by visitors. As well as being the tallest waterfalls on the Ginganga River it is also 1 of the widest with a width of 10 meters.

name: Kirinda Raja Maha viharaya
description: Located on a summit of a rocky mountain near Sri Lanka’s southern coast visitors to Kirinda Raja Maha viharaya are treated to views of the coastline complete with sand dunes and the Indian Ocean. Although visitors to the temple today can still use ancient steps cut into the rock to reach the temple, a more recent stairway has been built.

name: Sangamankanda Point, Pottuvil
description: The most eastern point of Sri Lanka is near Pottuvil and known as Sangamankanda Point. Although in 1947 a 25 foot lighthouse was built there, thanks to the 2004 tsunami, the lighthouse now only stands 15 feet high.

name: Vankalai Bird Sanctuary
description: Vankalai Bird Sanctuary is in Sri Lanka’s Mannar District which was victim to the long civil war. This is the first such sanctuary the government has established in the area since the conflict ended.

name: Diyagalla Ella Falls
description: Located 21kms from Kitulgala, with a height of 20 meters the Diyagalla Ella Falls can be an impressive sight however, due to a hydro-electric plant having been built above the falls, no water flows over it during the dry season.

name: Thuparama Image House
description: Experts cannot decide if the Thuparama Image House at Polonnaruwa was built in the 11th or 12th century but all agree that it is miraculous that it is still in such good condition. This is one of only a few ancient buildings which were made completely out of brick, including the roof.

name: Crocodile Lake / Panama Wewa
description: Panama Wewe is often referred to as Crocodile Lake and is located near the village of Panama. Although not too large the lake is renowned for a rock known as crocodile rock which is visible from the shore and is famous due to large crocodiles often basking on it in order to catch the sun’s rays.

name: Arulmihu Sivasubramania Swami Kovil - Colombo
description: With a history stretching back to 1822, Arulmihu Sivasubramania Swami Kovil is often referred to just as the Pilgrims’ temple due to the number of travellers that visit it. Although fairly modern for Sri Lankan temples, the site on which the temple is located has been attached with Buddhism from ancient times with one nearby shrine said to be founded in 300 BC.

name: Sri Purwarama Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located not far from the Dalukgolla Junction on the Kurunegala – Puttalam Road, Sri Purwarama Rajamaha Viharaya is an ancient temple which was built in the Kandyan Era. As with others built in that period the Tampita Viharaya is built on a wooden platform on top of pillars, usually made of granite.

name: Yatagala Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Yatagala Raja Maha Viharaya is an ancient rock temple located in Kalahe. This temple is known for 2 things, its 9 meter tall statue of Buddha and its 2,300 year old Bo Tree.

name: Nisar Weligama Auto electrical
description: mechanic can fix any kind of electrical work

name: Sri Pada Holy Temple (Adams Peak)
description: 40km northeast of Ratnapura is a mountain known as Adam’s peak and this mountain is famous, not for just being Sri Lanka’s 4th highest but also with Buddhists due to it having what is said to be Buddha’s footprint close to its top. Due to this asset many Buddhists make pilgrimages to the Sri Pada Holy Temple.

name: Berendi Kovila
description: Berendi Kovila, built around the mid- 16th century, is the best preserved Hindu Temple from the Seethaawaka Kingdom era. The temple is located in the Kegalle District and is sign posted from the Avissawella – Kegalle road.

name: Kalthota Kuda Doowili Ella Falls
description: Although in order to visit the 40 meter high Kalthota Kuda Doowili Ella Falls you will have to trek through the wilderness for three and a half kilometers you will at least be urged on by the roar of the waterfalls for the last half kilometer.

name: Muttur Galkanda Temple Ruins
description: The entrance to the ruins of the ancient temple Muttur Galkanda is through a recently built lion gate but although the stupa at the top of the hill on which the temple was built has not yet been restored, its remains can still be seen.

name: Ambareli Rajamaha Viharaya
description: This is an ancient temple built on a rocky outcrop in the Hinguru Wewa area. During the Kandyan era a Tampita Viharaya was a popular feature in temples and the one at Ambareli Rajamaha Viharaya is the tallest in the country. The temple is a popular place of worship for the surrounding area as more recently, a preaching hall was built around the old structure.

name: Angkor Wat
description:
Angkor Wat is an architectural marvel and the crown jewel of Cambodia’s heritage. Built in the 12th century by King Suryavarman II, this vast temple complex is a testament to the grandeur of the Khmer Empire. Originally dedicated to the Hindu god Vishnu and later transformed into a Buddhist site, its intricate carvings, towering spires, and expansive galleries captivate visitors from around the globe.

Surrounded by a vast moat, Angkor Wat is renowned for its symmetrical beauty, iconic central towers, and awe-inspiring bas-reliefs that narrate tales from Hindu epics. Whether illuminated by a fiery sunrise or framed by twilight hues, Angkor Wat’s majestic presence leaves an unforgettable impression. A true wonder of the ancient world!

name: Kosgama Ella Falls
description: Although many people visit the 75 meter Huluganga Ella falls few of them realize that by travelling just another 450 meters they could also see the Kosgama Ella Falls which, although smaller at just 20 meters, is also picturesque. These falls are beneath an ancient steel bridge a little further along the Panvila – Bambarella road.

name: Mahakandura Ella Falls
description: On the Ragalla-Kandy road, close to Padiyapelella, 42kms from Kandy is the 120 meter high Mahakandura Ella Falls which can be seen from the hairpin bend in the road. The water from the fall cascades down several levels before eventually plunging into the depths.

name: Alagollewa village experience by Duara travels
description: Duara travel offers visitors a truly unique experience in the village of Alagollewa. Visitors will not just witness traditional Sri Lakan village life but will experience it first hand as they are accommodated and fed by one of the village families. A portion of the cost to visitors is donated to the village community and so the villagers profit directly from all visitors.

name: Nuwarakanda Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Built in the 3rd century BC Nuwarakanda Rajamaha Viharaya is said to have 32 caves for housing 32 Arhats but many of those caves have not yet been found. There is also supposed to have been a tunnel but the entrance has long been sealed and a stupa built in front of it.

name: Royal Palace of King Parakramabahu
description: Listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in Sri Lanka in the Polonnaruwa District are the ruins of the Royal Palace of King Parakramabahu. In the 12th century this building had 1000 rooms on 7 stories and the huge size of the building can be judged today by just seeing the 1 meter thick walls that still exist.

name: Lanka Filling Station - Galkulama Fuel mart
Whiskey Point, Arugam Bay
description: An excellent place for novice surfers can be found at Whiskey Point, not far from Arugam Bay. Although this point allows for the surf to break beautifully for surfers, it is also a great place for others to just chill out, with sun, sand and seafood delights.

name: Crocodile River
description: Although there are only 2 types of crocodile in Sri Lanka, the Marsh Crocodile and the Sea Water Crocodile, crocodiles as well as other wild life can be seen in abundance during a 3 hour excursion down the Nilwala River.

name: Mayura Pirivena
description: According to ancient records the Mayura Pirivena in Anuradhapura was a leading place of learning during the Anuradhapura era in the 4th century. The monks at this complex had amassed such a huge amount of texts that even scholars from as far away as India would travel here to read them.

name: Aluvihare Rock Temple
description: It is believed that this temple was built by King Devanampiyatissa in the 3rd century BC when Buddhism was first introduced to Sri Lanka. The temple, 30kms north of Kanda, has several caves nearby which are home to many interesting frescos.

name: Mahatma Gandhi Park, Batticaloa
description: The center piece of the Mahatma Gandhi Park in Batticaloa is a golden statue of the great Indian statesman. This is a popular place for people to relax and enjoy a sunset whilst local fishermen pass by in their canoes.

name: Ambilla Raja Maha Viharay
description: Located in Matale the Ambilla Raja Maha Viharay is considered by some archaeologists to be a virtual art gallery. One of the more important pieces of art at this temple is the ‘Hasthi Panjariya’ which features both an elephant and a bull. Legend tells of a King Cobra is the guardian of this temple.

name: Senanayake Samudraya Fisheries Harbour
description: Senanayake Samudraya is a huge iconic reservoir, the largest in Sri Lanka. The reservoir is so large that an area referred to as Fisheries Harbour will show the water recedes 200 meters in the dry season allowing for a plain of new growth to augment the bright colours of the fishing boat sails.

name: Peessa Ella Falls
description: The 45 meter high Peessa Ella Falls is not only enchanting but is probably the only waterfall in the region which flows all year round thanks to being sourced by an aquifer at Mount Lunugala’s peak.

name: Divulwewa Ancient Monastery
description: Although today an archaeological site the Divulwewa Ancient Monastery once housed hundreds of monks. Main items of interest which have been discovered at the site include a library of texts written on pillars and a Buddha statue carved out of sandstone.

name: Padeniya Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Do not be put off when driving along the Kurunegala Puttalam road at the perhaps gaudy modern temple wall of the Padeniya Raja Maha Viharaya located opposite the Anuradhapura turn off as, the exterior hides what is a charming and perhaps somewhat unique find. Once you enter the site and pass the modern additions, on some uneven rocks there is an ancient cave temple. This temple is charming in so far as it terracotta pendant tiles on the eaves and it is unique, for Sri Lanka at least, in so far as it shows a distinct 15th century Chinese influence.

name: Thuparamaya - Anuradhapura
description: Thuparamaya Temple at Anuradhapura is the oldest Buddhist temple in Sri Lanka, built on the instructions of Mahinda Thero who introduced Buddhism to the country. It is said the temple was built to enshrine the collar bone of Buddha.

name: Alahana Privena
description: Polonnaruwa is cramped with many ruins for visitors to explore but perhaps most impressive among them is the Alahana Pirivena Monastery. Built on terraces in idyllic surroundings, the monastery is said to have comprised of rocky outcrops, ponds and streams over an 80 hectare area. 2 of the main attractions of the monastery is a 41 foot high image of Buddha in one of the monastery’s cave and the sight of the sun setting behind its largest building.

name: Budugala Ruins and Temple
description: Unfortunately there is little information available for visitors to Budugala Ruins and Temple but they are still interesting. Although today the site only contains ruins of buildings thought to have been built in the 1st century BC, stone stairways are still accessible so visitors can see the grandness of what it must once have been.

name: Namalpuragama Sri Vishuddharama Tampita Viharaya
description: Although the Tampita Vihara at Namalpuragama Sri Vishuddharama is relatively small it does stand on 16 pillars and has been well maintained. As well as the Tampita Vihara being well maintained the images on the walls of the temple are also still in good condition.

name: Kabulumulla Pattini Devalaya
description: Kabulumulla Pattini Devalaya is only 1 of 4 places of worship to the Goddess Pattini who is considered the patron Goddess os Sri Lanka by both Buddhists and Hindus. It is said that 1 of the anklets she bought with her from India is kept here.

name: Gangaramaya Rajamaha Viharaya
description: One of the most famous temples in Colombo is Gangaramaya Rajamaha Viharaya whose architecture is a mix of Thai, Chinese, Indian and Sri Lankan. The temple is located close to Beira Lake on a site which was once a monastery.

name: New Ishara Motors (Wellawaya)
description: Recommended for both mechanic and helper

name: Wewurukannala Vihara
description: In 1960 a giant Buddha statue 160 feet tall was added to the Wewurukannala Vihara but in order for visitors to see this statue they must first travel through a tunnel which could be described as a Buddhist’s hell. The tunnel is filled with lifelike images of what could happen to people who stray from the path to enlightenment and include being boiled or hacked to pieces.

name: Ancient Embekke Devalaya
description: The Embekke Temple which is located in Sri Lanka’s Ancient Kandy district is popular with tourists. Although the temple, built in mid-14th century, consists of 3 main buildings, it is the Drummer’s Hall which receives the most attention. The attraction of the hall is its wood carvings on its pillars and entrance porch which are considered to be some of the best examples of Sinhalese art.

name: Galapatha Raja Maha Vihara
description: The ancient temple Galapatha Raja Maha Vihara is located close to the Bentota River which has a haunting legend associated with it. Due to the legend many locals can recall their forefathers summoning the gods to protect them from demons if they had to cross the river.

name: Asgiriya Adahanamaluwa Gedige Viharaya
description: Constructed in memory of his mother by Great king Wickramabahu the 3rd in 1312 is the oldest temple in Kandy. Paintings in the shrine room are considered to be of great archeological importance, as are the Dragon Archway, carved doors, pillars, frescoes and some of the inscriptions. On the 12th June 2012, marking its 700th year, the Department of Postal Services of Sri Lanka issued a stamp featuring the complex.

name: Dodanduwa Shailabembaramaya Viharaya
description: Located about 103kms along the Galle–Colombo road the Galle – Colombo was built in 1819. An image house was added in 1837 and its house’s paintings completed in 1877. The temple’s stone statue of a seated Buddha was brought from India in 1839.

name: Waulpane Ella Falls
description: Waulpane Ella Falls is perhaps unique as it is a 45 meter high waterfall which is entirely inside a cave. On inspection by French Scientists it is believed that the cave is at least 500 years old. Although there are 12 other caves nearby this is the only one so far discovered to contain its own waterfall.

name: Kapurella Hotwater Spring
description: The area where the Kapurella Hotwater Spring is located had been a restricted area due to terrorist activities in the early 2000s but now is once more open to the public. This spring which provides water at 64.5 degrees Celsius, provides the warmest waters of any spring in Sri Lanka.

name: Mutiyangana Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Although the city of Badulla may date back as far as the 18th century BC, the Mutiyangana Raja Maha Viharaya which lies at its center only dates back to the time of Buddha. On Buddha 3rd visit to Sri Lanka he went to Badulla and the site of the temple’s stupa is said to be where he met King Indaka.

name: Upulwehera Archaeological Site
description: The Upulwehera Archaeological Site is located at the foot of the Kahalla Pallekele mountain range and today is known to have been home to the Upulwehera Rajamaha Viharaya. The site contains 2 stupa but whilst the smaller of the 2 has had some restoration work, the larger one, located at the top of a hill, remains in its neglected state.

name: Senanayaka Samudra Reservoir
description: The Gal Oya National Park opened in 1954 covering 512 square kilometers and has a variety of wildlife including bear and leopards. It is also home to the Senanayaka Samudra Reservoir, the largest ‘tank’ in Sri Lanka which opened up 100,000 acres of land for cultivation.

name: Minara Motors Dickwella
description: Recommended mechanic to visit the customers for breakdown and this is his garage location

name: Nasivantivu Beach, Batticaloa
description: Batticaloa is one of the top tourist destinations in Sri Lanka as it combines history with some magnificent beaches. Nasivantivu Beach is located about a 45 minute drive from the town and as it has accomodations there is good for day trips or longer stays.

name: Ahupini/Asupini Falls
description: These 30 meter high falls are steeped in history and legend. One legend states that one mounted monarch once attempted suicide by leaping from the top of the falls. Local folk stories say the falls give off a 15 minute roar from time to time and that this signifies they will take a life within the next 2 months. This story is perhaps given credence by the fact that rocks in the plunge pool have been responsible for several deaths and so swimming in it is not advised.

name: Thanthirimale Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Thanthirimale Rajamaha Viharaya was built in the 3rd century BC but its humble beginnings saw greater days as time went on. It is said that King Devanampiyatissa spent one night at the temple but after that it seemed to have developed into a large monastery complex.

name: Kalkudah Beach
description: Located on Sri Lanka’s east coast, far away from the traditional tourist beaches, Kalkudah Beach seems to go on for miles with hardly anyone on its beautiful sands. Apart from a couple of resorts at one end of the curving coastline, all that can be seen is endless sand and palm trees.

name: Dambakola Patuna Temple
description: Dambakola Patuna is the port in the north of Jaffna where Theri Sanghamitta arrived with a sacred BO sapling. King Devanampriya Tissa (250-210 BC) in commemoration of her arrival later planted 1 of the offshoots of the plant there and built a temple on the same site.

name: Delgamuwa Raja Maha Viharaya
description: The Sacred Tooth Relic was protected from the Portuguese for about 40 years inside the Delgamuwa Raja Maha Viharaya and so is an important place of worship in Sri Lanka. King Dharmapala of Kotte was known to be a puppet of the Portuguese and so the custodian of the relic moved it to the temple in order to protect it.

name: Galabadda Biso Pond
description: Thought to date back to the 12th century in the remains of a Palace for a Princess is a pool which is a masterpiece of Sinhala architecture. Made from solid rock the pool has 4 inlets for water, 1 on each side.

name: Yapahuwa Rock Fortress
description: Built on a 90 meter high rock, Yapahuwa Rock Fortress is built in a similar style to the more famous Sigiriya rock fortress. Although built in the 13th century, today, traces of old battles can still be seen in its defenses.

name: Gal Palama over Malwathu Oya
description: 3.4kms from Sangamitta Mawatha you can find an ancient stone bridge crossing over the Malwathu Oya. Although there are in all 5 large stone bridges that have been found in Sri Lanka, this is the most popular with visitors. The bridge is thought ot have been constructed somewhere between the 5th and 9th centuries.

name: Sri Sagala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Containing caves with drip ledges used by monks Sri Sagala Rajamaha Viharaya is part of an ancient and massive Aramaic complex dating back to the 1st century BC. The temple is built on top of a massive rock known as Nelligala.

description: Unfortunately, probably due to treasure hunters, only one of four Buddha Statues remains whole at the larger of two caves at Gal Viharaya. The smaller of the caves, identified as Kuda Gal Viharaya probably also had statues inside but any signs of those have long since vanished

name: Hunukatu Ella Falls
description: The 7.5 meter high Hunukatu Ella Falls is sourced from water running off the Samanala Mountain which then cascades down the limestone of the falls. To reach the falls visitors take the Oath – Makandura road from the Ratnapura to Embilipitiya road as far as Algewatte village.

description: Has done few repairs earlier and now has a tuktuk garage himself

name: Star Fort of Matara
description: Constructed by the Dutch in 1765 the Star Fort of Matara is located about 350 meters from Matara Fort on the eastern bank of the Nilwala River. Although the Dutch had already built Matara Fort in 1740, they had found it to be vulnerable and so decided a second fort was needed.

name: Zen Cafe
description: Serving healthy juices & smoothies, coffee with coconut milk options & food prepared with love! An oasis of peace, plants & positive vibes where you can feel totally at home.

name: Rikilla Ella Falls
description: The nearest town to the 30 meter high Rikilla Ella Falls is Kitulgala and 5kms from the Dedugala highway. This waterfall is sourced by a stream which starts on the north side of the Hunusahaldeniya mountain range.

name: Ancient Stone Bridge at Mahakanadarawa
description: Good connections between villages in Sri Lanka have always been important but as these villages grew, so did the need for better roads. Many of the roads therefore had bridges made of stone and rock so as to facilitate heavier loads. The best preserved of these types of bridges is the ancient Stone Bridge at Mahakanadarawa which used 14’ stone beams as the road, held up by 42 stone columns embedded into the river bed.

name: Katugas Ella Falls
description: The Katugas Ella Falls are listed as being only 6 meters in height but some have estimated the height to be closer to 21 meters. The end of a hike to visit the falls is along the side of the stream but care should be taken as it is prone to flash flooding in the rains.

name: Wanawasa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although the resort town of Bentota is today best known for its beach, it has played a major role in the introduction of Buddhism to Sri Lanka. From the town there is a road which crosses a bridge and then follows the horseshoe of the river. Along this road there are 5 ancient temples, one of which is the Wanawasa Rajamaha Viharaya.
