Thalawathugoda Biodiversity Study Park (Diyasaru Park)
description: The Thalawathugoda Biodiversity Study Park (Diyasaru Park) is an artificial wetland containing ponds and canals over a 60 acre site. As well as the park being home to some marshy plants, it is also home to 50 migratory bird species, 25 species of butterfly and 15 fish species, plus the odd crocodile.

name: Okanda Devalaya
description: Just before the entrance to Kumana National Park there is a lane which heads towards the an outcrop of rock on the beach where you will find the Okanda Devalaya. This is the last gathering point for devotees of the yearly Kataragama Pada Yathra.

name: Habarana Purana Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Today the Habarana Purana Tampita Rajamaha Viharaya is a neatly maintained temple but ruins of pillars and moonstones show as evidence of the temple’s long history dating back to the 1st century. According to the local folklore the temple is the site where an ancient king was buried after he committed suicide having lost a battle against his brother.

name: James Taylor's Seat
description: James Taylor is the man who, at the young age of just 21, brought fame to Sri Lanka as a tea producing country. After his death the tea producers honoured his name by preserving what is known as James Taylor's Seat. This is the remnants of a log cabin he used to stay at which affords magnificent views of the surrounding countryside plus the patch of land on which he first grew tea.

name: Kanugala Sri Pushparama Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: It is believed that the Kanugala Sri Pushparama Purana Tampita Viharaya was built in the 13th century. Standing guard at each side of the entrance to the temple is a statue of a guardian and the site has a traditional dragon arch.

name: Uda Aludeniya Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Located on the Kandy – Gampola road Uda Aludeniya Raja Maha Viharaya was originally built in the 14th century but due to it being reconstructed in 1930, little of the original temple now exists except for what may be the earliest example of Sri Lankan wood carving. The wood carvings are revealed on the original doorframe which still exists and is now being preserved by archaeologists.

name: Thalakiriyawa Tampita Viharaya
description: Although the clay statues of Buddha in the Image House of the Thalakiriyawa Tampita Viharaya on the Galewela Road were damaged by treasure hunters the Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology have restored them.

name: Dodawatta fall
description: Dodawatta fall is also sometimes referred to as Minimaru Ella and is a small little known waterfall which can be seen from the Noori Road. Located inside a tea estate the fall is difficult to access but can be done by hiking a rough trail upstream to the bottom of the fall.

name: Tomb of King Vijaya
description: 6kms south east of the ancient kingdom of Panduwasnuwara is a dagoba called Medagama Kanda which has been conserved by Sri Lanka’s Department of Archaeology and is thought to be the burial site of King Vijaya who died in the 6th century BC.

name: Kabaragoi Ella
description: At 23 meters in height the Kabaragoi Ella waterfall may be relatively small but it is certainly graceful. As with most waterfalls the amount of water flowing down it depends on the season but this is a popular placw with bathers all year round.

description: This waterfall with a total height of 20 meters is in 2 sections. The first section is wide and flows under a bridge on the Beragala to Wellawaya Road and the second section then plummets down after the bridge.

Dankumbura Purana Gallen Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although the Dankumbura Purana Gallen Rajamaha Viharaya is believed to have been founded in the 1st century BC by king Walagamba, it was abandoned for more than 800 years, only being rediscovered 250 years ago. The most important find at this temple is the 27 foot statue of a reclining Buddha which can be found in the temple’s cave.

name: Trincomalee Beach
description: Located on Sri Lanka’s eastern coast about 245kms from Colombo, Trincomalee is known for its world class harbor but now visitors are getting to know it for its beach. Trincomalee Beach has everything visitors could ask for from shipwrecks to dive to or wind surfing.

name: Sinharaja Forest Reserve
description: Sri Lanka’s last primary tropical rainforest is located in the country’s south west and is the Sinharaja Forest Reserve which was made a UNESCO World heritage Site in 1877 to help preserve some of the endangered endemic species which call the forest their home.

name: Hatthikuchchi Aramic Complex ( Rajanganaya Ruins)
description: Today known as the Rajanganaya Ruins, the Hatthikuchchi Aramic Complex dates back to the 3rd century BC and areset in beautiful surroundings. It is believed that this was 1 of the 4 monasteries established by Mahinda Maha Thero when Buddhism was first introduced to Sri Lanka.

name: Balapitiya Purana Viharaya
description: Looking more like a church than a temple, Balapitiya Purana Viharaya was built 130 years ago but no knowledge is available as to why it has a European design. The part of the temple which actually looks church like is the prayer hall and one theory is that it was originally built as a church and then later donated to the temple. This southwestern coastal area of Sri Lanka is predominantly Buddhist and this is considered their main temple.

name: Biso Dola Ella Falls
description: Located in the Ratnapura District the 3 meter high Biso Dola Ella Falls are surrounded in legends. One of the most popular is that this is the place where the ancient King Mayadunne’s concubines would come to play and bath. In times of drought it is said that those concubines can still be heard playing at the falls.

name: Mottunna Sri Kireetaramaya Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Although the Mottunna Sri Kireetaramaya Purana Tampita Viharaya is a modern temple it has an ancient Tampita Vihara which is considered to be one of the best preserved in the Gampaha District.

name: Corbert's Gap
description: Due to there being 5 peaks which look like a clenched fist, the Dumbara Hills were referred to as the knuckles by the British. From Sinhala Dumbara Hills translates to Misty Mountains and earned its name due to the mountains often being shrouded in mist. One of the best vantage points to see this range is known as Corbert's Gap.

name: Budulena Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Perched on a mountain the road to Budulena Rajamaha Viharaya is curved as you ascend higher and higher. As you travel the road up in an SUV mountains seem to be all around you but finally you reach the top and can visit the temple’s shrine room with its images of the Lord Buddha.

name: Silent Beach Tangalle
description: Although Sri Lanka has many nice beaches perhaps the ones around Tangealle are usually less crowded. Located on the southern coast Silent Beach, also known as Amanwella Beach has beautiful white sands which are fringed with palm trees.

name: Jaffna Fort
description: After the Portuguese invasion of Sri Lanka in 1618 the Portuguese built a Fort at Jaffna. The location of the fort was close to Gurunagar which is a village where some miracles had been attributed to a statue of the Virgin Mary and so originally the fort was named Fortress of Our Lady of Miracles of Jafanapatão (Fortaleza de Nossa Senhora dos Milagres de Jafanapatão).

name: Nagalakanda Monastic Ruins
description: Not much is known about the history of the Nagalakanda Monastic Ruins or when they were in fact built but archaeologists know that it was just a part of a huge complex, much of which has still to be excavated.

name: Kushta Raja Gala
description: Believed to have been carved around the 8th century, Kushta Raja Gala is a Statue carved into solid rock. The origins of the statue or who the statue is of is not known for sure but one of the main theories is that it is of a foreign King who was cured of a skin disease, known to the Singhalese as Kushta, whilst visiting the area.

name: Kondawattuwan Ruins and Reservoir
description: The Kondawattuwan Reservoir is thought to have been built between the 1st and 3rd centuries BC and is surrounded by ruins. The ruins are what is left of the once great Digamadulla kingdom but what is perhaps of more interest are the nearby ruins of an ancient monastery which has square and round stones with replicas of Buddha’s footprints, a rarity in eastern Sri Lanka.

name: Waulpane Rock caves
description: Although the Waulpane Rock caves are legendary in so far as they have evidence of a civilization dating back thousands of years, they are rapidly losing their interest to visitors. The reason for this wane in interest is that the caves have become places used by illegal gem miners and the area around subject to logging activities.

name: Ellepola Ella Falls
description: When seen from the weat it is said that the 18 meter high Ellepola Ella Falls resembles a white sail. These waterfalls can be seen from the school on the Colombo – Ratnapura road however a better view can be experienced from the just after the State Plantations Welange Estate.

name: Second Samadhi Statue at Abayagiri Monastery
description: What is known as the Second Samadhi Statue at Abayagiri Monastery is of unknown origin but the pose which the Buddha is in was popular in the 6th to 8th centuries so experts suspect it is from that period.

name: Ramba Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Located on the bank of the Walawe Ganga Ramba Rajamaha Viharaya was once the royal temple when Maha Nagakula City spent a brief period as the country’s capital. It was also used by King Vijayabahu I to plan his war against Cholas in 1055. This would account for the large numbers of artifacts discovered at the site during excavations.

name: Lihiniyagala Len Viharaya
description: The same cave which houses Lihiniyagala Len Viharaya is also home to the only prehistoric cave paintings in Sri Lanka’s central Province. Although the actual date the temple was built is unknown, some of the inscriptions are known to be from the 2nd century BC.

name: Talalla Beach
description: Located 26.5kms from Galle Talalla Beach is one of the many beaches in Sri Lanka which is becoming popular with foreign tourists. This is a sandy inlet which is fringed with palm trees and yet has all the modern conveniences of guest houses and appealing eateries.

name: Indian bajaj motors
description: They have spare parts and the garage at the same location

name: Yahangala Archealogocal Ruins
description: In the Hambantota District of Sri Lanka there is a huge rock which has had steps carved into it and is known as the Yahangala Archealogocal Ruins. At the site there is a bubble shaped dagoba which is thought to date back to the 1st century AD but this ancient site probably has a history which dates back much further than that.

name: Anandakulama Tissa Forest Hermitage
description: As if hugging the sky, perched upon what seems like intricately balanced rocks, the Anandakulama Tissa Forest Hermitage is a statue of Buddha. This formation of rocks is located near Trincomalee Town on the road to Kanniya Hot springs.

name: Kokilai Bird Sanctuary
description: The Kokilai Bird Sanctuary is located on Sri Lanka’s eastern coast about 60kms from Trincomalee. Covering an area of 7,401 acres the sanctuary includes the Kokilai Lagoon and surrounding area of mangrove swamps, forest, scrub and some cultivated land. The sanctuary is of most importance to migrating wading birds such as egrets, flamingo heron and storks.

name: Ratnapura Maha Saman Devalaya
description: It is believed that a Maha Saman Devalaya has existed at Ratnapura long before the Portuguese destroyed it in the 16th century but later, in the 18th century the one which can be seen today was built by the Kandyan Kingdom.

name: Lagoon Safari - Community Engagement Project
description: The oldest Bird Sanctuary on Sri Lanka is located in the south at Tangalle. In a project designed to engage the local community the Kalametiya Bird Sanctuary now offers a Lagoon Safari for visitors to see some of the 150 migratory birds and the 40 species of fish known to reside in the lagoon.

name: Nagolla Aramaya
description: In caves which have been modified for today’s modern monks, shaded by trees and almost invisible to the human eye, is Nagolla Aramaya, a monastery and hermitage which dates back to pre-Christian times.

name: Budupatuna Ruins
description: Although the ruins of an ancient complex called Budupatuna, far from civilization deep in a forest reserve, may have been forgotten by the authorities, treasure hunters certainly knew of its existence. Although a Japanese expedition to the site in 1985 reported 3 statues intact, a similar expedition in 1992 reported that 1 of the statues had been ravaged by treasure hunters.

name: Barathanaga Lena cave Temple
description: The Barathanaga Lena cave Temple is a complex of numerous drip-ledge caves which have inscriptions on them dating back to the 3rd century BC. The Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology has designated all inscriptions at this site as archaeological monuments.

name: Yatawatta Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Though built in the 15th century the Yatawatta Purana with its Tampita Viharaya whose door frame was carved much later, in 1861, is almost as popular today with Buddhist priests as it was then. Today this temple is considered a major place of learning for many Buddhist priests.

name: Dodanwela Devale
description: Whilst on his way to battle the Portuguese King Rajasighe II was forced to make a stop in Dodanwela and vowed to give his crown and jewels to its people if he proved victorious. He was and he kept his word. Dodanwela Devale was built on the site to commemorate the event but the King’s crown is now in the Kandyan Museum, or was until it was recently stolen by treasure hunters

name: Kudumbigala Monastery
description: Believed to have existed since the 3rd century BC archaeologists have found at least 200 caves associated with Kudumbigala Monastery. The caves would have been used by monks in the past but even today the monastery serves as a retreat for monks who want to get away from bustle of modern day life.

name: Diyathiri Ella Falls
description: After the waters from a tributary of the Maha Oya River drop the 30 meters of the Diyathiri Ella Falls, they continue a further 125kms to the sea. The falls are located in the Nuwara Eliya District 20kms from Nawalapitiya.

name: Coffee Planters Fountain
description: The Coffee Planters Fountain in Kandy was constructed in British style to commemorate a visit to the city by HRH the Prince of Wales. Prior to tea becoming the major agriculture product of Sri Lana, formerly Ceylon was a major producer of coffee and it was the coffee planters of the time that built the fountain.

name: Bambarakanda Ella Fall
description: Located in the Badulla District with a height of 263 meters (863ft), Bambarakanda Ella Fall is the tallest waterfall in Sri Lanka. Located 5kms from the A4 Highway, surrounded by Pine Trees this waterfall forms part of the Kuda Oya which itself is a branch of the Walawe River.

name: Wambatuhena Ella Falls
description: 66 families depend on the stream which feeds the 10 meter high Wambatuhena Ella Falls. These waterfalls whose water finally flows to the Telegram Oya Reservoir at Pothuwala used to be known as the Kahagala Ella Falls.

name: Agrabodhi Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Dating back to the 3rd century BC, Agrabodhi Rajamaha Viharaya is an ancient Temple in Weligama. Legend has it that the Temple was built on the site which, whilst moving saplings from the Bodhi Tree (also known as the tree of enlightenment due to Buddha being enlightened whilst sitting beneath it) to southern regions, one of the saplings took route there during a rest period. The temple is also the site where one of the best preserved “Ata Magala” stones was discovered, complete with its 8 clear carvings. Although destroyed during the Portuguese rule, the Temple was rebuilt between the years 1781–1798.

name: Queens Tower at Delft
description: Queens Tower is a tower which was built by the Dutch on Sri Lanka’s southern coast in an area known as Delft Island. Built like a chimney a fire would be built at the bottom and the glow at the top could then be seen out to sea. The British also used this tower and in fact built their own called Kings Tower however only the basement of that tower still remains today.

name: Aradhana Gala - Mihintale
description: Aradhana Gala, also known as the “Rock of Invation” is located on a flat plateau on top of a rock 1000feet high. This is the place where it is said that Arahat Mihindu first met King Devanampiyatissa. During the month of June, which is the month the historic meeting took place Buddhists make a pilgrimage to Aradhana Gala.

name: The growing rock at Delft
description: 30kms away from Sri Lanka’s Jaffna peninsula is its farthest inhabited island, Delft. This island is known for its herds of wild horses left over from the colonial days and also for its ‘growing rock’. The rock does actually appear to grow as it has gotten larger over the years. Currently measuring close to 4 feet, locals can remember when it was only about 1 foot high when they were young. It is thought to be active coral in the rock that makes the rock continue to grow in size.

name: Nagadeepa Viharaya
description: In the Jaffna District of the Northern Province of Sri Lanka is the Nagadeepa Viharaya an ancient temple and one of only sixteen of the country’s holiest shrines. According to local history the location is where, having been enlightened, Buddha visited in order to settle a dispute between two warring kings.

name: Rock Beds of Gerandigala
description: The Rat Snake Rock (Gerandigala) is a 1km long rocky outcrop that the Galewela – Kalawewa Road runs parallel with. What makes this rock outcrop different from other outcrops is that this is not flat on top but instead has delicately balanced rocks making it look like the plates on a dinosaur’s back.

name: Nalini Ella Falls
description: Although Nalini Ella Falls is what the locals’ call these 240 meter falls, they apparently have no official name. These mysterious falls are so high it seems like forever before the water reaches the bottom.

name: Galkiriyagama Sri Wanasinghe Viharaya
description: The drip ledge caves, Tampita and stupa at the Sri Wanasinghe Viharaya in Galkiriyagama have been declared protected monuments by the Sri Lankan Department of Archaeology since 2011. One unusual feature of this temple is that all the statues in the image house seem to be of a Samadhi posture.

name: Marble Beach
description: Marble beach is located in Trincomalee and provides visitors with plenty of activity besides swimming in the Indian Ocean. A volleyball court at the shoreline is in regular use and a fine selection of foods is available for when the exercise takes its toll.

name: Dalveen Falls
description: In the Ratnapura District near Rakwana are the 30 meter high Dalveen Falls. Although the falls can be accessed via the Dalveen Estate superintendent’s bungalow junction, visitors are advised to use a 4 wheel drive vehicle when doing so.

name: Kaudulla National Park
description: In 2002 the Kaudulla National Park, located 197kms from Colombo, became Sri Lanka’s 15th National Park and in the 2004/2005 season it received 10,000 visitors. The park is known for its dry evergreen forests and the phytoplankton in its large water tanks.

name: Beligala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: This is said to be a place where 1 of the original 32 Bo-tree saplings were planted. It is also said that this is the temple where the Dambadeniya King Vijayabahu III hid the Holy Tooth Relic during his reign.

name: Medirigiriya Vatadage
description: Medirigiriya Vatadage dates back to pre-Christian times and is mentioned in chronicles from the 2nd century. Due to an invasion of the area the site was abandoned and only rediscovered in 1897. In 1937 600 acres surrounding the temple became an archaeological site and in 1945 the site was opened for the public.

name: Neelagiri Maha Seya
description: Built in the 1st century BC Neelagiri Maha Seya was restored in the 7th century but then due to 30 years of terrorism in the 1990s it needed restoration work again. New restoration was able to start in 2011 on what is the largest stupa in the Eastern Province and since then at least two new inscriptions have been found which also date back to the 1st century BC.

name: Anjaligala Rajamaha Viharaya Ruins
description: Although there is today a new temple called Anjaligala Rajamaha Viharaya, it is built on the same site as the ruins of an ancient temple with the same name. What remains of the ancient temple are a ruined pagoda, some inscriptions and pillars which used to hold up the old temple buildings.

name: Thunmodara Ranmudu Ella Falls
description: Located 48kms from Colombo, unfortunately the 15 meter high Thunmodara Ranmudu Ella Falls is becoming a victim to its own popularity as the number of visitors the falls receives is having a detrimental effect on the waterfalls natural environment

name: Napath Ella Falls
description: Located in Kolambagama Pahalakande village in the Ratnapura District, Napath Ella Falls is 12 meters in height. At the top of the falls there are two separate cascades but they join halfway down to complete the drop as one. Local legend tells of a light that sometimes appears from the falls but only one woman is said to have witnessed it before it disappeared.

name: Gal massa (The Dolman) of Padavigampola
description: The only known example of construction by Stone Age man on Sri Lanka is the Gal massa (The Dolman) of Padavigampola. Built in a similar style to that used by druids in the building of England’s famous Stonehenge, as it pre-dates written history, no historic records are known to exist regarding why it was built or what purpose it served.

name: Kabiliththa Devalaya (Maha Siyambalawa Devalaya)
description: Although Kabiliththa Devalaya does not bring the thousands of devotees daily like the famous Kataragama Devalaya but it does still receive daily visits from the most devoted. The site is supposed to hold great spiritual powers and so devotees must go without eggs, meat or fish for a week before visiting.

name: Diyasunnatha Kirthi Sri Rajasinghe Tampita Viharaya
description: The Kirthi Sri Rajasinghe Tampita Viharaya in Diyasunnatha dates back to the 13th century and at that time King Vijayabahu II is said have built a 3 storied image house at the site. Today the temple is used as a place of learning, educating lay students and monks.

name: Galle Lighthouse
description: Located within the walls of the Galle Fort the Galle Lighthouse is the oldest light station in Sri Lanka however, due to the original being burnt down 1934, a new 1 was built in 1939 100 meters from where the original stood.

name: Kurundu Oya Falls (Maturata Ella)
description: Located on the Kurundu River, Kurundu Oya Falls cascading down 189 meters is Sri Lanka’s 2nd highest waterfalls. To reach these magnificent falls, which are in the Nuwara Eliya District, take the Kandapola road from Nuwara Eliya for 18kms and then another 11kms into the Coodoogala Jungle after which you will have to hike the last 2kms.

name: Sithulpawwa Magul Maha Viharaya
description: Recently having been dated to the 2nd century BC Sithulpawwa Magul Maha Viharaya in Sri Lanka’s Hambanthota District is said to be where princess Viharamahadevi and King Devanampiyatissa consummated their marriage after he had met her ship at Pottuvil and they were making their way to the capital, Magama.

name: Little Adam's Peak
description: Little Adam's Peak attracts a lot of visitors as although it is 1141 meters high and offers some spectacular views, it is a gradual and fairly easy hike to the top. As with most places at this elevation it is best to reach the top early in order to avoid it being cloud covered.

name: Berry Ella Falls
description: Located in the jungle area of Helagama the 9 meter high Berry Ella Falls are not the easiest to find but can be accessed from the 6 mile post along the Bibile – Mahiyangena road. Legend has it that a woman named Berry drowned at the bottom of the falls and so her name was added to the original name of the falls.

name: Devin Panna Ella Fall (Dunu Mala Ella)
description: Devin Panna Ella Fall is a 45 meter high waterfall located in an area which is steeped in legend. Ancient queens are said to have played the indigenous game “Pancha” in 5 holes in the rock close to the falls.

name: Devagiri Ella Falls
description: The water flowing to the Devagiri Ella Falls is from is the Dedugala Ehala Palanpitiya Mountain. Although these falls are 90 meters in height they do not receive many visitors due to their location. People who do want to visit them can find them near to Dedugala on the Dolosbage – Bulathkohupitiya Road however, locals refer to them as Diyangiri ella.

name: Minuwan Ella Falls
description: Although the many waterfalls along the Deraniyagala – Noori Road have had much of their water diverted by hydro power plants some, like Minuwan Ella Falls can still be impressive, especially during the rainy season. This particular waterfall has 4 segments and whilst the highest is only 4 meters in height, the 3rd and largest is an impressive 18 meters tall.

name: Nagadowa Ella Falls
description: The Nagadowa Ella Falls are listed as just being 8 meters in height but they are considerably higher, perhaps at least 80 meters. The confusion may be because the falls are made up of many small waterfalls coming down from the top of a mountain and so the 8 meters may refer to the last small plunge into the pool at the bottom.

name: Patan Oya Ella Falls
description: Although the 5 meter high Patan Oya Ella Falls is only one of many in the Sinharaja Reserve it does have the advantage of being located only 4kms from the reserve’s ticketing office.

name: Glassaugh Falls
description: Close to the railway crossing at Nanu Oya station is located the 20 meter high Glassaugh Falls. Although these falls are in 3 sections, only the top 2 can be seen from the railway from Nanu Oya station towards Radella.

name: Bingoda Monastic Ruins
description: Forgotten over time but clinging to the side of a massive rock, now covered in jungle are the ruins of what have been called the Bingoda Monastery. To reach these ruins you will have to hike about 1.5kms and rise about 150 meters, some by way of steps carved into the granite rock.

name: Kaudulla Tank
description: Ever since the 11th century Sri Lanka has been known for its reservoir building skills and one of the greatest reservoir building feats of the 12th century was the Kaudulla Tank along with 15 other tanks and a network of 3 canals.

name: Balla Mala Ella
description: These falls were originally called Karawita Ella and flow down Udakarawita Mountain however, after a nobleman by the name of D G Siridoris, witnessed the dog of a planter lose its footing and fall to its death at the falls, he referred to them as Balla Mala Ella Falls (the waterfall in which the dog died). The falls have been widely known by this new name ever since.

name: Meepitiya Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: The Meepitiya Purana Tampita Viharaya is unusually small for a temple but what is even more unusual is that original paintings on the walls have been painted over in white. There is a 2’6” Buddha statue under the dragon arch however even that seems to have been altered from its original state.

name: Guruge Nature Park
description: The first theme park to open in Sri Lanka is called Guruge Nature Park and its theme is Sri Lanka’s history. The country’s history goes back to the 5th century BC and so the park has plenty of scope for rides and amusements.

name: Pulukunava caves and ancient ruins
description: The Pulukunava caves and ancient ruins near Ampara are located on the side of a forested hill alongside the Ampara – Mahiyangana road. There are numerous ruins at this site which include some drip-ledged caves with inscriptions which date back to pre-Christian times. Much of the rest of the ruins have been ravaged by treasure hunters but the torso of a Buddha statue can still be seen as well as a number of pillars and other remnants.

name: Deliwala Kota Vehera
description: Built in the 3rd century BC Deliwala Kota Vehera by Keerthi Tissa and later in that same century, under the reign of King Devanmpiyatissa, ancient relics were bought to the temple where they were ceremoniously enshrined.

name: Bellanwila - Attidiya Bird Sanctuary
description: Next to the famous Bellanwila Buddhist Temple in the suburbs of Attidiya just outside Colombo are the marsh lands of Attidiya Bird Sanctuary. Visitors to the sanctuary are allowed to walk the trail which at the halfway point has a viewing platform ideal for bird watching. As well as the many different birds visitors can see from the platform, they will also be treated to views of Adam’s peak in the distance.

name: Sherry Land
description: For all the off-road enthusiastic. A pub to enjoy chilled beer & fresh seafood and get some free off-road advice.Â

name: Menik Vehera - Polonnaruwa
description: The Menik Vehera Aramaic complex was part of the Polonnaruwa Kingdom and although built in the 8th century, evidence indicates the original complex was added to later. The 1st of 2 image houses at this complex has 3 standing and 1 sitting images of Buddha whist the 2nd has just 1 Buddha statue.

name: Hiriwadunna Sri Bodhiraja Forest Hermitage
description: Although the Hiriwadunna Sri Bodhiraja Forest Hermitage complete with its Bodhi tree now lies in ruins 1km from Habarana Town it became a popular topic several years ago due to a conspiracy theory published by a local priest. The hermitage was mentioned in the theory whose gist was that Buddha was actually born in Sri Lanka but that fact had been kept secret by India.

name: Vijithapura Raja Maha Viharaya
description: The Vijithapura Raja Maha Viharaya takes its place in Sri Lankan history from the 2nd century BC when it was one of the final battlegrounds where king Dutugemunu defeated the Indian Tamil King.

name: Kallady Beach, Batticaloa
description: Although today Kallady Beach, Batticaloa is perhaps one of the best kept beaches on the island there is a stark reminder of sadder days, namely the devastating tsunami of 2004. There is debris from that fateful Boxing Day still on the beach but it is cordoned off with a reminder that people should always be respectful.

name: Nilavarai Well in Jaffna
description: Known to some as the Nilavari Bottomless well as the Nilavarai Well in the Jaffna District never seems to run dry, this well is obviously very popular and serves to irrigate a large portion of the region.

name: Third Samadhi Statue at Abayagiri Monastery
description: There are three representations of Buddha, each from a different time period. The first is the seat on which Buddha sat whilst attaining enlightenment. The second is the footprint of Buddha and the third are statues of Buddha. Unusually all three of these representations are present in the Abayagiri Monastery.

name: Arisimalai Beach
description: The word Arisi means rice and so Arisimalai Beach got its name due the sand which is unusual as it seems more similar to polished rice than traditional sand. This beach is considered to be one of the best untouched beaches, certainly in the region north of Trincomalee.

name: The Kip
description: Great lunch selection.Â

name: Mulgama Seethagangula Uda Ella
description: Located in the Nuwara Eliya District at Mulgama Village lies the Mulgama Seethagangula Uda Ella whose waters flow another 800 meters to the Maskeliya Reservoir. A path leading to the village and the falls starts just before Nallathanniya but is often hidden by foliage.

name: Monument of Battle of Randeniwela
description: A monument along the Ella-Wellawaya highway commemorates one of Sri Lanka’s greatest victories. The victory occurred in 1650 at the Battle of Randeniwela when the Sri Lankan Kandyan Kingdom forces defeated the Portuguese invaders. The victory meant the start of the end of Portuguese dominance on the island with the leader of the Portuguese forces head being removed and displayed across the entire country.

name: Bahirawa Kanda
description: Bahirawa Kanda, which translated means mountain of Bahirawa, is a village located in the middle of Kandy. The village is known for its Sri Maha Bodhi Viharaya, a giant statue of Buddha in a pose of meditation. Although the statue was started in 1972, the site was officially opened to the public in 1993.

name: The underwater Kadadora Viharaya
description: Projects to fertilize parts of Sri Lanka has led to towns, villages and many temples to be submerged under new reservoirs and among them is a temple which is thought to have been called Pratibimbarama Viharaya of Kadadora. During periods of extended droughts the temple has re-emerged to show its statues and architecture. It first appeared in 2009 having been submerged for 30 years and then again more recently in 2016.

name: Thambadola Ella Falls
description: According to local villagers the 3 meter high Thambadola Ella Falls are under threat due to logging and other activities harmful to the environment and they say that indigenous fish and birds are also at risk.

name: Bo Ella Falls
description: Popular as a picnic and bathing area for locals, the 3 meter high Bo Ella Falls flows through rocks descending into a large rock pool. Fed by a stream from the Ma Oya River which starts on the Aranayake Rassawa Mountain, the falls exit the rocks via a 2 meter hole.

name: Velgam Vehera
description: Known to Hindus as Natanar Kovil the Buddhist Temple Velgam Vehera is located 6 miles outside Trincomalee in Sri Lanka. This temple has a wall which surrounds what is left of several structures but prominent among them is a stone statue of Buddha.

name: Rangiri Lena Viharaya
description: Away from busy roads in the Kurunegala District at Kumbukwewa area built under a huge rock cave is the Rangiri Lena Viharaya. This temple has 2 image houses, 1 which is built into the rock cave and the 2nd is built around other caves nearby.

name: Nelum Wewa Hot Springs
description: In the foothills of the famous Dimbulagala mountain range are the foothills of the famous Dimbulagala mountain range. Although there are several hot springs commonly known of in Sri Lanka, apart from some local villagers the existence of these were unknown until 2009.

name: Lebanon Estate waterfall No 1
description: Hidden away on the Lebanon Estate in the Kandy District are 2 beautiful waterfalls. The 1st of these falls has a height of 30 meters and is located about 250 meters from the bridge on the Bambarella road in the estate.

name: Bodhirajarama Maha Viharaya (Angurukaramulla Temple)
description: Although 90% of the inhabitants of Negombo are Catholic, hence it being known as “Little Rome”, the Bodhirajarama Maha Viharaya is very popular with Buddhists there. The temple is home to some good sculptures depicting Buddha in his work.

name: Korasagalla Wewa Biso Kotuwa
description: The ancient village of Korasagalla and the Korasagalla Wewa (reservoir) and its sluice (Biso Kotuwa) date back to the 3rd century BC. The village is said to be the place where King Dutugemunu received successful treatment after having been bitten by a Cobra in the 2nd century BC.

name: F.J.F.W Motors
description: recommended mechanics in Galle

name: Kandurugoda Archaeological Ruins
description: Maintained by the Sri Lankan army the Kandurugoda Archaeological Ruins are one of the few temples that now remain in the Jaffna District. There are a couple of legends associated with the temple but both of them refer to 60 monks being either poisoned here or died from famine and their bodies are supposedly entombed in the stupas.

name: Deepaduttaramaya Temple
description: Deepaduttaramaya Temple was the1st Buddhist Temple to be built in Colombo and although the Dutch rulers were against it, Mudliyar Thabrew Ubayakulatunga Wijesiriwardhana managed to convince them it should be built. This is the temple where the Buddhist flag was designed and whilst later suffering from years of deterioration, mainly in part to the Thai Royal Family who has worshipped there and made donations since the start of the 20th century, it has been restored.

name: Tharulengala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: The Tharulengala Rajamaha Viharaya built on a rocky hillside in the 3rd century BC is perhaps a perfect example of an ancient rock temple. Today this site is a forest hermitage covering about 20 acres but from its early beginnings it appears to have been constantly in use and being improved on.

name: Bolthumbe Saman Devalaya
description: The temple Bolthumbe Saman Devalaya was built in honour of King Ravana and even today he is prominent in the annual procession held in August. The procession features the Ravana Flag and it is said that one of the original Ravana Flags is held in the temple but it is never exposed to visitors.

name: Shiva Kovil (no. 1) - Polonnaruwa Kingdom
description: The stone blocks which have carvings on them at the 1st Kovil you reach when entering the ancient city of the Polonnaruwa Kingdom are not found around that area of Sri Lanka. As the carvings have been done in an Indian style it has therefore been suggested that perhaps the stones were brought from India or perhaps had Indian carvers come to Sri Lanka.

name: Pidurangala Monastary
description: Although the Pidurangala Monastary in the Matale District of Sri Lanka is thought to have been built as early as the 2nd century BC it only came to prominence in the 5th century when King Kashyapa hid therefrom his brother after having killed their father.

name: Kalotuwawa Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Kalotuwawa Purana Tampita Viharaya is built on a rocky hill and at the top is the stupa and the Tampita Viharaya. This temple is said to have been built in the late 18th century by Sri Lanka’s last king and is where, at a nearby pool, his queens would bathe.

name: Papol Ella Falls
description: Split into 3 segments the 45 meter Papol Ella Falls is located in the Ratnapura District adjacent to Makandura village. Although you can drive most of the way to these falls, at the end there is a steep slope to address in order to reach the bottom of the rock-face the falls surge down.

name: Tissamaharama Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Tissamaharama Rajamaha Viharaya has 4 ancient stupa, the largest of which is believed to have originally been built in the 3rd century BC but then been enlarged in the 1st century BC.

name: Kaludiya Pokuna of Mihintale
description: The Mihintale region is renowned for its ancient ponds and waterways and largest of these pools is Kaludiya Pokuna which roughly translated means ‘black water pool’. Thye pool is surrounded by trees and boulders which take on a somber look when reflected in the waters of the pool and this is why the pool is thought to have gotten its name.

name: Kempitikanda Sri Bodhirukkarama Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: Kempitikanda Sri Bodhirukkarama Purana Tampita Viharaya is just one of many temples that can be seen on the right hand side of the road whilst travelling from Colombo to Kandy and many of them are Soldara Vihara (Storied Temples).

name: Henanigala Raja Maha Vihara
description: The Henanigala Raja Maha Vihara is thought to be 1 of 64 temples built by King Kaouanthissa. The son of King Kaouanthissa was King Dutugamunu whose 6 foot statue can still be seen at the temple.

name: Arambe Ella Fall
description: The impressive Arambe Ella Fall is 54 meters high and 14 meters wide and is located in a forest known for its medicinal plants. The forest is also home to many fruits and for thousands of years prior to colonization, could support all of the local villagers needs.

name: Ruins of Panduwasnuwara Kingdom
description: Having brought back to Sri Lanka the Sacred Tooth Relic from India, King Parakramabahu made Panduwasnuwara the Kingdoms new capital to house the relic in. The city enjoyed only a short period as the capital though and so there are still many ruins to see, there are not as many as there are in places like Anuradhapura or Polonnaruwa.

name: Kundasale Sri Narendrasinghe Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Sri Narendrasinghe Rajamaha Viharaya was built in the 18th century at Kundasale about 6 miles from Kandy. Built by King Kirthi Sri Rajasinhe he later presented the temple with a gold plated Buddha statue which can still be seen there today.

name: Monara Gala Mountain (Peacock Hill)
description: Often referred to as Peacock Hill, Monara Gala Mountain, at a height of 1513 meters above sea level is the highest mountain in the Pussellawa region of Sri Lanka. This is a popular mountain with hikers as the city of Pussellawa is located only 200 meters lower and the trail to the top of the mountain is relatively easy.

name: Galboda Ella Falls
description: The road to the 30 meter high Galboda Ella Falls may not be very well developed but visitors can opt to go by train from Kandy — Badulla and then allow a further 45 minutes to reach the falls from there.

name: Karambagala Hermitage (Karandulena)
description: Located in the Ambalantota area the Karambagala Hermitage has many caves spread over 2 hillocks. Believed to have once been the temple for King Kithsiri Mevan in the 4th century the hermitage has the ruins of 3 stupas within its site.

name: Paravi Duwa Temple
description: Not all the temples on Sri Lanka are ancient as there are some which have been built fairly recently, like the Paravi Duwa Temple located on Pigeon Island. The island and therefore the temple can be reached by a footbridge but after the 2004 tsunami destroyed the first one a more recent one has since been built.

name: Thotupola Mountain
description: At a height of 2,357 meters Thotupola Mountain is Sri Lanka’s 3rd highest peak and is located in the Horton Plains National Park in the Nuwara Eliya District. There is a 2kms hiking trail to the top which starts from one of the park’s entrances and affords hikers a cool but windy climb.

name: Rajagala Ancient Temple & Ruins
description: The Rajagala Ancient Temple and Ruins located on a forested mountain over 300 meters above sea level is perhaps Sri Lanka’s second most important archaeological site after the Mihintale monastery in Anuradhapura. Apart from rock drawings which date back to prehistoric times there are over 100 stupas on the 1,600 acres site plus over 600 other ancient artifacts already found.

name: Alagiyawanna Ella Fall
description: Although these falls are only 4 meters in height they are worth visiting because, as there name Alagiyawanna (Beautiful coloured), implies the sun’s slivers of light shining on the waters through the forest is an impressive sight. The area surrounding the falls is also of interest to visitors and includes the Balana Pass which the Portuguese were unable to penetrate during their 250 years rule over the coastal regions.

name: Yala-East (Kumana) National Park
description: Abutting the larger Yala National Park, Kumana national Park was in fact called Yala-East National Park until its name changed in 2006. As well as significant flora and fauna in the park, it has a long and ancient history which can be seen by some of the inscriptions on rocks in the park.

name: Kadatkarai Palli, Kalmunai
description: Kadatkarai Palli, Kalmunai is located near to Kalmunai Beach and is one of the oldest mosques in Sri Lanka. This mosque is one of the holiest places in Sri lanka and looks magnificent at night when it is lit up.

name: Danthure Viharaya - Yati Nuwara
description: Named after Danthure which was famous as a battlefield where Portuguese rule of Kandy was ended the Danthure Viharaya at Yati Nuwara is a “Tampita Viharaya” meaning it is a temple which is built on pillars. The ceiling and walls on the upper floor of the temple have paintings from the Kandyian era and it also houses a statue of a sitting Buddha.

name: Kadurugoda Viharaya (Kantarodai)
description: Kadurugoda Viharaya was only discovered in 1917 after reports were heard of locals finding bricks somewhere. Later excavations have unearthed a shrine room, some Buddha footprints, parts of statues and some coins which pre-date the Christian era.

name: Devram Vehera
description: Devram Vehera in Pannipitiya is perhaps a unique temple complex due to it only having 1 monk in residence. The monk does have some lay monks to help him with the daily tasks but he alone is responsible for all the administration. Although these tasks keep him busy he has taken on the extra work of writing the Thripitakaya on stone slabs in order that they may be preserved in the same way ancient texts have.

name: Parakrama Samudraya - Polonnaruwa
description: Today when you see the large Parakrama Samudraya reservoir it is difficult to imagine that this was just one portion of the massive reservoir system built in the 12th century by King Parakramabahu the great.

name: Minneriya National Park
description: 182kms away from Colombo, in Sri Lanka’s North Central Plains is the Minneriya National Park which is perhaps famous for its herds of wild elephants gathering between May and October. This is the largest known gathering of Asian elephants anywhere in the world.

name: Ridi Viharaya
description: Ridi Viharaya also known to some as the Silver Temple is located in Ridigama, Sri Lanka. The temple was built in the 2nd century BC in gratitude to the place that provided the silver ore needed to complete one of Sri Lanka’s largest stupas at Ruwanwelisaya.

name: Kaluwamodara Sri Kalyanaramaya Purana Viharaya
description: The Kaluwamodara Sri Kalyanaramaya Purana Viharaya is located 1km from Aluthgama town and houses the largest marble statue of Buddha in Sri Lanka. The temple was built in 1825 and the statue was presented to it from Burma in 1870 however, according to the Myanmar authorities today, the statue is much older than just 130 odd years.

name: Deegawapiaya archaeological site, Ampara
description: 1 of only 16 places Buddha is said to have stayed on his 3 trips to Sri Lanka, Deegawapiaya, Ampara is an important archaeological site. At the site there are many stone flower pedestals which is an indication as to how important this site was in ancient history.

name: Single Tree Hill
description: Topped by a single tree, Single Tree Hill is the 10th tallest mountain in Sri Lanka and a popular climb for visitors who are treated to some magnificent views from the top.

name: MADHU THREE WHEELER SERVICE CENTRE KURUNEGALA
Chundikkulam Bird Sanctuary
description: After a troubling history Chundikkulam became a National Park on 22 June 2015. The area had been a bird sanctuary since 1938 however since the civil war the area had been used for Sri Lankan military bases. The park finally got its status after recommendations made by the United Nations Environment Program in 2014.

name: The Grand Hotel - High Tea
description: A timeless tradition for more than 100 years, Afternoon Tea at Grand Hotel takes place each day in the hotel s Parlor. In the 1840's Afternoon Tea became popular as an activity to break up the day and provide a snack between lunch and dinner. Today at Grand Hotel our guests can enjoy this tradition between 3:30 and 6pm, for about Rs.1000,- per person

name: Hulan Ella ( Walawe Ganga West Falls)
description: Due to other waterfalls being nearby, Hulan Ella is sometimes referred to as Walawe Ganga West Falls. These 30 meter high falls are located 8kms from Mulgama on the Balangoda – Kaltota but a 4 wheel drive is recommended for that last 8kms.

name: Dutch Fort of Kalpitiya
description: Completed in 1676 the Dutch Fort of Kalpitiya played a major role in the Dutch East India Company’s trade in cinnamon. Today, although suffering from the ravishes of time, the fort stills stands prominent in the surrounding village.

name: Mirissa Whale and Dolphin Watching
description: From November to April whale and dolphin watching is a popular activity in Sri Lanka and one of the best places to do it from is Mirissa. Boat tours can be taken from Mirissa harbor on the island’s southern coast.

name: Ancient Temple Kingdom of Yapahuwa
description: In 1272, King Bhuvenakabahu moved his capital to Yapahuwa, built on a granite rock outcrop, from Polonnaruwa. The new capital, being 100 meters above the surrounding lowlands, afforded better protection for his sacred Tooth Relic. Although the move saved the relic from being taken by the invading Dravidians, it was unable to save it from the invading Pandyans in 1284. After the loss of the relic, the capital was mainly abandoned, only to be used by monks.

name: Manthiri Manai Mansion
description: Now abandoned and dilapidated the Manthiri Manai Mansion is located in Jaffna. The mansion’s history, which was built in a mix of both Hindu and colonial design, has been lost in time but some believe it was a part of the last king of Jaffna’s palace.

name: Talaimannar Beach
description: Located on Sri Lanka’s north western coast, until the severe cyclone of 1964, Talaimannar Beach had been the main ferry point for transport to India. The cyclone destroyed the railway lines which made the ferry point a viable option. It has only been as recently as 2015 that the railway line has once again been restored and so the point may again see prominence.

name: Alupotha Ella Fall
description: Alupotha Ella Fall is located in Alupotha village in the Ratnapura District. To locals, the fall is often referred to as Rathambara Falls (Red Falls) due to a legend that a red-coloured eel inhabits the falls and during times of drought, the eel assumes the role of a deity and dresses in white robes, walking across the falls at midnight. If the eel, dressed in white, crosses the falls on 3 consecutive nights, rain will come.

name: Dimbulagala Raja Maha Vihara
description: Located 16kms southeast of the ancient city of Polonnaruwa, Dimbulagala Raja Maha Vihara is made up of numerous caves in the Dimbulagala range of hills and although once famous in ancient times, had laid abandoned until it was once again developed in the 1950s.

name: Metikotamulla Sadharma Thilakarama Purana Viharaya
description: Metikotamulla Sadharma Thilakarama Purana Viharaya is located 8.2kms from Veyangoda, 5.8kms on the Veyangoda and Minuwangoda Road and then a further 2.5kms towards Metikotamulla. There is little known history of this temple except that it was built in the start of the 16th century by a son of King Weera Parakramabahu VIII.

name: Sapugoda Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Buddhism was scarce in the coastal regions of Sri Lanka in the 18th century which meant Buddhist temples were few and far between. The Sapugoda Rajamaha Viharaya was therefore named after the region’s chief monk (Sapugoda) who had listened to the devotees’ wishes for a more convenient worship place and organized the building of the temple in response.

name: Adi Hate Ella Falls
description: This waterfall, located in the Badulla District of Sri Lanka, is relatively unknown due to it being deep in the jungles off Passara. Although visiting the falls requires following an uphill path, the path is well used by locals who often visit the 60 foot deep pool at the foot of the falls. There are other falls along this stretch of the river but unfortunately they have no paths leading to them.

name: Kethsirigama Mihindu Aranya Senasanaya
description: Kethsirigama Mihindu is located at the base of a mountain and its old pagoda rises like a mini mountain of its own. The few monks that now live in this hermitage have however built a new pagoda but whilst the pagoda may be new, the stone steps leading to it are ancient.

name: Rankirimada Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Like many other temples in the Kurunegala district the Rankirimada Rajamaha Viharaya appears to have some Kandyan influences but this is due to the temple being renovated during the Kandyan era as it is believed to have originally been an ancient rock temple dating back to the 2nd century.

name: Dimbulagala Kosgaha Ulpotha Ruins
description: Known as Dimbulagala Kosgaha the huge Dimbulagala Rock is scattered with ruins. The site was developed by thye Thero Dimbulagala Hamuduruwo since 1950 until his death in 1995. Legends surround the reasons why the Thero developed this area but most prominent is the one that he discovered a spring here which never dries up even during droughts.

name: Algama Kanda Ancient cave Temple
description: Algama Kanda Ancient cave Temple is located on Algama Mountain in the Kurunegala district. This is just one of many cave temples which are believed to have been built by King Walagamba who spent 14 years hiding in caves from the invading Indian forces. On being reinstated as King he is thought to have built temples in all the caves where he had hid.

name: Perumal Ella
description: Although the Perumal Ella waterfall bordering the Knuckles reserve above the Victoria Reservoir is a beautiful sight you will need a 4 wheel drive vehicle to get there and then still have to take a short hike along a riverside path.

name: Kotte Raja Maha Viharaya
description: The Kotte Raja Maha Viharaya which is located in Pita Kotte is officially recognized as an official Sri Lankan Government archaeological site. Although the temple is known to have been built in the 15th century, little is known about from that time until it was discovered in 1813. Today the site hosts an annual homage to the Sacred Tooth Relic which Kotte was known to have held at one time.

name: Harasgala Gallen Viharaya
description: The Harasgala Gallen Viharaya is located at the foot of a massive 800 meter high rock outcrop called Harasgala rock. The temple, which dates back to the 2nd century BC, includes several drip ledge caves which are thought to have been used by ancient monks.

name: Puwakmal Ella / Seetha Oya Ella
description: Puwakmal Ella is a 37 meter high waterfall which can be reached after a 1km hike from the Deraniyagala–Malimbada road and is also known as Seetha Oya Ella. The top of the falls are easy to reach but getting to the bottom will take more difficulty as you would have to struggle over some large boulders.

name: Perawella Ella Falls
description: Located in the Nuwara Eliya District 8kms from Panagama MacDonald Fortress is the 45 meter high, v-shaped Perawella Ella Falls. British colonials in the 19th century would say the falls made a frightening noise as the water cascaded down into a gorge. The British liked to hunt the Sambur Deer in the area but sadly they perhaps hunted too many as today they are a rare sight.

name: Sistersaway B&B
description: Traditional Turkish breakfast and coffee. Tom (co-founder) thinks this is the best breakfast in the South. Such a big portion.

name: Adisham Bungalow
description: Originally built for a British aristocrat in a mix of Tudor and Jacobean style in 1931 today Adisham Bungalow is a monastery which is open to visitors. Whilst home to Sir Thomas Villiers the hall received many prominent personalities but in 1961 the hall was bought by the Roman Catholic Church. The Church converted the hall to a monastery but it remains well preserved with its original, period furnishings and fittings.

name: Araththana Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although Arattana Tampita Viharaya is located in the village of Eladetta in Kandy, it is thought to have been built by the villagers of Arattana, hence its name. Built 2’ above the ground on stone stumps, the temple houses an image room which is known for its paintings of Buddha and his 15 disciples which were restored in 1982.

name: Magul Maha Viharaya, Lahugala
description: One of the largest tourist attractions in Sri Lanka’s Eastern province is the Magul Maha Viharaya at Lahugala. The temple is located 11kms from Pottuvil Town on the northern rim of Lahugala National Park.

name: Ras Vehera (Sesuruwa) Buddha Statue
description: Located close to but not as popular as the famous Awkana statue, at a height of 42’ 4”, the Ras Vehera (Sesuruwa) Buddha Statue is colossal. It is thought that this statue may have been built around the turn of the 4th century by King Mahasen as chronicles tell of such a statue being built by him which was not finished due to his death. This would explain the lack of inscription on the base stone which is unusual.

name: Suresh motors - Nainamadama

name: Galmaduwa Viharaya
description: The Galmaduwa Viharaya located just outside of Kandy was never completed and so never used. This was due to the fact that whilst under construction by King Keerthi Sri Rajasinghe the king heard of a newly discovered cave which he thought would be a better site for the temple.

name: Silvathgala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: It is said that this temple was first built in the 2nd century BC by king Dutugemunu but then rebuilt by king Walagamba about 100 years later in the 1st century BC.

name: R. M. A. S. BANDARA FILLING STATION
Ridikanda Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Built on a 400 foot hill at Kandamalawa in Gomarankadawala, Ridikanda Rajamaha Viharaya’s main temple lies at the foot of the hill along with the ruins of other buildings, whilst a restored stupa is located at the top of the hill. 15 caves with dripledges have so far been discovered on the hill around the temple complex.

name: Old Stupa / Vediyarasan fort
description: Located in the Gulf of Mannar Deft Island is the most remote of Sri Lanka’s islands. Although most of the tourist attractions on the island are from the colonial days there are said to be three stupas on the island. One of these old stupas is in the same location as Vediyarasan fort.

name: Maragala Gallenagoda Len Viharaya
description: Maragala Gallenagoda Len Viharaya is an ancient rock temple located amid a mix of paddy fields and dense jungle. It is said that the temple was built here by a deposed king who found refuge in the cave.

name: Manella Maha Ella Falls
description: Surrounded by giant ferns the Manella Maha Ella Falls is in fact 2 waterfalls, 1 just 6 meters high and the other 20 meters. It is said that this area was used in 103 BC by King Walagamba to hide his army and it is certainly possible given the numerous caves in the area.

name: Mirisavatiya Dagaba
description: Legend has it that the Mirisavatiya Dagaba at the Mahavihara Complex is built in a spot where King Dutugamunu, in the 2nd century BC, mistakenly left his scepter and when he went to retrieve it, it could not be moved.

name: Family Homestay in Ella
description: Its located at a small river with the possibility to go bathing there. They also have a staircase to a private waterfall behind the house. The family living here is gorgeous and the food is just great. It really is the best accommodation we have been her

name: Tomb of Alakeshwara in Pittakotte
description: Although known as the Tomb of Alakeshwara in Pittakotte, evidence would indicate that it was more likely to have been his palace from where he was able to repulse the armies from the north.

name: Lipton's Seat
description: In Sri Lanka Sir Thomas Lipton was a tea mogul and it is said that from where is now called Lipton’s Seat, he would look over his vast tea estates. Although the location is often in cloud, on a clear day, early in the morning, you can see 7 different provinces and 2 seas from this vantage point.

name: Dumbara ella waterfall
description: To reach the Dumbara Ella Waterfall it will require a 4 hour hike from 1 of several villages located about 7kms from Laggana. The waterfall is only 20 meters high with a cave at the bottom but the pool at the bottom and several others in the region are of great importance to zoologists as they contain diverse species such as freshwater shrimp and otters.

name: Makula Purana Tampita Viharaya
description: The Makula Purana Tampita Viharaya is located in the middle of some ancient paddy fields in Kegalle but this was not where it was supposed to be built in the 15th century. The site which had been planned for the temple was flooded at the time and by the time the waters had receded, the sapling which was to be planted at the temple, had already taken root.

name: Lankapatuna Samudragiri Viharaya
description: Although in ruins today the Lankapatuna Samudragiri Viharaya at Trincomalee is thought to have covered 50 acres. The temple is supposed to have been built on the actual spot where the Sacred Tooth Relic first arrived in Sri Lanka.

name: Vilgam Rajamaha Viharaya Ruins
description: There is evidence to indicate that the Vilgam Rajamaha Viharaya Ruins are just 1 of 74 Buddhists sites and shrines that were located in the Trincomalee District in the 10th century, all of which were revered at the time.

name: NASVI Motors
description: Repairs both bajaj and piaggio tuks

name: Diyavini Ella Falls
description: Located in the jungle south of Vikiliya and 8kms east of Balangoda the 60 meter high Diyavini Ella Falls forms a tributary which leads to the Diyavini River. Local villagers believe there are treasures buried near the falls and one of their leaders disappeared whilst searching for them.

name: Thalawila St. Anne's Church
description: Thalawila St. Anne's Church is considered among the oldest of Sri Lanka’s Christian shrines and receives devotees from all around the country. For over 250 years the church hosts a feast during the first half of August and the feast is attended by all religions.

name: The Northern tip of Sri Lanka
description: Although many people think that Point Pedro is Sri Lanka’s most northern point it is in fact Sakkottai, it is just that Point Pedro has the harbor and the lighthouse, neither of which Sakkottai has.

name: Back Of Beyond Dune Camp Yala
Hunas Falls
description: The Hunas Falls are surrounded by hills and tea estates which make then very picturesque. The beauty of these falls is such that several hotels have been established nearby as the falls are also an excellent starting point for hikers to explore the hilly terrain.

name: Maduwanwela Mudalinalage Aramaya
description: Dating back to the 16th century and the kandyan Era the Maduwanwela Mudalinalage Aramaya contains line drawings which are rare if not unique. As well as displaying statues of Buddha and other deities, the ceilings of this temple are adorned with images of lotus petals.

name: Kahanawita Ella Falls
description: Despite being claimed to have taken 4 lives in 2011 due to a sudden increase in water levels, the 5 meter high Kahanawita Ella Falls continues to be a popular bathing spot. The waterfalls are located 3.5kms from Dehiowita on the Dehiowita – Deraniyagala road.

name: Kirindi Ella Falls
description: The impressive 116 meter high Kirindi Ella Falls is located in the Kaluwaramukalana Jungle. The falls flow into a deep pool where locals say there is a set of steps leading down to a submerged treasure.

name: Seruwila Mangala Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Ranked among one of the holiest Buddhist shrines in Sri Lanka the Seruwila Mangala Raja Maha Viharaya is located ancient Buddhist temple in the Eastern Province’s Trincomalee district. Built in the 2nd century BC it is said to hold the sacred forehead bone of Lord Buddha.

name: Nillakgama Bodhigaraya
description: Built around the 8th century completely out of granite, the two level Nillakgama Bodhigaraya is considered to be the best maintained Bo-Tree House in Sri Lanka. The house has two entrances carved out of granite and indications would show that it once sported a wooden roof but that has long disappeared.

name: Victoria Dam
description: Sri Lanka’s Victoria Dam is the tallest dam in the country and supports the largest hydro-electric plant in the country. Although construction of this huge dam started in 1978, work on it was not completed until 1985.

name: Kahandawa Raja Maha Viharaya
description: The caves of Kahandawa Raja Maha Viharaya are said to have first been used by King Walagamba and his men as hiding places whilst fending off Indian invaders and then later they were turned into shrines. Around the end of the 1st century BC Monks are said to have taken over the caves to use as a monastery.

name: Ruins of Bowattegala Monastery
description: Evidence, that the villages of Kumana and Panama, in dense jungle today, were once part of a flourishing civilization, can be seen by the ruins which are disbursed in the area, such as those of the Bowattegala Monastery. The ruins of this and other monasteries, reservoirs, dams and canals, all from pre-Christian times and the mountain strewn with rocks and the ruins are now part of the Kumana National Park.

name: Namal Pokuna Aramic Complex Ruins
description: Although the Namal Pokuna Aramic Complex Ruins can be reached on the same road and was built on the same range as the famous Dimbulagala Raja Maha Viharaya it seems to be far less visited. Near to the main site of these ruins there are caves where even today monks often sit inside in meditation.

name: Dambulla Somawathi Stupa Archaeological Site
description: Relatively unknown to tourists and pilgrims alike, the archaeological site of Dambulla Somawathi Stupa, located behind the more famous Dambulla Rangiri Raja Maha Viharaya, is still being excavated. From the stupa there are stone steps leading to the Dambulla cave shrines and among the inscriptions carved on the steps is at least one which dates back to the 1st century BC.

name: Dondra Head Lighthouse
description: Located on the southern-most tip of Sri Lanka is the Dondra Head Lighthouse which is the tallest lighthouse in the country. With a height of 49 meters the lighthouse has 7 floors with a total of 196 steps.

name: Gartmore Falls
description: Known also as “Sri Pada Falls” or “Adam’s Peak Falls”, Gartmore Falls are located about 96kms from Kandy. This 25 meter high waterfall is fed by 2 streams which meet at the top and then falls in 2 sections known as the upper Gartmore Falls and the lower Gartmore Falls.

name: Sudugala Falls
description: Located just a few meters away from the Heightenford railway platform is Sudugala Falls. This waterfall is not very high but it is wide and long. With a width of about 60 meters the waterfall flows down a slope for about 50 meters.

name: Hanguranketha Pothgul Maliga Rajamaha Viharaya
description: It is believed that the site where the Hanguranketha Pothgul Maliga Rajamaha Viharaya sits, which was built in 1830, was the same site as older ruins which date back to the 11th century. The new temple is said to have been built on the site due to a Buddhist priest, having spent the night there, not being able to move his casket of offerings the next morning and took that as a sign to stay there.

name: Kothduwa Purana Raja Maha Viharaya
description: The Kothduwa Purana Raja Maha Viharaya is the only temple in Sri Lanka surrounded by a river which requires a boat to reach. The motor boats which take visitors to the temple are usually driven by monks.

name: Gokanna Viharaya
description: It is said that during Portuguese rule the Gokanna Viharaya was ransacked whilst monks were still inside. The temple had been Buddhist when first built in the 3rd century but when it was rebuilt after its destruction under the Portuguese in the 19th century, it was rebuilt as a Hindu place of worship.

name: Moon Plains
description: Once a garbage site for Nuwara Eliya city, Moon Plains in Sri Lanka’s Central Highlands has been cleaned up to become an Agricultural and Environmental Tourism Zone. Moon Plains present a scenic setting on vast slopes amid jagged peaks where buffalo roam and the occasional leopard stalks the elk.

description: He has a workshop and is ready to go for break downs that are out of his workshop as well

name: Ritigahawatta Kadala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: There are 3 routes by which visitors can arrive at Ritigahawatta Kadala Rajamaha Viharaya but the easiest is considered to be catching a bus to Buddagama then hike 3 miles through the jungle to Ritigahawaththa village. There seems to be controversy as to who built this temple, a son of King Saddathissa or King Walagamba but whoever did added a unique feature and that is 2 stone gutters along the sides of the stupa.

name: Blow Hole (Hummanaya)
description: Considered the second largest in the world, Sri Lanka’s only blow hole Hummanaya can blow water as high as 30 meters in the air. Located on Sri Lanka’s southern coast about 5kms from Dikwella, this natural phenomenon has become a popular tourist attraction.

name: Rajamale Ella Falls
description: The 45 meter high Rajamale Ella Falls are located in the middle of a tea plantation in the Siripada Reserve but can be reached along a 1km footpath from the Hatton to Nallathanniya road.

name: Kuda Vilachchiya Wewa and its Ruins inside Wilpattu
description: Since the 3rd century BC Sri Lanka has been known for its excellent reservoir building and the main reason for this was their sluice system which controlled the flow of water. One of the largest of the reservoirs was Kuda Vilachchiya Wewa which is located in what is now known as Wilpattu National Park. The reservoir itself which was 3kms long has all but disappeared but the ruins of its sluice system can still be seen.

name: Andigala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Although the Andigala Rajamaha Viharaya complex was built by King Dathopatissa II (659-667) of the Anuradhapura Kingdom, caves found at the same location contain inscriptions from the 2nd century BC. The temple is built at the bottom of a huge rock but steps cut in the rock lead to the top where the remains of an ancient Stupa can be seen.

name: Baobab Tree at Mannar
description: With a girth of 19.51 meters and a height of 7.5 meters (as measured in 2018), the Baobab Tree in Sri Lanka’s Mannar District is thought to be both the oldest and largest tree in the country. There are said to be 40 Baobab trees in Sri Lanka, 34 of which are on the island of Mannar. This particular one is thought to have been planted by Arabian sailors in 1477.

name: Kumari Ella Falls
description: Located close to Colombo the Kumari Ella Falls are said to have been named after King Sitawake Rajasinhe’s daughter. Her name was kumara and it is believed that she drowned in the waters of this 4 meter high waterfall.

name: Chathuranga Motors
description: Mechanic- 0712426560

name: Awariyapathaha Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Many temples in Sri Lanka were destroyed throughout history whilst some were restored or rebuilt, others were lost. In the case of Awariyapathaha Rajamaha Viharaya it would appear that it was rebuilt as 3 caves behind the temple indicate that an older temple dating back to the 1st century once existed on the same site.

name: Ambulgama Raja Maha Viharaya
description: Ambulgama Raja Maha Viharaya is located on Ambulgama Mountain which has 20 to 30 caves, all facing east. The mountain is said to be home to a King Cobra measuring 15’. The temple itself is surrounded by many larger than life statues of Buddha and his disciples. Visitors here are also treated to some magnificent views of the surrounding scenery.

name: Alakolagala Ella Falls
description: Unlike many of Sri Lanka’s falls, these falls can be easily reached and seen from a distance of up to 3kms away. The 30 meter high falls are accessible by road but the Alokola Oya River, the source of the falls, runs through mountains and an area where elephants roam freely, which adds to a visitor’s attractions.

name: Demodara Loop
description: The Demodara Loop is a name which has been given to a stretch of railway at Demodara. The line loops and passes under itself. Visitors like to visit the Nine Arch Bridge or walk the 4kms to the station where they can see the line run underneath it.

name: Dun Ella falls
description: Although today suffering from deforestation, the land above the 125 meter Dun Ella Falls is said to be a place where the soldiers of King Rajasinhe would collect wax for use on their bows. To reach the falls you will need a 4 wheel drive vehicle for the road from Bogahatenne and then at the Wewathanne National School take a footpath for a further 3kms.

name: Three wheel motor mechanics
description: This was found with the help of a local when the customers had an mechanical issue and were on the road.

name: Malmora Ella Falls
description: Located in the Lankagama village in the Galle District is the 30 meter high Malmora Ella Falls. Near to these falls is an unusual tree named ‘Kitul’ which only blooms every 8 to 10 years.

name: Kithal Ella Falls
description: With a height of 23 meters Kithal Ella Falls is located about 2.5kms from the town of Ella which is well known for its lush tranquility in the mountains. This picturesque waterfall can be visited by following the railway lines from Kithal Ella railway station for about 15 minutes.

name: Bodhinagala Forest Hermitage
description: Located in the Kalutara district, beneath a leaf canopy in the wet zone of a rain forest reserve, the Bodhinagala Forest Hermitage provides an excellent place for monks to meditate. The Bodhinagala Forest is the nearest rain forest to Colombo and the hermitage was founded in it in the 1950s.

name: UDANTHA MOTORS
description: Repairs bikes but can assist in an emergency.

name: Redeemaliyedda Nagadeepa Viharaya
description: The ruins of Nagadeepa Viharaya are located next to the Nagadeepa Reservoir at Redeemaliyedda in the Badulla District but have not yet been explored. It is known however that the complex contains at least 2 stupas and probably dates back to the 6th century. According to local villagers the site has great mystical, supernatural powers.

name: Wegala Ella Falls
description: Part of a stream which is fed by the Victoria reservoir and crosses the Kandy to Mahiyangana Road is the Wegala Ella Falls. Although the waterfall can be seen on the left hand side of the road, little else is known about it.

name: Sampath Ella Falls
description: In all there are 3 waterfalls that are located on a stream flow from Ampana but the largest of these is the 30 meter high Sampath Ella Falls. Although you can view the waterfall by following the footpath from Malwatte village through a rubber plantation, it is advised you get a guide if you want to get closer.

name: The Pot
description: Customer Recommendation "Stopped at a place called the Pot on the Colombo-Dambulla Rd yesterday. Can recommend it, owner a real character too."

name: Pilkington Point
description: Located at 1400 feet above sea level Pilkington Point offers visitors to Sri Lanka an ideal viewing point. From the view point it is said you can see four different districts on a clear day and also three lighthouses.

name: Uda Ranchamadama Excavation Site
description: The Uda Ranchamadama Excavation Site is where pre-historic burial canoes have been found. The site was first discovered in the early 2000s when land was being prepared for building. Later in 2007 and again in 2008, archaeologists have found several burial canoes and a couple of burial pits which they date to somewhere between the 1st and 12th centuries BC.

name: K S K Motor Cycle Service
Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Sithulpawwa Rajamaha Viharaya is located in the Hambanthota District and is a complex which holds a large number of stupas, cave temples and statues. One cave has drawings which are mainly in red and yellow which have been dated back to the 3rd century BC.

name: Medagoda Pattini Devalaya
description: Medagoda Pattini Devalaya was built in the late 16th century by Sitawaka Rajasinghe. Stories about Rajasinghe tell of him killing his father and then becoming an avid Hindu, killed many Buddhist priests.

name: Sri Sugatharamaya Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Dorabawila Sri Sugatharamaya Rajamaha Viharaya is different from most in so far as its Tampita Viharaya sits on pillars 5 feet tall whereas most will be just 2 or 3 feet off the ground. Apart from the Tampita Viharaya this temple is of relatively simple design with an image house measuring 10.5 feet long and 8 feet in height.

name: Trincomalee Fort
description: Trincomalee Fort otherwise known as Fort Frederick was built by the Portuguese in 1623. It is said that the Hindu temple Koneswaram was on the site where the fort now stands but it was demolished so its materials could be used to build the fort.

name: Devon Falls
description: Located along the A7 highway 6kms west of Talawakele are Devon Falls which are also known as the 'Veil of the Valley'. At an elevation of 1,140 m (3,740 ft) the falls themselves are 93 meters high and are sourced, via a tributary, by the Mahaweli River.

name: Hathbinna Ella Falls
description: In the Galle District, located near the Sinharaja forest, in the village of Lankagama is the 6 meter high Hathbinna Ella Falls. Lankagama village can be reached on the Hiniduma & Deniyaya roads and is surrounded by tea estates.

name: Kele Dambulla
description: In order to reach the ancient rock temple Kele Dambulla visitors must first climb 2 sets of steep steps under a canopy of rubber trees. Whilst the cave which acts as an image house has some fine reclining images of Lord Buddha, many of the other paintings are unfinished.

name: Ranchamadama Prehistoric Canoe Burial Site
description: During renovations to a school in the village of Ranchamadama in the Ratnapuara Distinct an ancient burial site was discovered about a meter under the ground. In 2007 the site was excavated and several funeral canoes were found, along with urns. Investigations show that this ancient burial site dates back to 1359 BC.

name: Casuarina Beach
description: Located in Karainagar about 20kms from Jaffna Casuarina Beach has white sands. Sometimes referred to as Casoorinathis beach is fringed with Casuarina Trees and is considered to be the best beach on the Jaffna Peninsula.

name: Pulligoda Galge Frescos
description: There is a current debate as to the age of the Pulligoda galge frescos which are located in a shallow cave 5.5kms south of Dimbulagala temple. Although some scholars state the frescoes are of a style used in the 12th century, others claim that materials used would indicate they were created much earlier, perhaps as early as the 4th century.

name: Degaldoruva Raja Maha Vihara
description: Located in Amunugama, Kandy, Degaldoruwa Raja Maha Vihara is an ancient rock temple famous for its Kandyan Era Frescoes. Although the temple’s construction was started in 1771 by King Kirti Sri Rajasinha it was not completed until much later under his son’s reign.

name: Sathurukondan Wetlands and Birds' Sanctuary
description: The Sathurukondan Wetlands in Sri Lanka are a Bird Sanctuary popular with bird spotters from all around the world. Some of the rarer breeds of birds which can be seen in the sanctuary are Spot Billed Pelican and Lesser Adjutant Stork but other rare animals may also be spotted, like the endangered Broad Snouted Crocodile.
