name: The Barn by Starbeans
description: Good coffee and place to work on a laptop if you need. -Tom 2024

name: Agra Upa Falls
description: Although the road to these falls and Dayagama has now been closed, access is still possible by a 1000 meter hike along the old road from the Horton Plains Visitor center. These falls along with their nearby sister falls are impressive multi cascading waterfalls which help feed the Agra reservoir and then ultimately Sri Lanka’s largest river, the Mahaweli River.

name: Lebanon Estate waterfall No 2
description: The smaller of 2 waterfalls hidden away on the Lebanon Estate is 20 meters in height and is a 1.5kms hike from the 1st which is just 250 meters from the road.

name: Jodu Ella Falls (Bambarella Knuckles Falls)
description: Sometimes referred to as Bambarella Knuckles Falls the 45 meter high twin Jodu Ella Falls is sourced by the Moragaha River which starts in the Knuckles Mountain range. The area in which the falls are located is known for its abundance of wildlife including wild boar and porcupine.

name: Mihintale Aramic Complex
description: In its hay-day the Mihintale Aramic Complex is said to have been home to 2000 monks and so they would have required appropriate amenities for that number. Centered round a shrine is what is thought to have been the complex’s hospital with evidence showing it was built in the 8th century.

name: Lankaramaya - Anuradhapura
description: Lankaramaya in the ancient Anuradhapura Kingdom is thought to be the site where King Walagamba stayed after he defeated the Tamil invaders in 103 BC. The Lankaramaya stupa is of the same style as the first Buddha stupa built on Sri Lanka after the introduction of Buddhiam in 250 BC.

name: Deegavapi Viharaya
description: It is believed that the 6th century BC Deegavapi Viharaya is 1 of only 16 places the Buddha stayed during his 3 trips to Sri Lanka. When he stayed here on his 3rd trip it is said he was accompanied by no less than 500 arahaths (Buddhists who have achieved nirvana).

name: Kottimbulwala Raja Maha Vihara
description: The Kottimbulwala Raja Maha Vihara stands majestic halfway along the Balangoda-Hatangala road. This is a time honoured temple that has a huge rock cavern which has numerous legends associated with it. The sparseness of cultivated land between the mountains and jungle surrounding the temple are witness to the simple lifestyle lived by the temple’s inhabitants.

name: Back of Beyond - Jungle Hideaway, Pidurangala
Abayagiri Stupa
description: With a diameter of 106 meters and a height of 75 meters Abayagiri Stupa, at the Abayagiri Monastery is the 2nd tallest stupa in Anuradhapura. Originally built in the 2nd century BC and renovated in the 12 century, the stupa has 4 entrances, complete with ponds, one at each of the cardinal directions. The 4 ponds are filled from water draining from the stupa’s 2 large terraces.

name: Samadhi Statue of the Abayagiri Monastery
description: There were many great sculptures made during Sri Lanka’s Anuradhapura era but the 7’ 3” high Samadhi Statue, made from Dolomite Marble is perhaps the best example. The statue was discovered at the site of the Abayagiri Monastery in 1886 and at that time it had hollow eyes which are an indication that the eyes were originally some kind of precious gem and had become victims to treasure robbers.

name: Dakkhina Stupa of Anuradhapura
description: A large stone stupa in Anuradhapura dating back to the 2nd century BC was identified in 1946 as being the cremation site of Dutugamunu (161 BC – 137 BC). For centuries prior to 1946 both Tamils and Sinhalese had thought it to be the tombstone for the Tamil king Ellalan (205 BC – 161 BC) and worshipped there accordingly.

name: Naigala Rajamaha Viharaya
description: On 22 April 1966 Naigala Rajamaha Viharaya was formerly declared an archaeological site in Sri Lanka by the government and is located near Weeraketiya in the Hambantota District. This is considered a rare example from the Ruhuna Kingdom and features 7 stupas.

name: Mana Ella Fall
description: The 67 foot high Mana Ella Fall is located on a mountain called Striee Pura (Queens’s paradise) in the Badulla district of Sri Lanka. Local legends say in the 10th century the king of Walagamba built secret tunnels throughout the mountain and also built stone bathing areas for the Queens.

name: Hikkaduwa Beach
description: Hikkaduwa Beach was first discovered by the tourism industry in the 1960s and it has been popular ever since. With miles of beach, sunken ships, a reef garden, beautiful sunsets and an assortment of water sports it has something for any visitor.

name: Sunken Town of Maskeliya
description: Although the town of Maskeliya has been sunk beneath the Moussekelle Reservoir since 1968 it has during times of extreme drought re-emerged. When this happens many people visit the town to see the temples and shrines which were once places of pilgrimage.

name: National Art Gallery
description: Sri Lanka’s National Art Gallery is located in Colombo and whilst many of the halls can be rented by artist to display their works there is one hall which houses a permanent collection of the diverse artistic styles found on the island.

name: Nakuleswaram Kovil
description: Nakuleswaram Kovil is a temple which was destroyed along with many others during the Portuguese rule but unlike some of the others, this was rebuilt in 1859 and has statues of the mountain deities.

name: Ethawetunu Ella Falls
description: With a height of only 5 meters Ethawetunu Ella Falls may be relatively small for waterfalls in Sri Lanka but its cascade is none the less beautiful for it. Located just over 7kms from Suriyakanda Town or 29kms from Ambilipitiya, it is in the Wijeriya region of Sri Lanka.

name: Bandigewatta Ella Fall
description: Located in the Ratnapura District Bandigewatta Ella Falls drop an impressive 24 meters to a tributary of the Walawe River. Local villages claim that at the foot of the falls is a cave which is seemingly endless. Due to plantations upstream from the falls the surrounding area is suffering from degradation.

name: Hakurutale Ella
description: Accessed from the road leading to the Victoria Power Station the waterfall Hakurutale Ella is in 2 parts. The most beautiful of the parts is the upper part but unfortunately only the lower part can be seen from the road.

name: Swastika Pokuna
description: Created in the 12th century Swastika Pokuna is one of the most beautiful ancient ponds that can be found in Sri Lanka today but surprisingly it is no longer a place for popular pilgrimages. It was recently however restored but unfortunately once again fell foul of treasure hunters in 2013.

name: Mangoves of Madu Ganga
description: A beautiful river named Madu Ganga is located between Colombo and Galle and as Sri Lanka’s second largest wetlands, has provided for the local people from before the colonial days. What is considered a treasure of the Madu Ganga is its mangroves which are home to a diverse array of aquatic life.

name: Miyugunarama Rajamaha Viharaya
description: Miyugunarama Rajamaha Viharaya in the Kurunegala district is believed to be one of the first temples built by King Devanampiyatissa after he became a Buddhist in the 3rd century BC. He later built many more temples, all just 4 miles apart.

name: Midigama Beach
description: As Sri Lanka’s beaches on its southern coast are becoming better known, they are also becoming more crowded. Fortunately for visitors that prefer a more relaxed stay on a beach, Midigama Beach is a small village which shares the same warm waters as the more popular beaches but without the crowds.

name: National Museum
description: Sri Lanka’s National Museum when opened in 1877 was called the Colombo Museum and consisted of just one building. Since 1942 it became the National Museum and has continued to expand to include associated museums in other towns such as Jaffna and Kandy.
